Because you can not reasonably mean that you should punish Poland because they want the same system of appointment as the one that Sweden uses? You are in a violent outburst with the European people, but you are not learning anything from the ever-decreasing turnout.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the representatives of the Commission too, let us talk about defense with Brexit. The notion of permanent structured cooperation brings us back to the method of small steps, or the gear dear to Jean Monnet. It is a question of bogging down the European countries which still have a little strategic autonomy to make them lose what little independence they have left, in favor of collectivization, of a pooling of weaknesses. The pooling of weaknesses will never be a strength. To be clear, there are only two militarily capable countries in Europe, primarily France and England. Britain saved its strategic independence by leaving the European Union. There remains the case of France. If France continues on the path of pooling, it will no longer be a military or diplomatic power. When Germany, thanks to its industrial supremacy - we have to admit it - will have a monopoly on the manufacture of weapons, nuclear power in addition, my country, France, will be gone. As General de Gaulle said, "when we give up defending ourselves, we disappear, because we let other nations make our history for us".

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, from what was discussed at the European Council Summit, I would like to point out the following: the European pillar of social rights is a utopian proclamation. Any discussion on equal opportunities and access to the labor market, on rights and on social protection is dishonest at a time when memoranda have been imposed in Greece that equate employment with "Stalinist-style" forced labor. The Council, the Commission and the appointed technocrats raise their concerns, problems and existential ideologies, undermining sovereign decisions of democratically elected governments in an unequal bargaining position. The only sure thing is that European politics is cynically and heterogeneously pursued, beyond the real needs and challenges of citizens, and offers the selfish benefit of some apolitical decision-making centers. Instead of continuing the current punitive attitude with arbitrary and unilateral criteria, until its complete degeneration, the Union must implement the Treaties on proportional assistance of the Member States in the framework of cooperation and solidarity.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! I believe that by officially advancing the Defense Union, the European Council has taken an important step here. Here, it should be made clear to some - like the previous speakers - that Europe will regain its sovereignty, and that is a very crucial point. I hope that with all the reform measures in Germany we can manage to create a government that can act quickly and that not so many rush into irresponsibility. I also think it is important that the question of the proposals for the development of economic and monetary union be brought forward on the basis of the Commission's proposals. And, Mr President of the Commission, I think it is extremely important to say that the euro is the currency of the entire European Union, that there is an obligation of all countries - with the exception of the special regime for Denmark - to follow this, and that it is right to help these countries achieve this goal. Let me make a few comments on Brexit. We must now quickly have negotiating lines both for our definition of the transitional arrangement and for the negotiating objective. And I believe that we are on the right track in the cooperation between the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament. It must remain clear: the sentence that was set in the guidelines for the first round, according to which a country that leaves the EU cannot have the same advantages as a country that remains in the EU and bears the conditions and burdens must in my opinion be the assessment rate. I believe we can achieve something on this basis. We can already negotiate the future commercial agreement in this second phase. But there won't be enough time, for that we need the transitional regulation - a transitional regulation in which the full acquis of the European Union must apply, including the European Court of Justice.It must also be clear that cherry picking is not possible.When I hear here that the City of London is making suggestions that special regulations should be created here and that they want Canada plus plus plus: The condition here also applies that one cannot have special advantages and that for this reason clearlyis that something like clearing houses and similar issues belong in the European Union.London cannot perform tasks that are the task of the European Union.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Brok, from what you have just said, it sounds very much to me as though you have no interest whatsoever, and nor does Mr Barnier. This is what I said earlier when they had a meeting with various people: there is no interest in doing business for the City of London. Therefore, Britain would be better off leaving without any agreement whatsoever, on World Trade Organisation terms. No matter how much damage this might do to Europe, it seems to me that Mr Barnier is not interested in the damage it does to the people of Europe. He is more interested in punishing us for doing something to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, of course we appreciate that Parliament’s President is giving blue cards because we have a lively debate. But we should not accept a situation where a blue card is given twice to the same Member of Parliament. This is beyond the kind of balance we should have, so please pay attention to this.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. -Colleague! The Member States of the European Union and the European Union have the same interest in safeguarding their interests and the same rights as the United Kingdom, and we must find a fair balance between them. You do not want - and you have said this over and over again - no agreement at all, and you use every hair-raising argument to make it clear that you do not want an appropriate solution at all. You are opposed to any solution, and therefore do not blame us on the fact that we will find a balanced compromise. I believe this alibi search for the total cracker is your responsibility and the responsibility you have for your own country. And the question that has to do with the future of jobs in your country - your responsibility. And we see in opinion polls that you are increasingly losing support in your own country.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, Mr Tusk, I am going to remind you of a phrase you said at the Council meeting: 'Stopping illegal immigration comes first'. In the previous plenary session, I had the opportunity to strongly criticize that statement. I am glad that I am here today so that I can tell you directly: you will see, Mr Tusk, the best way to combat exclusionary nationalism, populism, is not by copying their messages. You said one more thing, which shows that you do not understand very well even the policy that the Commission has implemented. You said that member countries agree that relocation is not the solution to illegal immigration. Of course not, Mr Tusk, because relocation is designed for refugees. So let's see if we can approach the migration debate as a whole with a little more consistency and with a little more solidarity and political intelligence. Here we have demanded a comprehensive approach to migration, we have demanded that ad hoc solutions be overcome and we have demanded that international legality be complied with, which says that refugees have the right to be protected in European countries. So I suggest, first, that you listen to us a little more and, second, that this new message that you have launched be the message that will remain in the coming months. Because, you see, we are losing prestige, prestige as an institution - the European Union as a whole - precisely because of statements like these and because of unsupportive policies like the ones you are defending, against what the European Commission is trying to do. And one last thought, Mr. President: you see, Mr. Donald Trump just dropped a humanitarian political and security bomb, claiming that he is going to stop funding the Palestinian refugee agency. I beg you, Mr Tusk, to keep this in mind to balance it, because the last thing we need to do is leave the most vulnerable Palestinians even more abandoned.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - I would like to thank the Estonian Presidency for the work done and the good cooperation in recent months. It was no easy task with such an ambitious program. In the field of employment and social affairs, the Presidency has taken many steps forward in many files. I mention, among other things, the coordination of social security and the Posting of Workers Directive. The proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights also took place under the Estonian Presidency. While I support many of these Presidency priorities, including a social pillar, I don't want to fool our citizens. We must be clear and honest about what Europe can achieve and impart and what not. For this reason, the social pillar is a missed opportunity for me. The Pillar could have guided the Member States to achieve upward convergence, but unfortunately it has become bogged down in high-flown political statements. In doing so, the boundary between what is the competence of the EU and what that of the member states is and should remain. I said it before and I will say it again: it is primarily the responsibility of the Member States to achieve social progress and economic growth. Europe must provide added value and not undermine or replace the policies of the member states.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: - Sir.Chairman!Then another meeting was held, another declaration was signed, another speech was given, and not least, even more steps were taken towards the United States of Europe.But honestly: you talk about us taking citizens' concerns seriously, but you forget to listen to them.Millions of citizens are unemployed or living under severe consequences, with poor wages and poor working conditions.We can all feel the consequences of the deterioration in welfare, which of course comes from economic cuts.If we are to take the citizens seriously, it requires that we dare to break with the EU's internal market.It requires that we dare to break with the EU's austerity policy.That is why I would like to urge you to stick your head out of the EU glass bubble, talk to the citizens, listen to them and ask them if they actually want the United States of Europe, or if they want power back in their own hands.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: - Mr President, dear President of the Council, dear President of the Commission, dear colleagues! Months have passed without us seeing any answers to the crucial questions about Brexit. Under what conditions are European companies allowed to trade? What rules, what tariffs apply to the export of goods such as German cars to the British Isles? It's about hundreds of thousands of jobs in Germany and in the rest of the European Union. The Commission and the heads of state and government are risking this without need, because they are abusing Brexit above all to make the exit of other states from the EU as unattractive as possible. This wrong focus is an almost deliberate damage to the economy, workers and consumers. Since the Treaty of Rome, the European project was intended for the free exchange of goods and services - in Europe, but also with the whole world. It is a shame that suddenly nobody wants to remember it during Brexit.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to wish you a good and fruitful year at the beginning of this new session, but the global context and even the results of the Council we are discussing today predict a not so easy year. We are facing challenges generated by crises that may have seemed punctual and unrelated in 2015, 2016 and even 2017. Today, however, they are mutually reinforcing and accelerating. I appreciate the fact that the European Council in December addressed many pressing and sensitive issues, but I am skeptical of achieving all the objectives set. I would like to point out once again the issue of migration. More jokingly, more seriously, if we make an analogy between the European Union and global warming, then the phenomena of mass migration are analogous to extreme weather phenomena. And, if a cause of global warming is the concentration and intensification of industrial activities, then, analogously, the centralization and polarization of the Union are clear causes of migratory phenomena. The obvious solution is to rebalance the Union by increasing the powers of the Member States. President Tusk questioned the idea of ​​a compromise. Okay, but the first step must be taken by those who made a mistake in opening the gates of migrants irresponsibly! (The speaker agreed to answer a question following the collection of the blue card in accordance with Rule 162 (8)).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- I would like to ask our Romanian colleague, Mr Rebega, who I know was a pro-European and, by chance, joined the ENF group, why he is skeptical about the future of the European Union and what would be the alternative to the Union.European?Because the alternative would be just a gray area, an area of fear, an area where we would all have a lot more problems than we have now.I believe that the future is a stronger, more integrated European Union.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: Answer to a question addressed in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- I am very happy to answer my colleague.I remain a pro-European, but I give two examples to our colleague in Romania, namely: the solidarity that the European Parliament refers to every time by imposing compulsory migrant quotas - however, the Commission blatantly violates the treaties on the functioning of the European Union.So, if we want a stronger European Union, we must first of all respect what we have decided.Secondly, it is important for you, Mr Frunzulică, to remind you once again that Romania is not part of the Schengen area, even if it meets all the technical conditions imposed by the European Commission.You have to answer the question: is this a European Union that we want?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, every Council of the Union outlines, by correlations, its future that worries you so much. Fierce competition of capital, international and intra-EU, for profit and power. The common denominator is the intensity of barbarism. See: Banking Union, ie strengthening the banks for new financing in the capital, means auctions of public property everywhere. In place of the International, the European Monetary Fund, that is, perpetuation of the commission everywhere. Social pillar of sharing poverty, insecurity, flexible employment, ie reduced popular demands and social consensus. And if that is not achieved, repression. European Union present worldwide for its interests within and distinctly within NATO, enhanced military cooperation. That is, the so-called export of Democracy, in the reality of war, with thousands of victims and refugees drowned or trapped. Hold states toys on their backs, whether they need them as slaves or not. Each unification step includes contrasts, isolationist tendencies or even centrifuges. In any case, the intensity of exploitation and the dangers to the people. The wolf-alliance of capital is not humanized. It is overthrown along with its power in every state.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! Gentlemen, Presidents of the Council and the Commission! It seems that discussing the summit conclusions is always such a ritual work, but in fact it is not so with this Council. I want to highlight in particular the renewed Common Security and Defense Policy. It may be the missing common denominator that we lack in the European Union today. It also responds to the perceived security deficit of the citizens of the Member States. And it also has the potential to connect Member States and connect citizens. Hence, it is to be welcomed and noted that the permanent deepened defense cooperation has two new members. These are Portugal and Ireland. Thus, already 25 Member States are involved in this cooperation. We expect PESCO to be both broad and ambitious. However, how far these ambitions will reach, we will learn from the national implementation plans and commitment to the implementation of the first adopted joint projects. I would also like to emphasize that this is also a way to strengthen this European pillar of NATO through coordination and also the use of the effect of such financial leverage in joint financing, in particular, defense expenditure. Here, I would like to emphasize that a balance is also necessary here, so as to balance it both geographically and to include small and medium-sized industries. Finally, I would also like to say about the Brexit issue. It seems to us that it is extremely important that we have significant progress in financial matters, securing citizens' rights, but in fact, we are waiting for these decisions, perhaps not so much the final ones, concluding this divorce from Great Britain, but rather a change of this decision. I think we would all be most pleased if this change were to happen in the UK. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much for the opportunity, Mr President and Representative.I have actually noticed that you have used the word 'adequate' budget in the context of the European Defense Union.Does the People's Party, and in your opinion, require "adequate" budgetary resources within the current framework or far beyond the current framework?

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card - Mr. Deputy, we all know very well that new tasks are also new obligations not only in terms of their implementation, but also in the financing of this project.We know that these new defense tasks also require an increase in the budget minimums, in particular when we are talking about joint expenditures both on armaments and on organizational solutions, on increasing our expenses, our capabilities, in particular our defense capabilities.Therefore, it cannot be considered that the current budget sufficiently responds to the challenges included in the defense union project.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the December European Council marked an important milestone on Brexit and we expect the commitments of the joint report to be swiftly and faithfully translated into the draft treaty and the remaining issues to be resolved. This Parliament will continue to be vigilant and attentive, the bastion for the defense of citizens' rights. Of course, as President Tusk said, our hearts are always open. Just as our position is balanced and firm, and if we say no to "cherry picking" on financial services, we mean precisely that, that the basket is one and not three, and that to have the "passport" one must be in the internal market. On Economic and Monetary Union I believe that the difference drawn now by President Tusk on what is realistic and what is not between the proposals of the Commission and Parliament should be reviewed in the light of the evolution of the position in some countries - I am thinking of the German coalition agreement. . Smart realism is to incorporate the ESM into European law and to allocate specific additional resources to the EU budget for economic stabilization and convergence. We are ready on this ground to play our role.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the British need to know that we are not happy about your departure. The European Union loses a bit of its essence with the departure of the United Kingdom. Therefore, we can affirm here today that it is in our will to achieve the best possible agreement for both parties. So that the morning after March 19, the European Union has lost a partner, but has retained a friend and an ally. During 2017 we Europeans have also become aware of our security. The permanent structured cooperation on defense that was launched last year is already a European milestone and of which my country, Spain, is proud to be an integral part. At the last European Council of the year, issues that are fundamental to me were also discussed: the social dimension, education and culture. Europe means, ladies and gentlemen, progress and equal opportunities. It means common values ​​and shared principles. It means solidarity with those who are having a hard time, whether due to the economic crisis or the refugee crisis. It means a greater awareness of the environment and the protection of our natural heritage. In short, dear colleagues, the Europe of the 21st century will have to be more social or it will not be. If we want, ladies and gentlemen, a future of opportunities, progress and well-being for the next generations, let us start investing in it.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, the Brexit debate is still overshadowed by a complete lack of clarity as to what the UK Government actually wants to achieve. Deep divisions in the UK Government are clear for all to see. Approaching two years after the referendum, they have still not settled on what they want as a final destination in this process. At the same time, British public opinion has not rallied behind the referendum results, as one might have expected. If anything, it has shifted slightly the other way. There are still significant doubts. Nigel Farage himself admitted last week that this issue is not a settled issue in British politics. So in that context, many in Britain will have noted and appreciated the comments made by the President of the European Council just now, when he said that if Britain had a change of heart the door would still be open. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card question. – [beginning of speech inaudible] and also very pro-European. I just want to ask him, as a follow-up to what he said, about the possibility of a change of heart. How could that come about, and in what timeline? I think it is probably unlikely between now and next March. If that is the will of the British people, what can we do to facilitate that?

name: Richard CORBETT
text: blue-card answer. – You are right that there are many ‘ifs’ in that process. But I think the lesson we have learned from the statements made today by President Tusk and, indeed, President Juncker, is that the door is still open, from the European side, right up to 29 March, or whatever date is scheduled in the end, for Britain to leave the European Union. That means that, if the debates in Britain were to conclude that Britain should reconsider, there is no obstacle from the European side to that happening. That is an important element to enrich the debates in my country about what best to do, as we face a situation which is far more complex, far more costly, and far more difficult than we were told at the time of the referendum.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Mr President, President of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like, in the first place, to emphasize this conclusion on defense, and basically to focus on that. I would naturally like to say that we are very pleased with this progress that has been made. We regret that Portugal joined at the last minute, mainly because the Portuguese government is supported, in Parliament, by totally anti-European countries and totally against NATO, by parties and, therefore, the Portuguese government was in a very difficult situation when Portugal was always in front of all defense efforts. It is unfortunate that we have wasted this time and I would like to leave a recommendation here to Parliament and a recommendation to the Council and the Commission. To Parliament, which constitutes a real defense committee, a defense committee, to monitor these matters and to the Commission that in its next, say in its next term, may have, there may be a defense council, a council of defense ministers chaired by the Vice-President, the High Representative, so that the defense policies of PESCO and the defense policies of the European Union, in conjunction with NATO, can be followed either in Parliament or by a team of ministers from different governments at European level.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the European Council has finally followed up on the requests of Parliament and the Gothenburg Leaders' Summit, formalizing the conclusions on education and culture as an integral part of the European social dimension. In particular, we welcome the commitments for student mobility with the strengthening and extension of the Erasmus + program, for which the CULT commission is asking for the tenfolding of funds in the next multi-year program, the creation of a first network of at least twenty European universities, which favors the mutual recognition of tertiary education diplomas, and the enhancement of multilingualism. It is significant that two initiatives born by the CULT commission have been accepted: the "European Student Card", to facilitate the most disadvantaged students with services and benefits, especially those on the move, and the recognition of the importance of the European Year of Cultural Heritage, on which tomorrow we will have a debate in Plenary requested by us. I hope that the "Education" package, on the Commission's agenda today - which finally launches an action plan for digital skills but also for teaching European values ​​of inclusion in Europe - will be finally approved as soon as possible by the Council. However, there needs to be coherence, i.e. that in the next multiannual framework there are significant increases in resources for education and culture and that also, finally, the EFSI (the European Fund for Strategic Investments) can access cultural and creative.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, 2017 was one of the most significant in the sixty-year history of the European Union when we talk about a common defense of security. It is important to continue with the same intensity and realize the first projects as soon as possible. Sufficient progress has been made in the Brexit agreements, and I stress again that all citizens of the European Union must be treated equally with regard to their rights after the departure of the United Kingdom. I particularly welcome the conclusions on the social dimension of the European Union, education and culture. Although they are largely the responsibility of the member states, they are among the most visible results of European integration. I am glad that the budgetary resources for social activities in the context of the next multiannual financial framework have also been included in the conclusions. At a time when some of the most powerful leaders are irresponsibly questioning the devastating effects of climate change, it is important that we once again jointly reaffirm our commitment to the Paris Agreement. In general, the conclusions are a good basis for continuing work this year, we have the opportunity to translate the commitment to these topics into concrete financial instruments under the Draft Multiannual Budget Framework.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Mr President, we have been a very important part of this legislature denouncing the paralysis of Europe, alerted by the rise of populisms, concerned about the great crises, such as that of refugees, and I believe that it is time to be brave and understand that fundamental reforms are needed for the European Union. Because we need a reform of the euro area that focuses on achieving economic and social convergence and that translates into fair and equal growth. Because we need a social pillar - as the European Social Democrats have been defending - that guarantees the rights of workers, that guarantees decent wages and fair pensions. Because we need a strong Union budget, which addresses new policies such as defense and cooperation, but does not allow cuts in fundamental policies, such as cohesion and agriculture. And I want to point out a question. The three institutions are here. The three men who preside over the European institutions - Parliament, the Council and the Commission - have set the priorities for 2018, forgetting about gender equality policies: the fight against the pay gap is not a priority, gender violence is not a priority, conciliation is not a priority. It is a very worrying forgetfulness, because we put aside half of the European voices, half of the European souls, half of the European hearts: women. We will be here to remember it and to be the voice of your consciences.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly, I would like to say that I agree wholeheartedly with President Juncker when he speaks about the migration crisis and the refugees, especially that there is a need for burden sharing. Pressure needs to be put on the countries who thus far have not taken on their fair share in that regard because, at a time of economic growth, thankfully, right across all Member States, surely every Member State can take in the required number of refugees. Secondly, I was delighted that Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker both emphasised that the door is always open for the United Kingdom to change their minds. That is a very positive message, as Richard Corbett and others have said. In relation to that, I would like to ask President Tusk if, subsequent to March 2019, would a long transition period, rather than a short transition period, be more appropriate to ensure that this could happen and give the British people an opportunity to reflect and then make a decision?

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. president; Mr President of the European Council, Donald Tusk; Apparently, the agenda of this succession of Councils is widening and complicated, to the point of finally reaching a word about social Europe and even about Erasmus +. But it is not tolerable for him to do so at the cost of pending problems not being resolved, much less dissolving, as is the absolutely unacceptable case of the failure of immigration policy. Not a word, not a reflection about the change in migratory routes in the Mediterranean. Because they decline on the Libyan coast, but dramatically increase the pressure, with the tragic result, yesterday, of the death of seven immigrants on the coast of Lanzarote. But above all, the only thing that the conclusion of the European Council says is that it is necessary to reflect on the impediments to the fulfillment of the proclaimed objectives on migration matters. Do I tell you why? Because the demand of this Parliament is not being met. Because the exact opposite is done. Because it persists in the recognition of impotence in the face of non-compliant countries and a comprehensive policy is not addressed - as required by this Parliament - on migration matters, which accounts not only for the social dimension of aid at origin, but also for the fundamental right of the refugee and international humanitarian law in the protection of people who arrive on our shores.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr Tusk, your stance on immigration has sparked a storm of protests in Greece and especially in the Aegean islands. Where migration flows continue unabated. In the Aegean islands, where there are today more than 15,000 refugees and illegal immigrants. Mr Tusk, Greece does not tolerate other refugees and illegal immigrants. Of the 66,400 refugee relocations that the European Union has pledged to carry out from Greece in the last two years, only 1/3 of the relocations have taken place. And you, Mr Tusk, instead of supporting the relocation program, you torpedoed it, silencing countries that refuse to implement relocations. The only solution for Greece, as we have already proposed since 2015, is the departure of Greece from Schengen, so that my country ceases to be a magnet for thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - In my opinion, the last European Council of 2017 was the most important summit of that year. Because it was a summit where the leaders not only reaffirmed their position on certain themes, but also took very clear positions. I am very pleased that we can finally get to the second phase of the Brexit negotiations and that the signal has been given that we will not accept cherry picking. Two, advancements in defense and security. That is what European citizens expect from us: that we take steps to increase security in Europe. We are going to military headquarters, we have the permanent structured cooperation, we have the European Defense Fund. Let's roll all of that out very quickly now. However, as happy as I am in the field of defense, I am really disappointed in the field of asylum and migration. Yes, steps have been taken. Yes, we are moving forward. But I think that in this area, Mr Tusk, we really have to insist that all Member States show solidarity. That we can handle this easily if we all work together. I expect action from you there.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, there have been lots of important exchanges about trade deals with Britain post-Brexit, but there has been a lot less has been about equality and human rights, which are essential elements of democratic societies. The Council conclusion refers to paragraphs 52 and 53 of the UK-EU Joint Report on Phase 1 of the Negotiations regarding the Good Friday Agreement and the rights of the people in the north of Ireland. Many of those rights are rooted in EU law and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Council and this Parliament confirmed that they would uphold the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts. Ireland’s Taoiseach will be here in this Chamber tomorrow. If the Taoiseach is going to make good on his promises to the people of the north of Ireland that we will never again be left behind by an Irish Government – a welcome acknowledgement that we certainly have been – he must guarantee no diminution of our rights as a result of Brexit. That needs to be reflected in the legal text currently being drawn up for phase 1 in order to move on to phase 2, and there must be no ambiguity. The denial of rights in Ireland was wrong in 1968, which marked the start of the civil rights campaign and an awful conflict, and it would be wrong 50 years on, in this year of 2018.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, one of the issues that the European Council once again addressed was the issue of immigration. Unfortunately, however, as always, the European Union's persistent approach to this serious issue does not leave much room for optimism that there will be a meaningful solution. Quite simply, because the European Union refuses to address the root causes of migration and the side effects associated with them. While, for example, everyone agrees that the external borders, especially of the countries of entry, must be effectively controlled, this mission has been removed by the countries' security forces and assigned to ineffective bodies, such as the European Border and Coast Guard. As a result, hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants are being pushed, mainly on the Greek islands, being pushed there by Turkey, and remain living in miserable conditions for an unknown period of time because many countries have closed their borders and do not accept the rate. corresponding to them. So what Treaty are we talking about? For which asylum procedures? So let us arm ourselves with patience and wait until the next European Council meeting to hear the same wishes again.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, in fact this European Council brought more unity, or was intending to bring more unity among the Member States. I am also looking to see more solidarity between all the Member States – and I am referring here to the Schengen Area. We cannot continue to deny access to some Member States fulfilling all the conditions to the Schengen Area, and I refer mainly here to Romania and Bulgaria. I truly hope, President Tusk, that during the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council, Romania and Bulgaria and then Croatia are going to be accepted as fully fledged members of the Schengen Area.  As well as this, I hail the adoption of this European defence industrial development programme and the first EU Defence Fund in view of financing the first capabilities projects for a future European Defence Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the problem of migration and the position of migrants who are on the territory of the Union or waiting at its borders is becoming a long-term challenge to which we must no longer respond with ad hoc solutions.The recent protest of migrants on the Croatian-Serbian border proves that the problem is still present, and some announcements that Turkey could miss several hundred thousand migrants again in the near future are quite worrying.The citizens of a number of member states have punished the current approach to migration in the elections, and the Union must take that into account.Political instability across the continent, even in Germany alone, is a consequence of migration and its effects on society.It is high time that we decide, on the basis of clear and sharp criteria, who Europe needs, whom Europe must help, and whom we will have to tell to seek happiness elsewhere in order to protect the interests of our own citizens.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, the joint report agreed with Brussels in December was an important step forward in agreement on the terms of the UK’s exit from the European Union. Across the United Kingdom there is an acceptance that the integrity of our precious union and of our economy is better protected as a result of Democratic Unionist Party input into the text. We will continue to act in the national interest. An implementation period and trade talks should now go ahead as quickly as possible. Finally, can I say that my constituency, my home, Northern Ireland, is not a bargaining chip? As we have seen over the last few days, whether it be in West Tyrone or delivered by a European Union President in Dublin, careless talk or calculated soundbites can have harmful consequences for political stability in Northern Ireland. I say to Presidents Tusk and Juncker: your understanding of this would be greatly improved by talking to Northern Ireland’s political leaders.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the December European Council discussed, inter alia, the external and internal dimension of the European Union's migration policy. No agreement has yet been reached on the reform of the Dublin regulation. On the relocation of migrants, in particular, there remains an unacceptable unavailability of some Member States, namely the Visegrad group made up of Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary, which reject the decision, which has also been taken, of mandatory quotas. relocation. My hope is that the successes in the fight against human trafficking and therefore the reduction of irregular flows will make the climate of the discussion on internal rules calmer and, therefore, easier. The issue of permanent structured cooperation on defense was also addressed at the December summit. For many years, the main argument against PESCO had been the fear that it could lead to a weakening of NATO. In reality it is quite the opposite: strong European defense strengthens NATO. That is why I think PESCO is good news for the future of the European Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Mr Tusk, we are considering the December meeting today. I would like to ask you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, if you consider 2017 to be a good year? Let's not forget that we ended 2017 with a Brexit, there is still a lot of unrest in the Member States, there is still the idea of ​​division - we have Catalonia, we have a behavior of Hungary that you probably found out, the last being the vandalism of the Romanian embassy in Budapest. have met the technical conditions, Romania and Bulgaria are not in Schengen. Bulgaria holds the presidency and it is unfair to have a president of Europe without being in the Schengen area. Do you consider that for the future, however, we reach a single space, a single Europe, a unity? Because yes, there is progress, we have the social pillar, we have a few things that we have registered as progress, but that does not mean that we have to forget that there are things still unresolved and I think that they must be prioritized.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice President of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU faces daunting challenges, and we have heard many of them mentioned here today, but I don’t think there is reason to be so gloomy about our future. Let’s go back a couple of years. We faced an incredible refugee crisis in 2015. We found the right measures to tackle that crisis at the time. Now we need to find the measures to be able to sustainably handle a migration over a long period of time. This is a different challenge and will need different measures, but we are up to it. I think that in close cooperation between our three institutions – the Council, the Parliament and the Commission – we can come up with answers and I would just caution against making the issue of relocation the biggest issue there is. It is a small issue compared to the overall challenge of migration. It is the last resort measure in the case of an extreme crisis pertaining to refugees.  The bigger challenge we face is migration – people who want to come to Europe to seek a better future – and we have to make sure that we develop all the instruments at a European level to tackle that issue: better border controls, better agreements with countries of origin and countries of transit and also a better system of legal migration so that we get to Europe the people that we need in Europe. I think we are up to this challenge and I think we can face this challenge in the coming year, but we need to do it now. We need to do it within the mandate of this Parliament and this Commission. Likewise, I would say on Brexit that it was a good decision in the European Council, and now we need to get to work. What we need is more clarity from London. Let me just say once again, as President Tusk has also said, that it is not the EU that decided to leave the United Kingdom, it is the United Kingdom that decided to leave the European Union. If at some point the United Kingdom had second thoughts or were to take another decision, obviously the European Union would leave the door open. I want to stress this once again. Finally, let me say this – and I think this is important for our future cooperation – the three institutions need each other and the basis of our cooperation is rooted in the Treaty and in EU law. For this to work, we need full respect for the rule of law in all our Member States. It is not an option you choose. It is not an option you choose on the basis of national sovereignty. It is a fundamental issue for the functioning of the European Union, and I say this against the background of increased support for the European Union amongst the European population in every Member State of the European Union. Even in those Member States who have governments who dispute some of the fundamental values of the European Union, the population still increasingly supports the European Union as the instrument to provide solutions for the challenges that the world throws at us. Let’s be very clear. We are at the beginning of the fourth industrial revolution, a huge challenge. We need to find solutions to the migration challenge, a huge challenge. We need to have an answer to the aggressive and cynical attitude of President Putin of Russia. That is a huge challenge. But we can face this challenge. There is no need for paralysing pessimism in the European Union. We can be more optimistic than before. There are more jobs. Economic growth is up. Support for Europe is up. Let’s use this opportunity to solve some of the problems we need to solve urgently.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, I have nothing to add to what Frans Timmermans has said. I totally agree with you, with your comments, and there is just one thought, one reflection: I want to thank all those who took the floor in today’s debate, because your positive reactions to my comment on Brexit make me even more confident that we will stay united as 27 in every scenario, and this is why I feel so comfortable today – at least in this context. Thank you Frans for your remarks.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - At the end of last year, the leaders of the Member States gave their assessment of the negotiations on the UK's exit from the EU and decided that there was enough progress to move to the next phase. However, I still have all the worries about what the end result of Brexit will be and especially the attitude towards the Bulgarian citizens of the Island. When I say this, I am fully aware that when it comes to protecting the rights of Bulgarian citizens, they will be formally as well protected as the rights of all other European citizens, be they French, Germans or Poles. However, we already know some of the worst practices of the English institutions. Public opinion in the country since 2007 is extremely negative towards Bulgarians and Romanians. We must be very careful in the negotiations and extremely firm when it comes to the specific guarantees of respect for the agreed rights of our citizens.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, 450 years ago, in 1568, in Transylvania – currently part of Romania –freedom of conscience and religion were included in law on a global scale for the first time, and are today one of Europe’s fundamental values. In sharp contrast with the religious tolerance proclaimed at that time, Romanian Prime Minister Mihai Tudose last week threatened with hanging those Hungarians who have initiated Romanian—Hungarian dialogue on autonomy for minorities and who dared to fly the secular Hungarian flag. We welcome with satisfaction the news that the Romanian Head of Government handed in his resignation yesterday. We request, however, that all political leaders and parties of Romania, as well as the institutions and leaders of the European Union, publicly condemn this xenophobic and intimidating hate speech against minorities, which is almost unheard of in Europe and is reminiscent of Nazi and Communist times.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this Chamber and at the level of the European institutions, a commitment against all forms of racism can never fail.It happens in Italy that one of the presidential candidates in the elections of the Lombardy region speaks of "the risk of extinction of the white race" due to the arrival of too many migrants.I believe that the European institutions must condemn this type of political expression.Racism is not an acceptable political opinion and it would be important for the European Parliament to make it clear that racism cannot be part of the political battle in Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Tokes that he should apologize for the allegations made, because I informed Parliament yesterday, in a political statement, in Budapest, that the Romanian embassy has been desecrated, the coat of arms and insigniaof the Romanian unitary state were set aside and covered with other textiles that are not recognized as flags and that Szekler land, which Mr. Laszlo Tokes keeps talking about, was never independent, although it calls for the centenary year - Romania will celebrate inDecember 1 The Union, the Great Union and the creation of the independent Romanian state - separation.I want the institution and the Parliament to get involved and explain to the Hungarian state why an embassy is not guarded and why the embassy and the embassy insignia are desecrated.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: – Mr President, while the President is very nice to talk about races now. It is a very good occasion. Just one week ago, not 500 years ago, but a week ago, President Trump of the United States said that Africa, Haiti and other countries are shitholes.  (Heckling) Why are you reacting like that? I am saying that the President of the United States insulted the whole of Africa. He insulted all the people of colour. He insulted all Europeans. We believe in democracy and equality of races. The European Parliament must take a stance against Mr Trump. That is what I am saying.  (Applause)

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too think that the words that evoke the term "race" in politics and that the words "race" and "colors" that are evoked are harbingers of terrible memories which belong to the experience of'Europe and beyond.I believe they must be rejected, not only with a declaration from Parliament but with our daily action.Europe and Lombardy, civil Lombardy, civil Italy, civil Europe have all the antibodies to be able to say that we are beyond these divisions, that we believe in human rights and we believe in them every day, with every choice we make in this.Parliament.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, we have just heard five speeches which were not points of order. Why are you allowing them? We have all got political speeches we would like to make. These were not points of order.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: We now turn to voting time.(For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to request that these dossiers be referred back to the Committee on Fisheries under Rule 59 for interinstitutional negotiations, in accordance with Rules 59(a) and 69(f).

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, this is going to be a very long vote. I am looking around and I can see the problems that you have got: a lot of colleagues are not putting up their hands. Would it not be quicker to just do an electronic vote on this?

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Well, I have the feeling, and not to defend anything indefensible, that we are managing the times properly.But in any case, your opinion is highly respectable.- After the vote on Amendment 240:

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: – Mr President, it’s the same problem here. Why don’t we vote electronically from the beginning? Then we can work a bit faster. That is my suggestion.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: For my part there is no problem, but this is a decision that you have to make.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Mr. President, I would like to ask you exactly the same as what you have just been asked, but in Spanish.I think that we would save a lot of time if we went directly to vote everything electronically, given the situation of practically equality.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Well, nothing, if you agree, you will understand that they greatly facilitate the task of voting if we do it electronically, because we logically avoid having to weigh the votes of one and the other.- After the vote on Amendment 253:

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, I have a doubt in relation to amendment 252. The amendment belongs to the committee;It is not a group amendment and, therefore, in the event of a tie, I understood that it is approved and not rejected, but I don't know if I'm wrong.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: It is exactly the same, come the amendment of the commission or come from any group.When it comes to an amendment, if there is a tie, it would be rejected.If it were, however, the original text would be approved.That is the difference when there is a tie in these cases.- After the vote on Amendments 305 and 355:

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Mr. President, now that the vote by show of hands seems less shared than before, when electronic voting has been decreed, can we go back to the vote by show of hands for the non-nominative vote, to speed up the procedure?

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: As I intuit from the reaction of the honorable Members, I think it is preferable to continue as we are voting so far.- After the vote:

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker.- Mr. President, in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, I intervene to request from the Chamber that the report be returned to the committee in order to begin inter-institutional negotiations.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: With this we conclude the voting time.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! The report on international ocean governance raises a number of important issues, such as registered illegal fishing, the exploitation of natural resources on the seabed or the stressed risk of pollutant emissions in the fight to combat pollution of the seas and oceans. However, it is problematic to seek to strengthen the common fisheries policy, which may prove beneficial to countries where the sector is traditionally developed to the detriment of the weaker. Promoting renewable energy in the form of ocean tides and winds is controversial and may disrupt the ecosystem. Similarly, the postulates of decarbonisation are beneficial for highly developed countries, but very harmful for countries that need cheap energy. That is why I abstained, also because of promoting the new idea of ​​creating global values ​​and principles of sustainable development in reality against nature.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, economists are familiar with what they call spontaneous order, the way in which structures will form without supervision from above. It is a counterintuitive, difficult prospect. You would think that planning something would be much better than letting it evolve higgledy—piggledy, but it works. It is why the Cold War did not go the other way, and it is certainly true in the field of fisheries.  The European Union has an extremely top—down, controlled approach to fisheries. Stocks are treated as a common resource, and defined as such in the Treaty, to which all Member States have equal access. This is very different from the policies of Iceland or New Zealand or the Falkland Islands where skippers are incentivised to take ownership of quota and where effectively the system is privatised. We can see which one has led to flourishing fish stocks and which one has led to a collapse. Not for the first time we are labouring under the fallacy that the more we intervene, the more good we do, when in fact we have half a century of evidence to the contrary.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Work on the next financial perspective after 2020 is an excellent opportunity to review the existing macro-regional strategies. Experience so far shows that they are useful for most regions to solve common problems. To be effective, macro-regional strategies must be based on a long-term vision and the necessary administrative capacity. Obviously, the implementation of macro-regional strategies must be provided with financing, which cannot only come from the EU budget, but must be complemented by national and regional contributions. Therefore, countries and regions participating in these strategies should clearly define the human resource commitments and funding they will make available for their implementation. Undoubtedly, the simplification of procedures would also contribute to increasing the effectiveness of actions undertaken within macro-regional strategies. In order to make better use of the potential of macro-regions, many of the necessary changes indicated in the report, which I fully supported, still need to be made.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, I supported this report because I believe that macro and regional strategies are key to ensuring the prosperity of European citizens living in the Alps, the Baltic, Adriatic and Ionian Seas, as well as in the Danube region or in the mountain regions. in the Balkans. I consider it extremely important that the report emphasizes aspects of the European Union's strategy for the Danube region. As a European, born and raised in the Danube city of Silistra, I believe that the regions are not getting enough visibility despite the potential they have. River transport, cross-border infrastructure development and joint tourism products are just some examples of policies that can help both Vienna and Budapest, Vidin, Ruse and Silistra to develop better. No less important is the development of a strategy for the mountainous regions of the Balkans, such as the Rhodopes and the Balkan Mountains. I hope that the recommendations of this report will be seriously considered by the European Commission and that it will propose and support policies and initiatives for the implementation of the Danube Strategy and develop macro-regional strategies for the Rhodopes and other mountain ranges in the Balkans.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report by the rapporteur.In my opinion, it is balanced.With regard to the Baltic, Danube, Alpine and Adriatic-Ionian strategies, I believe that these strategies are a platform for transnational cooperation and should be encouraged in this regard.They are also a unique topic in regional policy within the EU, and synergies, coordination and cooperation between Member States and individual regions should be sought.It is important that the rapporteur has raised some doubts about the quality of implementation as well as about the capacity of staff and the capacity of administrative authorities to manage these implementations.We also need greater powers for local and regional authorities.I support further cooperation on this basis, but I would be very careful about further development, another special strategy.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the discussion on the implementation of the European Union's macro-regional strategies allows us to point out that Europe is still too timid in reporting the successes and benefits that come from being a Union. Citizens do not have the right perception of what the single market, the free movement of people, the structural funds, European investments mean. Promoting the mobility and interconnection of all European regions is now an essential priority in order to give cohesion to the Union project that, with great effort, we build every day. Furthermore, uniformity and simplification of the legislative framework are necessary to improve the certainty of procedures and to increase the mobility of member countries. Facilitating access to finance by simplifying procedures goes in this direction. I therefore voted in favor of this report because it indicates precise criteria for doing so and because I believe that our role as MEPs is essential for keeping these objectives among the priorities of national parliaments and our territories.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my colleague Mato's report was created with the aim of regulating the entire fishing sector, as regards both the collection of fishing resources and the definition of the gear to be used. In fact, however, we are voting for a real mess due to internal inconsistencies in the report but above all to the interference of the industrial fishing lobbies, not to mention the hasty management of today's vote and the Eurocratic ploy to pass incorrect amendments. It is clear that I am referring to the thorny issue of electric fishing, banned by the European Union twenty years ago, but still allowed today in some fish basins. It is a type of fishing that emits electrical impulses by means of nets, devastating marine ecosystems, and according to several scientific studies, ignored by the Commission and many colleagues, indiscriminately kills all fish and causes, at the same time, irreversible damage to the few that survive. Even China, repeatedly criticized here too, has banned it. The 5 Star Movement has said no to those who want to allow such practices to still be applied, regardless of mere national interests and the areas concerned. This is why we have tabled amendments and for once Parliament has not succumbed to the blackmail of the lobbies and has stopped electric fishing.

name: John FLACK
text: – Mr President, I am proud to have used my votes today to support both the UK east coast fishing fleet and to do more to curb the so-called cetacean by—catch. This means that dolphins, whales and sea birds being entangled in fishing gear, struggling fruitlessly to free themselves, suffering serious injuries and then a horrific death suffocating under water. I also voted against the expansion of so-called pulse fishing, which is basically electrocuting fish, but Parliament clothes it in the sugar-coated term ‘technical measures’. As well as being inhumane, pulse fishing also threatens the livelihoods of many fishermen, both in the UK and in France.  It is clearly a step too far in the industrialisation of the seas. It prioritises profits over conservation, and as a Conservative I will always err on the side of conservation. We talk a lot about European values in this place. To allow these barbaric practices to continue when we have it in our power to stop it, are not the values I subscribe to.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - Today we are voting on new rules for European fisheries. Anyone who thinks that you can regulate fishing in both the Mediterranean and our North Sea with the same European rules is mistaken. We need customization, our own rules, and these new rules will make it possible. In this way, the fishing industry will become more our Flemish fisheries and less the European one, and that is a good thing. At the same time, there has been a lot to do about this famous pulse trawl fishery. The French are radically against, the Dutch absolutely in favor. I also understand why: they have already transformed a large part of their fishing fleet with this new technique and we see the result. They have used a loophole in the regulations for this. The result is that they have been emptying our Flemish North Sea for several years. We have to be clear about that. This has to stop! As N-VA, we are also clear. We will always stand up for our Flemish fishermen. We will fully protect them so that they can continue to earn their living fairly.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament's vote banning electric fishing in Europe is a historic vote and I am proud of this European Parliament, which has risen to the level of the demands of our time to conceive of development in harmony with nature.I also mean that when we are determined on an objective by work of conviction, it is possible to win support, although we are in the minority in this European Parliament, and I am proud that this is my amendment, since jwas the first signatory, which made this progress possible.Finally, I want to underline the exemplary mobilization of NGOs and citizens which made it possible to obtain this result.Electric fishing will be banned from Europe and this is a big step forward.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, today we have started to change the rules for European fishing, but the question that arises is whether we have done enough with this vote today.Of course, I myself did not support this document, mainly because I lack objective criteria, both in the environmental, social and economic fields, on the one hand to ensure job losses in the fisheries sector and, of course, to protect marine fishing stocks that are seriously endangered.in many seas.On the one hand, I am happy that we have banned electric fishing or electric fishing, but I think we should be much stricter with so-called huts or trawls, which permanently damage not only the bottom, but of course also fish life, and I thinkthat they would still need more dialogue for a better text than was presented today.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I voted against this proposal today because of the absolute incoherence of European Union fishing policy, which has done so much damage, particularly to the United Kingdom’s fishing industry and communities, but also to those of France and other countries – all Member States of the European Union. In particular, what made me absolutely incensed was the fact that we voted on the electro-pulse fishing technique. This should have been banned outright. It should have been regulated with additional regulations. When a country that we are normally able to criticise so hugely, China, introduces a ban, and the European Union is not able to follow suit, it does bring into question what does the European Union mean by the term ‘sustainability’.  Time after time we know that areas are devastated once electro-pulse fishing goes through, and yet we are going to allow Dutch trawlermen to do that damage in the waters of the British Isles and in European continental waters. That is a shameful situation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr. President, when we talk about wanting sovereignty, we are referring to real and effective popular sovereignty when managing our fishery resources through criteria, of course, of sustainability, equity, social justice and transparency. In Spain we have lost around four thousand fishermen in the last five years, simply because Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy is not being complied with in my country. In this case we have it clear. Electric pulse fishing is highly damaging to marine ecosystems and an extremely violent method that kills not only marine fauna, it also kills our artisanal fishing: the one that really gives life to our fishing villages, which is respectful of the sea ​​and that is the livelihood of thousands of families in my country. The European Union cannot succumb to the pressure of the fishing lobbies, of the big fishing companies. You can't do it today and you can't do it tomorrow. These large companies neither do sustainable fishing nor do they take care of the sea. The only thing that matters to them is short-term economic profit. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to make decisions hand in hand with the people of the sea, thinking about taking care of this resource, which is a common good, and also thinking about taking care of those who live from it.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, today, by voting on the acceptance of the Commission's proposal, especially by accepting Amendment 174, we have helped Croatian fishermen in the Adriatic a lot. Finally, this amendment allowed for the deletion of a provision from the Mediterranean Regulation that restricted the use of swimming nets. For a long time after joining the European Union, Croatia tried to return the use of swimming nets to the state it was in before joining the European Union, and today, thanks to the report of our colleague Mato, we have succeeded. The arguments of fishermen and scientists are taken into account, which enables fishing, and at the same time protects the ecosystem. Therefore, it is important that we pass regulations that are adapted to the specifics of the regions, which has been done today for the Adriatic Sea. The European Commission has accepted the arguments of a scientific study that defines the maximum height of the swimmer's net and the ratio of altitude and depth of the sea, all due to the extremely variable configuration of the seabed, especially on the eastern Adriatic coast. I would therefore like to thank once again all those who participated in the adoption of this Regulation and who worked in particular in the Committee on Fisheries.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, I believe that the agreement that we have just reached in this Parliament to ban electric fishing is very important.I hope that the Commission and the Council will take note of this position of the European Parliament.Electric fishing is totally incompatible with the sustainability that the European institutions claim to seek with the CFP.But I had to abstain from this report because I believe that the preservation of traditional arts such as xexus in Galicia is not clear enough with the report we just voted on today.I hope that the European Commission will respond in the same way as it says in a letter that it addressed to me saying that the success will be safeguarded.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I supported this report.I am a great opponent of electric fishing.I believe that this system or method of hunting is plundering and damaging the oceans and seas, disrupting the ecosystem there, disturbing the structure of the bottom and killing even those that are not, in principle, hunting, and it is good that we, as Parliament, are clearly sending a signal,that we are not subject to lobbying interests, lobbying and we try to approach the environment in such a way as to protect it.So that is why I finally supported the report.In the event that some proposals that support electric fishing precisely pass, I would not be voting in favor of this report, because I think it is really very important to be environmentally friendly.It is one of Europe's values - to protect the environment, to preserve it for future generations.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, it has been described as the marine equivalent of fracking: sending electric shocks through the oceans to make fish living on the seabed leap up to be easily caught in a trawl net, but at what cost to the ecosystems of the North Sea?  There are fears that the repeated electric shocks may cause long-term damage to the sediments of the seabed and harm the nervous systems and backbones of fish. For 10 years, this technique has been allowed to continue under the guise of a scientific trial, with up to 80 boats operating in the North Sea. That’s not a scientific experiment, it is a commercial fishing operation. We deserve better for the waters of the East Anglian coast. I am proud to have voted today for a complete ban. I am proud that this House has too.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I finally supported this report.In my opinion, the final form of this report corresponds to a reasonable compromise.Proposals that cannot be described as anything other than lobbying were rejected.Indeed, the pressure on Members of Parliament has been relatively strong, but I am glad that Parliament has resisted this pressure to ban not only the use of electrical networks, but also those containing impulse discharges, which have been somewhat euphemistically described as technical measures.In this sense, I have promoted biodiversity, say, the good development of our oceans, seas and coastal areas so that life is preserved in them.It is important to reject other practices, such as industrial fishing, where zones remain completely dead after several trips by such boats.We should certainly return to this sometime.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr President, the seas have become a landfill. There is not a single ocean that is not filled with plastic. In 2015, 195 states pledged to sign a global agreement to reduce air pollution, but even today we have not done anything on a global scale about marine pollution. How is it possible? This takes 450 years to disappear from the water (she shows a plastic bottle) and the oceans are full. Containers, waste, organic pollution due to uncontrolled discharges of sewage and out-of-regulation outfalls, intensive aquaculture: these are some of the main problems on the Spanish coasts that affect fishing and also on European coasts and around the world. In particular, they affect artisanal fishing. A fisherman from Badalona told us some time ago that in the nets of his boat he only collected sanitary napkins, bottles, garbage. His father and his grandfather were fishermen. His children probably can't be anymore. We have to react, and the only way to do it, the only way to fight against this way of life and to generate garbage is to generate a way of life that precisely defends the people who take care of the sea and those who live from it, which is , again and again, the people who defend and fight for artisanal fishing.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, as highlighted in this Report, life in the oceans is highly endangered, especially since researchers discovered this year by longitudinal research that sea oxygen levels have fallen by 2% in the last 50 years. Although this percentage sounds like a small change, we must not forget that even a small change in the ecosystem can have a significant effect on living organisms in it. The only organisms that can live in such conditions where oxygen is constantly declining are bacteria, but the survival of all other organisms is significantly compromised. With this document, the European Union will continue its fight against climate change, but not only against climate change, but also against the behavior of today's inhabitants, whose bad habits significantly endanger life in the oceans. We hope to use innovative projects, blue technologies, the use of clean energy sources to promote environmentally sustainable infrastructure and protect ocean biodiversity. I therefore supported this proposal.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I was shocked if I could read at the end of last year in the scientific journal Science that the areas of dead zones in our oceans, seas and, above all, coastal areas have quadrupled and increased. Those dead zones are due to lack of oxygen. I think we need to be able to fight this, that we even have the means and the tools to do it. We need to work better with farmers, with local farmers, with local companies, which can just prevent these pollutants from entering coastal areas with simple measures. In his report, Mr Faria describes very well what biodiversity loss means. We have a problem with emissions from maritime transport, which can increase by 50%, but even by 250%, these are all challenges we face and we really have to face them. I am therefore pleased to support this report by my colleague, Mrs Faria, who is dealing with it, and I think it is an honor.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm vótáil ar son na tuarascála seo. The environmental health of the oceans is under significant threat and at risk of being irreversibly damaged unless the EU community undertakes targeted and coordinated efforts to solve the root problems. This report reaffirms the importance of international ocean governance and its economic, environmental and social components, particularly as it relates to Goal 14 of the Sustainable Development Goals: to conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources. In particular, I supported three priority areas, as set out in the joint communication, and any innovative technological, as well as financial, initiatives addressing ocean and sea pollution to promote efficient recovery systems for waste from shipping, for example, and marine litter in general, with the aim of eliminating it – and especially in relation to plastics, which can be described as the great environmental crime of our time. From an Irish point of view and from a European point of view, we owe it to ourselves and above all our coastal communities to deal with these difficulties.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - I voted against the report, which raises a number of real problems, such as the greater effects of climate change on poor societies, with calls for appropriate programs to be targeted at areas affected by natural disasters, with the provision of relief, calls to choose local food or condemn the use of sexual violence againstdisplaced migrant women.However, many provisions run counter to common sense in unjustifiably linking climate change to the migration crisis.And some provisions sanction unacceptable violence with the introduction of sanctions against groups or districts that do not respect the gender parity.Other provisions are also unacceptable, such as encouraging women to work compulsorily, providing services in the environment, such as afforestation or protection of natural resources.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, climate change does not affect everyone or everyone equally. A hurricane is not the same if you are rich than if you are poor; or a drought in Europe than in the global South; and of course, neither if you are a woman. According to United Nations data, 70% of the people living in poverty are women. Furthermore, they usually live in vulnerable areas, exposed to the impacts of increasingly unpredictable climate change. It is necessary and urgent, therefore, to include women as central agents in the fight against climate change. But not from a victim position, but from empowerment and equality. In the small and in the big. In Spain, for example, the Popular Party government has created a commission of experts with fourteen men solely for the design of the new climate change and energy transition law. I want to denounce here these intolerable situations that continue to perpetuate power relations that dynamite the possibility of moving towards climate justice. From here I also want to vindicate feminist environmental policies and more women in decision-making spaces, of course.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr President, I would like to go a little further than the report. Today, 70% of the world's poor people are women. The paradox is that it is also us, women, who can deprive decision-making of testosterone to save the planet, placing sisterhood at the center of politics, our way of conceiving life and solving problems. I am referring to feminism: the conquest that we really must achieve to achieve true democracy, real social justice and a planet with a future. To combat climate change, patches are not enough. We must change the heart of the production model, modify the sexual contract that discriminates against women and place the care economy as the central axis of life. We need to produce better to consume differently, take better care of ourselves to respect this planet that is our home. If climate change is the greatest threat we face today, the fight against it must be global and it must be feminist. Let's be very clear about this today, in January 2018, the year of the women's revolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, the fact is that climate change affects the most vulnerable groups in society, and those are those who rely on natural resources to provide livelihoods, but also those with less financial resources, and that is women.
