They are largely affected by climate change, as they are overrepresented in the world's poorest sections of the world, and are particularly vulnerable in developing countries because they do not have the same access to resources, education, employment opportunities and land as men, and are still responsible. for most care and household chores, and the production of food for the family. The concept of climate justice addressed in this Report aims not only to draw attention to these differences, but also to raise awareness of how climate change is not only a technical or economic problem, but also affects people’s lives. Considering that, according to the United Nations International Organization for Migration, 200 million people could be displaced by 2050 due to climate change and the fact that women and girls are among the most affected groups, I support this Report in the hope that it will help new and more efficient solutions are found for this problem.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: EU support for the Colombian peace process (2017/3021 (RSP))

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start this debate with a quote: ‘Building peace is like building a cathedral, brick by brick. We want to build it on solid and long-lasting foundations.’ These are the words of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, who just visited Colombia. He arrived in the country at a very delicate moment for peace and reconciliation, a moment when the enemies of peace are trying to roll back the progress that was so hard to achieve. Some groups have exploited the transition in former conflict areas to kill human rights defenders and campesinos leaders. Last week, the ELN restarted their attacks and kidnapped an oil worker. And yet, we should not lose sight of the bigger picture. Firstly, after half a century of war, FARC has disarmed and turned into a political party. Secondly, the Truth Commission has begun its work, and thirdly, the number of murders is still too high, but it is the lowest in 50 years. Colombia has an unprecedented opportunity for reconciliation, growth and human development. In a fragile but hopeful context, the friends of Colombia have a duty to engage even more closely, and this is what we, as the European Union, are doing. Part of our work is political and diplomatic. For instance, we first suspended and then removed the FARC from our list of terrorist organisations. It was an essential decision, showing to the ex-fighters that indeed a new beginning was possible if they laid down their weapons and chose, of course, democratic politics instead. Today, we are also following closely the suspension of talks between the Colombian Government and the ELN, and we are constantly in touch with the group of accompanying countries. The ELN’s decision to restart their attacks is unacceptable. We call on them to stop their attacks immediately, and we encourage the parties to resume talks on the extension of the ceasefire, which expired on 9 January. Peace can only come from a return to dialogue towards a permanent bilateral ceasefire. During these years and months, High Representative Federica Mogherini and Special Envoy for the peace process in Colombia, Mr Eamon Gilmore, have maintained close contacts with the Colombian Government and with FARC, as well as with opposition leaders, civil society and with our partners at the UN. In parallel to our diplomatic action, we are also engaged very practically in the reconciliation process on the ground. We have a particular responsibility to accompany the peace process in three areas: rural reform, the reincorporation of ex-FARC guerrillas into civilian life, and the establishment of a Special Investigation Unit in the Prosecutor-General’s office to combat crime and protect activists. At the same time, our EU Trust Fund for Colombia was established precisely to support these tasks. The Fund today has a budget of EUR 95 million, thanks also to the contributions of 19 Member States. Projects worth over 60% of the Fund have already been approved. Let me give you just one example of our support. The reincorporation of former fighters is one of the most delicate issues for reconciliation in Colombia. Some of them are moving into politics. Many others are going back to school and are looking for a job. Some others have a hard time in dealing with the memory of the war. In all these cases, our financial support can make a huge difference, so we have decided to start acting immediately, even before the National Reincorporation Plan is ready. In addition to the Trust Fund, we are supporting the urgent needs of the peace process through our Instrument Contributing to Stability and Peace, with an extra EUR 40 million so far. For instance, we are providing financial support to the transitional justice system because, as you know, reconciliation and justice must always go hand in hand. Furthermore, the Instrument Contributing to Stability and Peace could also be used to support the new Special Investigation Unit to fight organised crime and protect human rights defenders. Let me conclude on the work we are already doing to protect defenders. Since so many of them began have started to be murdered, we have not just made our voice heard. Eamon Gilmore visited many of the areas where the killings occurred. He met with their families, with local authorities, with police and the army. We also organised field visits for the Human Rights Group and the Group of Ambassadors with Defenders. Thanks to our programme ‘Protect Defenders’, several land activists and representatives of victims have received funding not only to cover attorneys’ fees and physical protection measures, but also, in the most serious cases, temporary relocation to other parts of the country. In parallel, we have continued providing humanitarian aid to people affected by violence, people who have been displaced, or to communities being confined and deprived of access to basic services, such as shelter, protection, safe water, clean water, food, healthcare, psychosocial support and education. Your support, dear colleagues, will be essential to carry on this work and all our work in support of peace, reconciliation and human rights in Colombia. We have decided to propose to Parliament an extension of the current bilateral cooperation with Colombia until 2020, and the addition of further resources. After half a century of war, it would be naïve to imagine that reconciliation could happen overnight. This last stretch of the road towards peace may be the hardest part. But it is just as important as the peace agreement itself. The people of Colombia – and peacemakers such as President Santos – need all our support from the European Union side. They can be sure that the European Union, together with the United Nations, will continue to be the strongest supporter of peace and human rights in Colombia, and a point of reference for all those who dream of a country finally reconciled.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. president; Commissioner, thank you very much for her words, which have replaced the absence, which we regret, of Mrs Mogherini with great ability. I will begin by saying, as a first point and with solemnity, that Colombia, with her behavior during this time, has deserved and is deserving the support that the European Union and the international community are giving it. The European Union must continue to support this process, which is undoubtedly one of the best designed in the world, analyzing its precedents. During this last year, it is responding to essential aspects to end armed violence and to more substantive aspects to overcome the causes of war. The demobilization and laying down of arms in Colombia were completed at a good pace. I believe that both the European Union and the Member States must continue to support the peace process in Colombia. Both from the political point of view and from the economic point of view, through financing with cooperation instruments and through the Trust Fund that surely, Commissioner, will be necessary to expand because new needs arise. The end of the conflict has led to an increase in the presence and action of the public force to guarantee the safety of the populations. A unique opportunity to structurally overcome the problem of illicit crops, which is also making farmers' dream of having their own land come true, among many other achievements. Finally, I want to remind you from here that the consolidation of peace has been the axis of the cooperation policy of the European Union with Colombia since 2002. For this reason, the Colombian Government and the National Liberation Army (ELN) must find through dialogue some kind of solution. From the European Parliament we ask that the talks on the extension of the peace agreement be speeded up to guarantee the agreements reached and the building of confidence in the last three months. The various attacks perpetrated by the ELN in different parts of Colombia are unacceptable from every point of view and are incompatible with an action for peace. Armed action is incompatible with dialogue. The desire for the suspension of military action to continue has been unanimous throughout Colombia. A sustained improvement in the humanitarian situation of communities affected by the conflict can only be achieved with a permanent ceasefire. This opportunity for peace cannot and must not be wasted, Commissioner. And I know that is the intention of the Commission. Lastly, and not least, it is necessary that, together with the support of the peace process, we be very respectful of the popular will. And this is compatible with the support that we naturally made in the referendum, perhaps even exceeding our own capabilities and neutrality. Unfortunately, on the occasion of the next elections, the different legitimate political options will confront each other on how to obtain and achieve peace. The European Union, Commissioner, must unequivocally respect that debate, because otherwise it would be interference that is not naturally up to Colombia to accept and that we must respect.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in Colombia is truly extraordinary. After more than fifty years of internal warfare, after thousands of deaths, after millions of victims, they have found the way to peace. And this has allowed the whole country to have learned that wonderful lesson that Gandhi gave us in his day saying "There is no way to peace, peace is the way." This is really the greatness of this agreement that is allowing Colombia to regain peace. And the equation, the agreement, substantially, arises on two bases. The first is the renunciation of violence. You have to stop killing, because there is no cause that justifies killing. None. But the second part of the agreement is to accept that those who renounce violence enter politics and can do politics legitimately. This is the basis of the agreement. And this is the greatness of what is happening in Colombia. But peace does not come alone. This does not fall from the sky. Building these processes is extraordinarily complex. There are lots of obstacles. And that is why we have established what I would call a political message that, unfortunately, this House will not be able to deliver today. Because the will of the Socialist Group was for this debate to be held and a Resolution approved, but we do not know why neither the European People's Party nor ALDE have wanted a Resolution so that, as two years ago, today we say how we support peace In colombia. And that is not interfering. Because we have the right to say that the electoral process does not interrupt the elections, does not interrupt the peace. And unfortunately, there is a certain political game in that direction. For this reason, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that a statement in favor of continuing the process, in favor of the Government accentuating its measures, that the agreements are implemented, a resolution by Parliament would have been adequate for the European Parliament and Europe remain agents main protagonists of this great agreement.Like we have Mr. Gilmore there, like we have the Trust Fund;but to continue saying that we want to implement the agreements, that we want the dialogue with the ELN to continue, demanding that the ELN stop killing and, at the same time, that the government continue negotiating.All of this is what we want to do with a pronouncement that it would have been good for this Parliament to have established.Because that is, in my opinion, the most important political position that we could adopt today: to demand an end to violence, definitively and forever in Colombia, from those who still maintain it, and that the agreements are implemented and that no one in the processelectoral interrupt this hope of peace forever in Colombia.(He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: "blue card" question.- I believe that politics sometimes lose us these little things and, if precisely in the debate on Colombia today there was some ingredient that was not needed, it was the questioning of the groups.Mr. Jáuregui knows that this parliamentary group has supported, without any doubt and in a strong and forceful way, the peace process in Colombia even in the first moments, in the initial ones.I don't know what steps you have taken, Mr. Jáuregui, with the institutions and those responsible for Colombia, but I can assure you that I personally asked if they thought it appropriate for this Parliament to approve a resolution in writing, and I can tell you that the answer was notit has been positive.Have the Colombian authorities told you that they needed and believed that a written resolution from this institution was urgent, after what we stated in November?

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: "blue card" response.- I do not question, Your Honor, that you support peace in Colombia, because you signed a Resolution with us.What I'm asking is why not do it today.And I have asked the European Commission - yes, sir - Mrs Mogherini and Mr Gilmore: is a parliamentary resolution of the European Parliament appropriate today, before the elections?The answer has been yes!And so I regret that it is not done.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: You know how it works. You asked a question, our colleague has answered, and that is it. We have to stop here even if we are not satisfied with the result; that is the rule.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, with just over a year gone by since the Colombian peace deal was finalised, I too would like to welcome the visit of the UN Secretary—General António Guterres to Colombia last week as a sure sign of the international community’s commitment to the deal. Implementation was never going to be easy, particularly given the splits in public opinion in Colombia, as was clearly indicated by the very close result in the referendum on the initial deal. With such domestic ambivalence it is therefore all the more important that the EU shows a unified and strong voice, as one of Colombia’s biggest economic partners with an FTA in place, and has a strong commitment to the peace process. The launch of the EU trust fund is a positive step, with some EUR 95 million already committed, but it is clear that more investment will be needed if change is to be seen quickly enough to maintain the public’s confidence in the peace process. Elections later this year will see at least ten members of the FARC handed seats in the Congress, as anticipated by the peace deal. By all accounts, the group has stuck to its commitments of peace, but the transformation from armed terrorist group to legitimate political party will be very tough to reconcile in the short term for many. Focusing on the main tenets of rural development and cocoa crop substitution will be key policy areas to see real progress happening on the ground. Resolving the issue of transitional justice, impunity for crimes committed during the armed conflict and restitution of property will also be very challenging to President Santos’s government. Finally, we cannot ignore that the National Liberation Army (ELN) is clearly benefiting from the deal. It is now moving back into areas previously controlled by the FARC, who have disarmed. Now, sadly, the ceasefire has expired and they have now resorted to unacceptable armed conflict in their attacks in recent weeks. I sincerely hope that we can all call for that to immediately cease.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the European Union must maintain political and economic support for the peace process in Colombia. The work of the special envoy of the high representative to the country is essential, promoting the Development Cooperation Instrument, and maintaining and increasing donors to the Trust Fund. The process is not easy, but it is moving forward and it should continue to be that way in this electoral year. According to the information we collect from the Colombian authorities and humanitarian and non-governmental organizations that work in the areas most affected by the conflict, we must continue to support the Guarantee Commission, because there are still too many victims among social leaders and human rights activists. But it should also be noted that 103 people have been arrested for crimes against these human rights defenders and more than 50% of those responsible have been identified. Is not sufficient. It is essential to continue negotiating with the ELN, which must declare a ceasefire, and this organization must be integrated into the process. It is equally urgent to continue supporting the land reversion process and the implementation of the comprehensive rural reform, which in 2007 has met its objectives. This support should ensure that land reversals, already in the final phase, and illegal crop substitution programs produce a much fairer situation in Colombian agriculture in 2018. Without that expectation, the more than one hundred thousand credit operations for new agricultural enterprises signed by small producers would not have been formalized. The implementation of this point of the peace agreement is key so that its beneficial effects reach the population most affected by five decades of violence. The current year is expected to be one of special justice for peace and the work of reparation and recognition of the victims. The European Union can contribute a lot in a historic year, also because the former guerrilla, the FARC, definitely embraces peace and the word in Parliament, after successfully demobilizing more than 13,000 combatants.Maintaining our commitment to this process is to honor the values that define us and contribute to a process that promotes not only peace and security, but also economic and social development and a better distribution of wealth and prosperity.Because social justice is a key element to stabilize and strengthen peace.Mr. President, there is always talk of the price of peace, but we all know that the price of any war cannot be paid.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, first of all, I would like to acknowledge and congratulate the efforts in Colombia to implement the peace process agreements, both in terms of legislative development, new forms of political participation, and the commitment of the FARC by abandoning definitely weapons, as the United Nations has certified. There are no half measures in this process. All our efforts must make the agreements prevail. The European Union must support again and again, and as often as necessary, the implementation of the peace agreements. Peace is signed one day but it is built during a process, and we have to be in that process at all times. And I think that unanimous pronouncement would be positive today. Positive and necessary. I would like to point out some elements that I think need to be addressed, like the transparency of the Trust Fund. The European Union Trust Fund must follow certain criteria and should serve to support point one of the agreements, comprehensive rural reform, promoting a fair policy of land tenure and a progressive substitution of crops. But above all, it must be transparent. We have to report. We have to tell what is being done with the money from the European Union. Secondly, I would like to talk about the extremely worrying process of reparamilitarization that is taking place in the territories previously occupied by the FARC. It should be a priority to make every effort to combat the proliferation of new paramilitary gangs, which are causing more and more murders of social leaders and peasants. If in 2016 28% of all human rights defenders killed in the world were Colombians, in the reports of the Office of the High Commissioner for Peace we observe that in 2017 they increased by 45%. Victims are at the heart of the agreements and must be respected and their rights guaranteed. Ladies and gentlemen, I hope we can be present in the next elections launching a unanimous message of support for the peace process in a way, as I said, unanimously and with indifference to the political color and political forces with which each one feels more represented.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr. President, I believe that peace in Colombia is a treasure that must be preserved. We have started down a path that was very difficult and it is a historical fact, one of the few good news from the international community in recent years. It is very difficult to find historical conflicts that have been resolved in recent years and we have the historical possibility that this conflict will be resolved in a peace that is being made with a very important collective effort of Colombian society, some of them to lay down their arms, others for accepting that those who fought with arms can enter into politics. All of this has been a huge collective effort and also an effort by the European Union, of which I have to say that it has played a very good role in this matter. But we cannot be conformist. Peace is not already made, and we also know that there are huge risks ahead: issues of the peace agreement that are not being resolved, special justice for peace, labor reform - which has been mentioned by many of your honorable Members -, the issue of the reappearance of armed groups —which worries us—, the defenselessness of human rights defenders, things that concern us. And, above all, an electoral process in which there are also some people and some candidates who intend to hinder a course that should not be changed in any way. Therefore, our support must be absolutely total, that of this Parliament and that of the European institutions. And I do have to say that I would have liked this Parliament to have made a text, just like the one we did last time, unanimously, in support of the peace process. And it was the best time to do it. At a time when there are doubts and difficulties, it was time to speak clearly, with a loud voice, as we did last time. I have to regret that some Group in this House is more concerned with seeing who wins the elections than by sending this unanimous message.In any case, we must move on and I want to urge the European Commission and the High Representative to move on with Mr. Gilmore's work, to move forward with the Trust Fund and not to leave this issue, which will be one of the great victoriesalso of European foreign policy if this operation goes well.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, more than a year has passed since the peace agreement promoted by President Santos, Nobel Peace Prize winner, and although some progress has been made, there are still many problems. Thousands of hectares of land continue to be used for coca production and hundreds of human rights activists have been murdered in areas previously controlled by the FARC. It is a slow demobilization that undermines popular confidence in the agreement and leaves a power vacuum immediately filled by other militias like the ELN, which is now trying to occupy the free spaces left by the FARC. Peace is a difficult road. It is certainly not enough to reach an agreement to solve all the problems, but only a true commitment between all parties and the help of external actors - including the EU, which has to do more - can produce results in the long term. . A few days ago, the ceasefire between the ELN and the government ceased, and the situation may collapse at any moment. Therefore, I ask the parties to show a renewed will to negotiate, and to the international community to renew its commitment, in order to guarantee the Colombian people what they have been fighting for for more than fifty years: peace.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the European Union, which continues to interfere in issues for which it has no legitimacy, should be less angelic. To repeat over and over again "we must get back to the negotiating table" only serves to please whoever says it, but certainly not to advance peace in Colombia, especially since some Mafia armed groups do not want to 'sit at this table. The guerrilla commanders who do not want to surrender their arms do not do it out of ideology, they do it for purely financial reasons in order to remain masters of their territory, to continue to plunder natural resources, to continue racketeering, kidnappings, assassinations and continue to accumulate drug revenues. Faced with guerrillas who are now only criminal, the countries of the Union would be better inspired to help the Colombian government militarily to eliminate a deadly enemy and to step up the fight against the cocaine trafficking which is fueling the civil war in Colombia. and is a serious public health problem for us. A year and a half after an agreement which was rejected by the Colombian people and which no longer rests on any popular legitimacy, certain areas should be promoted: increase the fight against narco-guerrillas; develop economic programs in regions abandoned by the guerrillas; distribute wealth more equitably to avoid nurturing one of the causes that allowed the development of insurrectionary movements instead of promoting free trade as the European Union does, which has the consequence of further aggravating the differences in levels of life between those who benefit from free trade and those who undergo it. Finally, the Colombian state must regain its full place in the territories left by the revolutionary forces. It is indeed incredible to note that the situation of the inhabitants is there often worse than when they were under the yoke of guerrillas, leading even Colombians to arm themselves to ensure their safety.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, parallels are often drawn between the Colombian peace process and that of my own constituency, Northern Ireland. In both instances, innocents were tortured and disappeared. It is estimated that more than 46 000 people have been forcibly disappeared during 50 years of armed conflict and terrorism in Colombia. For decades, the families of victims of the disappeared have been vocal in their ongoing struggle for acknowledgment and action, both in Northern Ireland and Colombia. Our own experience in Northern Ireland shows that people hurt most by such peace processes are often the victims who forever carry the legacy of murdered loved ones and the weight of injustice as terrorists walk free. It is my belief that a sustainable peace process is impossible without addressing these issues. Peace is a noble and worthy aim but I would ask this institution to tread carefully. Do not allow the allure of the ultimate goal to blind you to the legitimate concerns of victims nor discount the legacy of injustice they feel.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, support for peace, harmony and reconciliation is an honorable policy. The European Union has been practicing this policy in Colombia and also in other latitudes. It is worth recalling in this debate the dramatic appeal that President Barco made to the international community in 1989, after the assassination of senator and presidential candidate Galán. The European Union responded to that appeal with the most favorable treatment within our generalized system of preferences. This unilateral concession was followed by an ambitious bilateral agreement, the Multiparty Agreement, currently in force, and a visa waiver regime. The Commissioner recalled the importance of the inclusion of these organizations in the list of terrorist organizations of the European Union. And it was not by chance, it was after a meeting of a delegation of the European Parliament at the headquarters of Los Pozos, in the demilitarized zone created during the mandate of President Pastrana, that he asked the Council of Ministers of the European Union and this I accept it. Terrorism is a scourge that negatively affects our societies. It is a phenomenon that affects us all equally and to which we all have to respond equally. And, in the same way that we ask for the victims of terrorism in the European Union memory, dignity and justice, I believe that we must leave it to each society to settle the score with its past. On this basis, what corresponds to the European Union and the rest of the international community - I was referring to you, Commissioner, to the visit of the Secretary-General of the United Nations - is to continue making its contribution on the basis of the will of the Colombian people —and there will be legislative elections in March and presidential elections in May. The role of the European Union at this time is to continue to contribute generously - and I mean Mr. de Grandes' intervention - continue to support this process politically, continue to support it economically.I am honored, Mr. President, to be one of the representatives of this Parliament in the Trust Fund of the European Union for Colombia and I would like to end by simply saying that the European Union must continue to make its generous contribution - I insist - to the dividends of peace., of concord and reconciliation in this great country that is Colombia.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, I believe that peace is indeed an objective of the European Union, of its foreign policy. I do not believe at all that talking about peace and building peace and supporting peace in Colombia is going beyond our powers. But it is true that in order for there to be peace, the electoral situation must be overcome, which is what I believe may be failing at this time. The electoral process can stop the peace process, and that is what in no way should we accompany from here. We are not going to fool ourselves. The process is very complicated and has been reversed in some of the legislative processes that should accompany it. We know that, in addition, the differences between members of the FARC are growing. That drug traffickers are out of control over the territories they dominated and new ones that have been freed from military or guerrilla control. Peasant and social leaders are being assassinated; fifty of them, according to official sources. The Colombian Congress has not been able to fully comply with the calendar for the legislation derived from the agreements, among other things because the Colombian right, a part of the Colombian right, has not stopped putting the wheels in the wheels of the process. That we also have to talk about that. Only 50% of the agreements have been fulfilled. And many of those that remain pending are essential to conclude this process, which is a process that the European Union has supported, is supporting and must continue to support in the immediate future. But it is true that we need the unity of the Democrats, the unity of the Democrats in this House as well. And for that reason, with all due respect to the rest of the political groups that have not wanted a written Resolution to exist, I do believe that a text that in Colombia could be used precisely to demonstrate that Europeans would have been a powerful signal from the European Democrats. Democrats are in favor of that process. I believe that you should not confuse the electoral process and the electoral interests of a part of the European right with the Colombian right with the indispensable support of this Chamber for an exemplary process that will be decisive for the future of Latin America.

name: Renate WEBER
text: - Mr. President, Colombia is one of the most complex countries in the world. Fifty-two years of armed conflict have caused much suffering to the population and the country. Reaching a peace agreement was an extraordinary challenge and we still have to celebrate it, although we know very well that the priority of the peace process now is not to lose the humanitarian achievements made in the process in recent months and the achievements in reduction of violence. The challenge, and the next step, is to reach the most remote areas of the country and change the conditions that have led to the spread of violence. Although globally Colombia has the lowest homicide rate in 42 years - as the Secretary General of the United Nations said after his last visit to Colombia - it is absolutely necessary to accelerate the active presence of the State throughout the entire national territory. This period of transition towards peace is an opportunity to confront and resolve problems such as the cases of murders of human rights defenders. As a first step, the Colombian government made the decision to dispatch 60,000 soldiers and police to the most critical areas. It is not enough, but it is a first step. Other aspects are also very important: rural reform, including access to land, long-term development plans, investments ... And, in this sense, the cooperation of the European Union plays a central role due to its high impact and political value. Personally, I am very proud of the support that the European Union has offered to Colombia and its peace process, including through the Trust Fund, and I am convinced that it will continue its cooperation with Colombia in its political and practical dimension. As President Santos recently pointed out, peace is reached with will and concrete acts of peace, not only with words.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, I am addressing the Commission now, demanding that the Trust Fund should not be a channel for financing the factual powers in the service of interests, namely European agribusiness. We are concerned about the insufficiencies, delays and successive attempts to amend and tamper with the peace agreements, the unspecified way in which the Colombian government has made its commitments. We denounce its immobility in combating paramilitary groups, which have expanded their action spreading terror and death in numerous territories, with dozens of indigenous people and activists killed in recent months. In fact, only the FARC are scrupulously implementing the agreement, despite limitations and constant threats. We express here a word of solidarity and trust with those that, in Colombia, the set of progressive and democratic forces, the communists and revolutionary forces, the popular and indigenous movements, have assumed firmly and with total determination, sometimes paying with their own lives the unequivocal defense of the peace process in that country. A process that nothing, and nobody, should stop.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Mr. President, Colombia is experiencing a very critical situation, in part because the 2016 peace agreement is not implemented, which included, among other points, guarantees of security and political participation, the reincorporation of former combatants and the establishment of a comprehensive system of truth, justice, reparation and guarantees of non-repetition. In 2017, there have been more murders of human rights defenders and community leaders than in 2016. Urgent measures must be taken to dismantle the successor structures of paramilitarism, because the next presidential elections may make the situation worse. Human rights defenders told me here in Strasbourg that they feared it would happen like in Guatemala, where, after twenty-five years of making peace, the situation has not improved substantially. The International Peace Brigades ask the European Union to redouble our efforts to protect those threatened and to support the prosecution. That we act by condemning and visiting the communities. That we request information on the progress that the Colombian State has made or should make. Our support is vital.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, any sensible commentator will be relieved that the peace deal between FARC and the Colombian Government is holding up. This deal hopefully addresses the previous tragic security situation in rural Colombia, thus helping to allow for economic recovery in these areas. However, I once again find myself asking what additional meaningful support the EU has to offer. This deal was a great example of effective diplomacy within the Latin American continent. This of course doesn’t fit with the EU’s narrative, and your incessant need to involve yourself in any possible situation backed up by the European taxpayer. Mr President, if the European Union has real respect for Columbia, you will allow them to carry on implementing this agreement with the appropriate support of fellow Latin American countries and the United Nations.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Mister President! Colombia, like all of South America and especially the Mercosur states, is without a doubt a very important partner for the European Union. It is also important to contribute positively to this peace process as far as we can. But we should not gloss over things in the Colombia affair that simply cannot be glossed over. The question that arises is: Is this effort we put in really related to the result we see? I don't think so, because the European Union and its Member States, and with it the taxpayers, have so far put EUR 1.5 billion into this project, and what we are seeing is not exactly great. Measures and projects have been decided to enable cooperation. The Havana Peace Treaty was signed. The only problem is that large-scale measures have been decided, but there is a lack of implementation and, ultimately, the control of these measures. The acts of violence are increasing again - we have heard that - the acts of violence against simple farmers, the acts of violence against journalists, and the security situation in Colombia today is as worrying as we know it from the past. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. These developments cannot inspire us to see such undesirable developments in peace-building in a project supported by the EU. That cannot be our intention, which is why I say: agreements must be adhered to from all sides, and implementation must be monitored with vehemence.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues! Indeed, the implementation of the peace process on all sides is of the utmost importance and we should be helpful in this. We have to see that this can only be done with a great deal of reconciliation. I am extremely grateful to President Santos for having had the courage to undertake this peace process. That is a great achievement when you see the conditions and also the political context in his country. However, I also understand those who have had victims in their families - deaths caused by the FARC, for example. Anyone who does not take this into account and does not know how difficult it is, when there is personal concern, to set such a reconciliation process in motion, is easy to talk to. I believe that such bridges have to be built and that that means longer social dialogue in such a country as well. It also means that one should not pretend - where I had the impression at one or the other speech here - that the poor FARC people are the victims. They also did a lot of evil, killing and kidnapping people. That should not be forgotten in this context. But now that agreement is there and should be handled sensibly. That is why it is necessary that paramilitary forces also integrate themselves into this peace process and that new unrest does not arise, especially against farmers. I think the situation in this country, as in many other Latin American countries, has to do with the fact that there is a high level of social injustice. Only if social injustice and class differences are overcome in such countries can there be a lasting process of reconciliation. That is why this is an important prerequisite for us as the European Union to invest in Infrastructure, help and support with education in order to bring together the rural area with the poor people and the other parts of society in order to bring about a real measure of equal opportunities in the country. We also have to spend a lot of money, and that is also a question for the Americans. Only the repressive fight against drugs is not enough to combat drugs. We should also have an interest in Colombia being built up properly, social injustice being eliminated, because that is the most important prerequisite for the drug cultivation to end. And that is why, in my opinion, it is much cheaper for Americans and Europeans to invest a lot of money in support of Colombia and to overcome drug cultivation, instead of just repressively combating drug use and drug trafficking. So we should encourage ourselves to be much more generous towards such a country in terms of support.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, the peace process in Colombia proves that many times when there is the courage to talk, it is possible to go beyond what was apparently insurmountable. It proves that the most fearless are, in some circumstances, those who seek reconciliation and not confrontation. It also proves that intransigence can prolong conflicts beyond anything that is humanly tolerable. That is exactly what President Juan Manuel Santos understood, the same as in his inauguration as Minister of Defense in 2006, he had declared that he would be the minister of war to achieve peace. From minister of war, Juan Manuel Santos became president of peace and this vision, without which the conflict that lasted for more than half a century would still be maintained today, was duly recognized with the award of the Nobel Peace Prize in 2016. In one country where the historical pattern has been, unfortunately, that of violence, with a historical trajectory so marked by the civil war, the initiative of President Santos configured an absolutely extraordinary gesture. It is precisely for this reason that this peace process has been and will be subject to several complex risks and challenges. In this scenario, the support of the international community is absolutely vital and cannot be subject to any political calculations or electoral logics. And among the support that Colombians certainly value most and that they probably need the most is support from the European Union. That is why the political forces in this Parliament must always place the goal of peace above any ideological sympathies. The Colombian people have the right to a safe life, free from the constant threat of violence, they have the right to turn the page on war in order to release the country's energies and focus them on economic development and the promotion of common well-being. In 2016, this Parliament unanimously adopted a joint resolution in favor of the Colombian peace process with the support of the seven political groups. Unfortunately, this will not happen on the present occasion.But it is good not to forget the importance that this process has worldwide.And I will end by quoting the United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, who, last week, visiting that country, said that the peace process in Colombia has a symbolic importance for the whole world.It is projected far beyond Colombia itself.

name: Javier NART
text: - Mr. President, Colombia has had seventy years of violence. The violence in Colombia began in 1948, with the conflict between the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party. Later, he continued with Movement 19 and the murder of Carlos Toledo Plata. All the peace processes in Colombia have always meant victims and deaths. Because there are groups that do not want to reintegrate into civil life, among other reasons, because it is the reason for their own business. The Colombia peace agreement is an imperfect agreement, it is an agreement full of frustrations, but it is the only agreement, because it is a possible agreement. Among the frustrations, strategic frustrations, is, for example, that the FARC have kept absolutely secret what their treasure is, the treasure obtained by drug trafficking. As they have also kept something fundamental secret, which makes one doubt what their purposes are, such as what links, what channels they had to market their product, drug trafficking. And this remains outside and outside the peace process itself. But, I repeat, with all these frustrations, it is the only possible process, because peace is the process and the process is peace. Consequently, it is clear that victims are going to continue to occur. It is clear that we are going to have frustrations, but it is inevitably clear that we have to support the democratic Government of Colombia and all the people and groups that want to reintegrate into political life and civil life, and that the European Trust Fund is fundamental and that we therefore have to be proactive in Colombia. I would even say: our own contradictions, those of the European Parliament, are strictly secondary to what is strategic and fundamental, which is to support our brotherly Colombian people. That is the fundamental thing: the next elections and the hope of peace in Colombia, of true peace.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Mr. President, the FARC peace agreement with the Colombian Government opened a window of hope. It is a window that is still open, but is seriously threatened. The FARC complied, but the other party is not complying. There are political, economic, judicial or military sectors that have become rich, that have committed human rights violations, and that fear the end of impunity. It should be noted the negative role of the Attorney General's Office, the President of the Government, high-ranking military officials, right-wing parties or economic sectors that continue to do everything possible to prevent the development of the agreement. Political reform is still delayed. Peace constituencies have been sabotaged. The Special Justice for Peace has been emptied. The rural reform does not even reach 5%. The amnesty law has not been applied to more than five hundred prisoners. And paramilitarism is rampant. About one hundred and forty ex-guerrillas or social and political leaders have been assassinated. A clear and clear voice must come out of this House demanding full compliance with the agreements and a denunciation of those who sabotage peace.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the signing of the peace agreements, Colombia seems to have entered a transitional context characterized by violence, both by criminal organizations and by some paramilitary groups, now more visible or in the process of forming, which actually fill the power vacuum left by the FARC. In areas previously controlled by the FARC, paramilitary groups have entered or increased their activity, establishing military and social control that allows them to appropriate the proceeds of legal and illegal economic activities. These groups represent an enormous threat to the effectiveness of the peace process: from the very fact that some structures did not participate in the demobilization it follows that the paramilitary phenomenon and its military, economic and political structures, historically invasive in the Colombian fabric, are still present and strong. So what is the point of celebrating the dismantling of the FARC if a year later we find multiplied or strengthened other actors who have taken their place and taken advantage of their absence, such as the Gulf clan? Do we want to consider a solution to have eliminated the name FARC by letting the model of paramilitarism survive? The high rate of violence that persists, particularly in rural areas, to the detriment of social leaders and human rights defenders is also very worrying, with an increase in murders of 47%. In Colombia, a massive and resolute intervention by the government is urgently needed to develop a clear and integral strategy for the dismantling of paramilitarism, which attacks the multidimensional character of the phenomenon. This is why I believe it is desirable and necessary for the European Union to immediately strengthen the special unit of the Colombian Public Prosecutor's Office, created ad hoc for the eradication of the successor groups to paramilitarism, a unit which must provide results. concrete in the protection and protection of victims of conflict, human rights defenders and social leaders.Today the significant delay in the regulatory implementation of the agreement is still discouraging, which in one year only advanced by 18.3%.This slowness and disruption of the bureaucratic fabric of the de facto agreement risk making the agreement largely sterile and ineffective.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr. President, the origin of the process is Law 1448, it is the starting point. Once again I want to congratulate President Santos for his courage and for all the efforts that he is carrying out in the implementation of peace. I was a witness to the referendum and many preambles. Today we can say that Colombia is on the way to ending the longest internal armed conflict in the subcontinent. I also quote Guterres, but literally: «a peacebuilding process is not easy, there are imperfections, there are delays, but what was very clear to me is the total commitment of the Government and the FARC to peacebuilding ». The agreement is progressing, the implementation is being fast. Demobilization and disarmament are advancing: more than one weapon per combatant, 52,000 hectares of illicit cultivation eradicated and replaced, 180 of the 673 mined municipalities have been declared mine-free. There are regulatory advances in decisive matters, such as reintegration, guarantees of security, victims, justice and reparation, rural and social development. And this by following the route that the Government has defined. It has defined three pillars for the construction of a stable and lasting peace: more security, new opportunities and reconciliation and coexistence. I want to highlight "more security", because it is the essential pillar to prevent the emergence of other new armed groups. Important progress has also been the creation of the Horus plan, the 65 Locate base units, and the "blue tents." Unfortunately, today we must regret the violent actions of the ELN and I subscribe to the words of Mrs. Mogherini calling for the talks to resume quickly, in order to ensure progress in the area of ​​peace and confidence-building in Colombia. From the beginning I have supported this process and I am aware that there is a long way to go. For this, it is essential that the assistance that the European Union can provide through the Fund support fiduciary - estimated as is known at 95 million euros - increases.Stable and lasting peace will give Colombia what it so much deserves, the harmony it so badly needs and the internal and external confidence to position itself definitively as one of the most important countries in the economic and social sphere of the American subcontinent.

name: Soraya POST
text: - Mr President! Of course, the EU must continue to support the Colombian peace process. What do you think the EU should focus on in particular in its support? In conversations with Colombian activists, I have formulated the following three points: The Special Jurisdiction for Peace, JEP. In November, the Colombian Constitutional Court voted through a mechanism tasked with investigating the human rights violations committed during the conflict. JEP is a cornerstone of the peace agreement and it is important that the EU supports a process that strengthens the rule of law. The EU should continuously monitor the work of the mechanism. All political forces in Colombia do not welcome the JEP and we in the EU must therefore be clear that we are behind the investigation of crimes committed by all parties to the conflict. Truth Commission. According to the peace agreement, a truth commission will produce a report on what happened during this conflict. The Truth Commission aims to create an emotional restoration and is a fundamental step in moving forward as a society. The members of the Truth Commission have already been appointed, but we must be vigilant that there are interests that want to hide the truth about the abuses that have been committed, not least those that the army has committed. The EU must, of course, support the Truth Commission and continuously monitor its work. The EU must also show its clear support for women, indigenous peoples and LGBTQ organizations in their efforts to follow up on both the JEP and the Truth Commission. Abuses against these groups must be taken very seriously. Therefore, it is also fundamentally important that they should be able to actively participate in the follow-up of the peace agreement and participate in the peace negotiations between all parties involved.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - The peace agreement is now more than a year old. But we all know that it is not a win. We must dare to say that many Colombians do not actually see or feel peace. Take the necessary land reform now. During the conflict a lot of land was taken from the farmers. A law has been voted in favor of it being returned, but unfortunately that law only survives on paper. And I think, Commissioner - and you know this, I see you nod - that this is a crucial point in the peace agreement. If you as a farmer have no land, you cannot work, you have no income and you end up in poverty. Then you will of course revolt again. For me, this is therefore at the heart of this peace process. Returning the land to farmers must be Europe's priority. A second point - as you have also mentioned - is, of course, the ceasefire. As long as there is violence, people naturally do not feel peace. We must also focus on that. A third point that I think has been little discussed here today is the following. This year is an election year. By just looking at different countries you know that in an election year there is always the threat of more violence, of bloodshed. We as Europe must make our voices heard on this. Continue to focus on the peace process, but try to keep the calm in this election year and ensure that the democratic content is respected. Good luck, you have our support. Let's help the Colombians.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Yes, I agree that the European Union has a special responsibility to support the peace process, which is so important and significant for the people in Colombia and also for many other states in the Andean region and in Latin America. It is far from secure, but just as fragile. This also includes shared responsibility for the decisive and irreversible implementation of the roadmap for the human rights, social and environmental obligations of the Colombian government within the framework of the EU-Peru-Colombia free trade agreement, which has now been in existence for five years. Because the social, political and economic reality is very concrete for every person in Colombia. Let me put it this way: EU trade policy must not jeopardize the peace process. However, the trade balance has turned to the disadvantage of Colombia. Agricultural goods from Europe and the USA forced thousands of smallholders to give up their businesses again, and rural exodus is bringing new social explosions to cities. The question of land is undoubtedly - and this has already been underlined here - a crucial one. What happens to land and raw materials in the areas previously controlled by the FARC? Will smallholders lose their land again? Are international investors getting on board? The existing trade agreement gives us little opportunity to react to the new situations - but we have to react!

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – (Initial words inaudible) partners in Latin America, our relations are based on political dialogue, trade cooperation, joint efforts to achieve sustainable development and peace-building, which the EU has supported since the very beginning. When, in 2016, one of the most ambitious peace agreements in recent history between the Colombian authorities and the FARC was signed, the EU reconfirmed its support to peace-building through a financial support package and a trust fund for Columbia, with a special focus on economic development and agricultural productivity. Nevertheless, recent events show that the peace process in Colombia remains challenged and the EU support is of crucial importance. The ceasefire agreement between the Colombian Government and the ELN expired on 9 January without any extension, and the rebels launched a new offensive last week killing members of the security forces, and attacking an important crude oil pipeline. Therefore I call on all involved parties to resume the talks on the extension of the ceasefire as soon as possible in order to secure the progress made in peace and confidence-building over the past months. The various attacks by the ELN in different parts of Colombia are unacceptable. What is needed is a serious and constructive dialogue and the commitment of both parties, the Government and the ELN, to reach a solution of the conflict through political means. Recently we can see that the desire for the continued suspension of military action has been unanimous throughout Colombia. The communities have a strong belief in a prosperous future for their country and want to achieve not only peace but also prosperity and good living conditions for all inhabitants. I hope that the Colombian Government will play a key role in providing the necessary security, administration, healthcare system and infrastructure they need and in helping the local farmers to get better access to the market, and the families of the victims should be high on the political agenda. We should also not forget about the thousands of former rebel combatants whose reintegration into Colombian society is a huge and important task for the Colombian authorities. A sustained improvement in the humanitarian situation of the communities affected by the conflict can only be realised with a permanent ceasefire. So the EU shall support further the peace process in Colombia.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, now that we begin this year 2018, this Plenary of the European Parliament wants to send a very clear message to Colombia. Especially this year, because it is an electoral year in the country, a year in which we know that the peace process is going to be stressed, it is going to be questioned by some, and it is even going to be threatened. At this moment, we, as Parliament, want to send two messages. A message of recognition, of recognition to the political actors, the Government, the victims and their generosity, to civil society, who are building peace from their efforts and from their generosity, day after day, in Colombia. And a message of support, of explicit support, as we have already done in the past, so that we can continue to walk, because there is much to be done in this peace process in the country. And it is time to also point out the steps forward and some chiaroscuro. The delivery of weapons by the FARC is very positive, it is positive to see how the appropriate steps are being taken so that this world is incorporated into politics, but there is still much to do. Much remains to be done to protect and guarantee, by the State, the safety of all local leaders and human rights defenders throughout the territory, especially in the interior of the country. That is necessary and more implementation is needed. And at the same time, we must ensure that steps forward are taken in comprehensive rural reform, which is the root of much of the conflict in Colombia, and finish completing the Havana accords with agreements with the ELN. The European Parliament sends a clear message of political, financial, diplomatic and operational support for an important peace process for Colombia, for the Colombian people, but also for the region, Latin America, and for the international community as a whole.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: - Mr. President, from EH Bildu we salute the steps that have been taken in Colombia to advance towards full peace with social justice from the territories. We welcome the efforts being made for its consolidation by the United Nations and we also request the special envoy of the European Union to redouble its efforts. And I say this because we are concerned about the limited progress in the area of ​​economic reintegration of former FARC combatants and the fact that there are still half a thousand of them in prison. We are also extremely concerned about the ongoing harassment suffered by social and human rights activists. It is urgent to promote humanitarian relief in this regard. The agreements are to be fulfilled. Lastly, we are extremely concerned that the ceasefire between the ELN and the Government of Colombia has ended and hostilities have resumed. We urgently call on both parties to stop their offensive action and to resume the round of talks, giving priority to the adoption of a new bilateral ceasefire that will serve as the basis for advancing the peace process.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr. President, Colombia has established itself in recent years as a key partner of the European Union in a region like Latin America, very close to us Europeans and, of course, to the Spanish, as is my case. The strength of the relationship with the European Union is due to the strengthening, over the last few years, of political and cooperation ties, and also of commercial ties through the free trade agreement. And I also want to highlight the importance of the abolition of the short-stay visa, which received so much support from this Parliament and, of course, from my political group. I also welcome the fact that the European Union has known how to be close to Colombia, accompanying and supporting the efforts of the Colombian people for peace. The appointment at the time of a special envoy or the creation of the Trust Fund for the post-conflict, promoted by the Member States, including Spain, are good proof of this. The conclusion of the negotiation with the FARC was a historic event that ended more than half a century of conflict and laid the foundations for a more prosperous Colombia as well, since a country at peace can unleash its full potential and this results in the well-being of its citizens, and also at the international level and in its international projection. We, from here, must continue to support the efforts that are being carried out to consolidate peace. As has already been pointed out on numerous occasions, it is essential that Colombians, that Colombian citizens perceive the benefits of peace as soon as possible, particularly in the areas most affected by the conflict. Last weekend - it has been repeated here ad nauseam - the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Guterres, visited Colombia. He pointed out, among other things, that the construction of peace is a central objective of the Colombian people. Well, the European Union must continue to accompany the process, as it has gone doing, together with the United Nations, for example in the framework of the verification and implementation of the agreement with the FARC.Now the main obstacle to definitive peace is found in the so-called ELN.The known attacks, carried out by the "elenos" a few hours after the end of the ceasefire, are totally unacceptable.It is imperative that these terrorist acts stop soon.It is necessary to have a ceasefire as soon as possible and the resumption of the work of the negotiation table in Quito, so that a definitive agreement can be facilitated soon.Mr. President, the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Santos in 2016 was a gesture of recognition from the international community to Colombia, which has suffered so much from violence for so many decades.It was a source of pride for them, for Colombia, but also for all of us who are friends of the country.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Colombia deserves our full attention.The conflict between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia lasted for 52 years and resulted in numerous casualties among the population.The Union welcomed the peace agreement between the two parties, reached in October 2016, as an opportunity to strengthen institutions in the country and improve human rights and sustainable development.Despite the generous humanitarian aid, however, many points remain unresolved, such as the social inequalities of marginalized communities and the scarce economic opportunities that induce many young people to enter the illegal drug and arms trade.It is therefore important that the European institutions continue to listen to the voices of those who denounce the violations and corruption present in Colombia and undertake to pursue collaborative policies in the political and economic sector.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - In 2016, we welcomed with enthusiasm and relief the historic peace agreement and the new era of peace and coexistence in Colombia. We also welcomed the start of the implementation of the agreement. A lot of work has been done, but it is not yet complete. I would like to emphasize that this is not just a project of one of the Colombian governments or one of the coalitions, it is about the responsibility and future of the whole of Colombia, and every government coalition should be committed to this project. Therefore, no political change in the structure of Colombian policy should overshadow or jeopardize the full implementation of the peace agreement. It must be carried to the end in the spirit as it was conceived, and not shaken by faith in its credibility. Above all, Colombia must not afford steps that would lead to the old state of violence and fear that has been overcome by the peace agreement. Of course, there were problems with the implementation. They need to be tackled wisely and with sensitivity, but not with the intention of breaking down the agreement. Only partial implementation would not lead to the ultimate goal. I support any assistance that the European Union can contribute to implementation. Today, however, I am glad that we are so united in our view of the continuation of the peace and reconciliation process in friendly Colombia.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Colombia's peace agreement was complex and had a strong commitment by the European Union. As compliance with this agreement faces more and more risks, it is not just the future of Colombia and its people that are at stake. The credibility of European soft power is also played, which so many positive contributions have made to the promotion of peace and human rights in the world, bothering those who prefer the maintenance and contexts of conflict and chaos to better fulfill their distraction agendas. and imposing the power of the strongest. That is why the political calculus shown by some groups in this chamber is regrettable. Colombians are free to choose the president they want, but that does not exempt us from continuing to support them in the fight for peace. In this context, the European Union, knowing the situation on the ground and the limits to its ability to intervene, has an essential role in leading an internal and external coalition to safeguard what has been acquired. This debate reiterates a key mandate for the Commission to continue its effort for peace in Colombia and for peace in the world.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - (the speaker was far from the microphone) ... a tremendous challenge in Colombia, a country that remains plagued by violence perpetrated by armed groups, including dissidents from the FARC, ELN and paramilitaries who thrived in the shadow of drug trafficking. 2018 brings presidential and legislative elections that cannot be used as an excuse to interrupt the peace process. The common alternative revolutionary force, which results from the transformation of the FARC, must learn to function as a political party and have space for it. At the same time, it cannot be accepted that other armed groups, including paramilitaries, take over areas previously controlled by the FARC, murdering, oppressing and expelling populations. The European Union must speak and act by helping the Colombian government to continue the dialogue, including with the ELN, but also to fight corruption and organized crime, because, as the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, stressed last week spent on a visit to the country, it is not enough for the State to deploy security forces in the areas affected by the violence. The essence of the state's presence has to translate into education, health, infrastructure and access of agricultural producers to markets, providing living conditions for the Colombian population, for communities, which in the last year have only seen more than 170 activists and union leaders killed . Not killing peace means giving the Colombian people living conditions.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Mr President, the time has come for the European Parliament to renew its commitment to Colombia and its citizens and to reiterate its support for the peace process. The expiration of the ceasefire agreement between the Colombian Government and the ELN should not jeopardise all that has been achieved through diplomatic efforts, dialogue and confidence-building measures. It is vital for an agreement on the extension of the ceasefire to be concluded swiftly and for the ELN to show commitment to peace and restraint.  But this is also a crucial election year for Colombia. After five decades of armed conflict and more than 220 000 deaths, elections in the country must be an opportunity to advance the peace process to the benefit of all Colombians, and to defeat those forces willing to sacrifice Colombia and have it regress to 2012 purely for political gain. The needs and aspirations of the people of Colombia can only be fulfilled by the Peace Agreement, which is the only viable path to a secure, stable and prosperous Colombia.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, the peace agreement with the FARC was also a victory for European diplomacy and external action. We have invested great resources, political attention and effort in supporting Colombia’s path to peace, to help create a political and social context in which the implementation of the 2016 agreement was possible. But the situation today after the latest ELN terrorist attack and the collapse of the ceasefire is becoming fragile. The EU was right to despatch Eamon Gilmore as a Special Envoy. He played a key role in the peace deal and this should continue. The EU should actively support the implementation of the 2016 accords in full. In this respect, the Trust Fund for Colombia is a useful tool. It should be expanded and all Member States should contribute. It requires long-term investment in reconciliation, inclusive democratic institutions, and economic development.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, UN Secretary General Guterres' visit to Colombia ended yesterday. Unfortunately, we must recognize that the achievement of peace and reconciliation is still a long way off and, indeed, the escalation of violence should worry us. Despite the progress made with the agreement signed between the government and the FARC and the subsequent disarmament, this agreement is not yet implemented in all its parts and in other areas of the country, paramilitary groups continue to threaten the population of peace communities, such as it occurred in the attack on December 29 on the community of San José de Apartadó and as reported by the chilling direct testimonies, among others, of the Italian Peace Corps "Operation Colomba". Unfortunately there have been many other cases like this, which are not mentioned, like the situation in Samaniego. In 2017 alone, there were more than 105 victims among human rights defenders. The EU must continue to support the peace process and ask the Colombian government to condemn the paramilitary attacks and launch investigations to ascertain responsibility for the attack on the peace community and ensure the full protection of all rights defenders humans.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think this discussion helps us to focus on a lot of the good work that the European Union does, for which it gets no credit, and definitely not from its critics. It has contributed enormously to the peace process in my own country, Northern Ireland, which has been going on for many years and it will continue, as indicated in the first phase of the withdrawal agreement on Brexit. Iran is another example of the great diplomatic efforts and influence of the High Representative and the European Union. Here we have a very important role to play in Colombia because we are not a threat to anybody. I think it is great to see us using our initiative and our goodwill to help people move along with the peace process. In Columbia, I remember well, a constituent of mine, Michael Dwyer, was killed there, and there were a lot of questions to be answered about that a few years ago. So it is great to see peace coming to these places, and hopefully also prosperity and safety.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I want to give my full support for the Colombian peace process, particularly in light of current difficulties. I’m very worried by the situation whereby rural communities abandoned by the FARC are being taken over by criminal drug traffickers rather than being supported by legitimate actors. It is undeniable that positive progress has been made, particularly regarding the disarmament of FARC. However, I urge the Colombian Government to redouble its efforts to bring support to the most vulnerable communities in order to ensure that Colombian citizens see the benefits of peace in their everyday lives. I’d also like to show my support for civil society organisations working on the ground, such as libraries for peace. This organisation provides remote demobilisation zones in Colombia with a central place where people can access critical resources and fight trauma together. People-to-people initiatives such as this are vital for genuine peace processes and they also fulfil the aims of the EU’s cultural diplomacy strategy announced by the High Representative herself in 2016.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, fortunately after five decades of continuous war, the situation in Colombia seems to be normalizing, albeit at a slower pace than we would like. The FARC, the largest armed group in the country until last year, in cooperation with the government has already given very positive examples and, despite the various problems that have arisen, shows that it remains committed to the peace process. On the contrary, the ELN, after the end of the ceasefire, the first after fifty years, continued the attacks. A development that does not make any of us happy. We must call on both the government and the guerrillas to return to the talks, as both sides have expressed this will. Of course, the attacks must stop immediately before any resumption of negotiations. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the armed groups have taken advantage of the gap left by the disarmament of the FARC and have rushed to occupy the areas it controlled, creating new problems in a country trying to recover and end a war. which cost almost 300,000 dead.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (beginning of the speech with the microphone off) ... century of civil war with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, the conclusion of the conflict seemed to be near, thanks also to a historic agreement for which President Juan Manuel Santos won the Nobel Peace Prize. Unfortunately, the negotiations to achieve the effective pacification of the country were abruptly interrupted due to new attacks carried out by the guerrillas. There is great concern on the part of the international community: the armed conflict, which the 2016 peace accords ended, claimed some 220,000 victims between 1958 and 2012, 81% of which are civilians. Unfortunately, the path that Colombia must take to achieve peace is still very long and the European Union must make every effort to avoid the interruption of the peace process and put an end, definitively, to an internal conflict that has cost thousands of victims and 6 million internally displaced persons.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, a bomb attack on an oil pipeline from Colombia to Ecuador, attributed to National Liberation Army (ELN) guerrillas, is jeopardizing the peace process in the country. President Santos is determined not to extend the ceasefire agreement. If this happens it will mean a setback. It is a fact that Colombia has seen significant growth over the last 25 years. From the World Center for Corruption, Drug Trafficking, Human Rights Violations, and Murder for Political and Non-Political Purposes, it has evolved technologically. But as contradictory as this may seem, Colombia's problem is that it is rich in oil. This makes her vulnerable to the interests of the international oil giants who will not allow her to easily disengage from them. They want to manipulate and control it. Something similar happens with Greece, whose economy was destroyed when it was ascertained and certified that it has rich energy reserves.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this debate has been a very useful exchange. I thank the Members for their valuable interventions, and from this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic power and instruments to support the Colombian peace process. We will continue to look at how best to use all of our instruments in this direction, in particular in stabilisation and development assistance, political dialogue, humanitarian relief and specific support for human rights, gender and democracy. And promoting post-conflict economic growth through the EU-Colombia trade agreement.
