I am proud of our contribution to the peace process in Colombia, the EU contribution to this very demanding and difficult peace processes. That is why I would like to clarify two specific issues. Some of you raised the issue of rural reform. Yes, the EU is supporting such programmes with an amount of almost EUR 120 million for this specific reform. My second point is about our funding through the trust fund. It is completely in accordance with our rules, and fits into in the framework of accountability and transparency. May I close by signalling once again, as the Commission, our appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping these important issues not only on the European agenda, but also on the international agenda?

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - After fifty years of civil war, Colombia has found the way to peace. The 2016 Accords have two pillars: the renunciation of violence and the recognition that those who renounce it can legitimately engage in politics. The implementation of the Accords is complex and requires an enormous effort and the will of the Colombian people, their Government and the FARC. For this effort to bear fruit, they need the active support of the international community. Such international support should have today taken the form of a unanimous resolution of this House, aimed at underlining that the peace process cannot be interrupted, whatever the outcome of the 2018 elections. Unfortunately, that message has not been delivered because PPE , ECR and ALDE have opposed a debate with resolution, considering that a written text would be an undue interference in the Colombian elections. But demanding an end to violence from those who maintain it and the continuity of peace is not interference, it is a right and a duty of the EU.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - After fifty years of civil war, Colombia has found the way to peace. The 2016 Accords have two pillars: the renunciation of violence and the recognition that those who renounce it can legitimately engage in politics. The implementation of the Accords is complex and requires an enormous effort and the will of the Colombian people, their Government and the FARC. For this effort to bear fruit, they need the active support of the international community. Such international support should have today taken the form of a unanimous resolution of this House, aimed at underlining that the peace process cannot be interrupted, whatever the outcome of the 2018 elections. Unfortunately, that message has not been delivered because PPE , ECR and ALDE have opposed a debate with resolution, considering that a written text would be an undue interference in the Colombian elections. But demanding an end to violence from those who maintain it and the continuity of peace is not interference, it is a right and a duty of the EU.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – The tragic and saddening situation in Colombia is not what we had hoped for. Although the first phases of the peace agreement have been implemented and subsequently, combatants have been disarmed and demobilised, there are still many challenges which the country is facing. Violent incidents have risen, due to drug-trafficking groups taking over FARC areas in places where there is no state presence. The temporarily agreed ceasefire is soon coming to an end and we hope that an agreement will be reached on a permanent ceasefire, as it has been proven that violence is not the way forward. The violent events which have happened in recent days are very worrying as they are undermining the political peace process in every way. That is why an honest effort needs to be made on behalf of all parties involved to resume talks.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - After fifty years of civil war, Colombia has found the way to peace. The 2016 agreements have two pillars: the renunciation of violence and the recognition that those who renounce it can legitimately engage in politics. But demanding an end to violence and the continuity of peace is not interference, it is a right and a duty of the EU.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iran (2018/2510(RSP)).

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, today we are here primarily to discuss the internal situation in Iran after the recent demonstrations and violations of human rights, but let me first say a few words on a different matter, which is our work to preserve the nuclear deal with Iran. Two years ago precisely, on 16 January 2016, the International Atomic Energy Agency verified that Iran had implemented its nuclear—related commitments. As a consequence, the United Nations, the European Union and the United States lifted their nuclear-related economic and financial sanctions. This was an important milestone to guarantee that Iran’s nuclear programme can only have a peaceful nature. The European Union has a clear and consolidated position on the joint comprehensive plan of action, which was reiterated by all 28 Foreign Ministers on 16 October last year. We are – and stay – committed to the continued full and effective implementation of all parts of the JCPOA. Over the past two years, the IAEA has confirmed in nine reports that Iran is implementing all its nuclear—related commitments under a comprehensive and strict monitoring system. Members will have seen that last Friday the United States extended the sanction waivers, and we are now, together with the E3 and the other EU Member States, carefully assessing the statement and its implications. Just a few days ago, High Representative Mogherini chaired a meeting in Brussels with the Iran Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif and with the Foreign Ministers of the E3, the three European countries that participated in the negotiations of the deal. They all agreed that the deal is working and must be preserved as it is crucial for the security of Europe, the Middle East and the world. Last week’s meeting was also an opportunity to discuss other issues which we are concerned about but are not related to the nuclear deal. These issues include detentions in the Middle East, Iran’s ballistic missile programme as well as the protests that took place in Iran in recent weeks. Let us be clear, all these issues must be addressed and must be addressed outside the scope of the nuclear deal. None of them would be easier to address if the JCPOA was not in place – quite the contrary.  So turning to the main topic of this debate. Since the end of 2017 we have focused our attention on the demonstrations in Iran. The High Representative intervened clearly with a declaration on 2 January after consulting all 28 Member States and speaking on their behalf. The declaration spelled out that the loss of human lives in Iran was unacceptable and that freedom of expression had to be guaranteed. We also raised these concerns directly with the Iranian authorities, including at the ITER level. According to our information more than 20 people including security personnel died during the events and there are reports of deaths in prisons. Iran should investigate all human rights violations and hold the perpetrators responsible. The rights of those arrested in the context of the protests should also be respected in accordance with international standards. It is positive that President Rouhani stressed that there must be room for peaceful expression of criticism, both in the streets and online. It is key that these declarations be followed by consistent decisions and action. Most observers believe that the economic situation has been the main driver behind the protests, and the economic engagement between the European Union, its Member States and Iran, that was consequent to the entry into force and continued full implementation of the nuclear agreement is also aimed at improving the economic situation of all Iranian citizens. But we shouldn’t forget that the restrictions on civil and social freedoms in Iran have also been one of the top concerns of the Iranian people and of course for us. We, the European Union, have never refrained from raising human rights issues in our contacts with the Iranian authorities. For instance human rights were the first item on the agenda at the last high-level dialogue last November and we will continue to discuss these issues in the framework of our bilateral relations. Our engagement with Iran, as I mentioned, has also focused on improving the economic situation of Iranian citizens following the lifting of all nuclear-related sanctions. We have encouraged trade and economic engagement with the constant goal of benefiting the people of Iran. For that reason we have established technical cooperation with Iran and stand ready to help with the necessary reforms. There is no shortage of experience within our Member States which can be shared. The lifting of sanctions was an essential starting point for the improvement of the Iranian economy, but it is not sufficient; some challenges are also structural and need reforms. These include addressing barriers to investment and weaknesses in the areas of transparency, the rule of law and banking, but also a stronger fight against money laundering in line with the standards of the Financial Action Task Force. This would lead to a more balanced distribution of wealth within Iranian society, which was one of the basic demands coming from the streets in recent weeks.  The people of Iran aspire to a more open, free and fair country and we Europeans have always been on their side. We have not only called constantly for the respect of human rights in public statements and in private conversations, but we have also chosen to engage with Iran to accompany and encourage reforms in that country. (Applause)

name: David McALLISTER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I start with a quote: “People have a legitimate right to ask us to see and hear them and to follow up on their demands.” This sentence comes from Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, and like most of the people in this room I could Sign the statement. Nevertheless, despite these statements, developments in the country remain worrying. Violence against people demonstrating peacefully, as Commissioner Hahn has just described, with dead, injured and thousands of detained regime critics, is the sad result of the last few weeks. The people of Iran, from all walks of life, are dissatisfied with the corruption, with the nepotism, with the restrictions on their freedom rights and also with the fact that their taxpayers' money amounting to billions of euros annually for highly problematic activities in Syria, Iraq , Yemen or Hezbollah in Lebanon. It is now in the hands of the politically and religiously responsible in Tehran to improve the situation of their dissatisfied citizens in their own country through political change. Commissioner Hahn has already correctly pointed out the foreign policy difficulties; I don't want to make any further additions to this. But what I would like to add is the very clear wish that we as the European Parliament make it clear that, firstly, those responsible in Tehran should respect the rights of the demonstrators and respect the freedom of expression and assembly. Second: We support the appeals to the Iranian leadership not to put down the protests by force, and call on those responsible to turn words into deeds. This includes the right to peaceful demonstrations and the release of those politically imprisoned. These points should and these points will be addressed by the Foreign Affairs Committee a delegation trip from February 12 to 16, including to Iran.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The images from the Iranian cities make us concerned. We are deeply convinced that human rights and civil liberties are due to everyone - in Brussels and Hamburg, but also in Tehran. This also includes freedom of expression and freedom of demonstration, and we are concerned about the harsh and sometimes violent reaction of the Iranian authorities. The dead demonstrators and the many people imprisoned are unacceptable to us. They are also not a sign of strength, on the contrary. However, we are also convinced that demonstrations themselves must be peaceful and non-violent if they do not want to lose their legitimacy. We have problems with Iran on other issues too: the missile program or anyone who questions Israel's right to exist must expect our bitter resistance. Nevertheless, or precisely because of this, it is important to speak. With a clear stance, but also with mutual respect, for example in the high-level discussions on human rights that you mentioned, Commissioner. There is also some initial progress, for example in the use of the death penalty. The Iranian government has taken the first steps in the right direction, and more should follow. I agree if the Iranian government demands not to interfere in internal affairs - for example by actively supporting uprisings. But one must be allowed to speak about universal human rights, and the missile program and Israel's right to exist also affect us and our fellow citizens. The Social Democrats expressly support the clear stance of the Commission and the High Representative and all other contractual partners of the so-called nuclear deal. This is a good example that diplomacy can achieve something. Iran is sticking to it. There is no reason to question him - im On the contrary: it can help build trust so that, perhaps one day, we can solve other problems in conversation with one another.To question him is to lose trust, to be unable to solve a problem and to irresponsibly destroy what we have achieved.It is time for the American president to come to his senses.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, given the ongoing tensions in the region and the debate underway under President Trump’s administration as to the future of the JCPOA, the wave of protests that we have now seen in Iran during the last two weeks has arrived at a particularly volatile and dangerous time. Judging by reports on the ground, and seeing the release in the last two days of large numbers of those detained, it does now seem as though the situation may be calming. Clearly there have been horrendous breaches of human rights, with as many as 25 protesters reported dead, abuses which we must all condemn in the strongest terms, but which are tragically characteristic of that brutal theocratic regime. It is clear that the protests emanated from a mixture of economic, social and political concerns from the population at large, an analysis which even President Rouhani himself has conceded. On the nuclear deal, I am conscious that for many Western politicians who oppose it these protests are seen as a further justification of their position. It is, however, vital that the nuclear deal is seen as being totally separate from our general relations with Iran and stand alone. The P5+1 JCPOA in Geneva in 2015 was not aimed at improving the governance situation in Iran, but at preventing the state from acquiring nuclear weapons. On these aims alone, it appears so far, fortunately, to be succeeding under strict IAEA monitoring, and we must all hope in this House that it continues to do so in future.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the people in Iran have taken to the streets en masse in peaceful demonstrations, asking for a more just, open and free society, as well as less corrupt leadership. They deserve the EU’s unequivocal support and should know that the EU has their rights and their freedoms at heart, and at the top of our political agenda. I do worry that the messages from the EU are not clear enough. Yes, we should stick to our word on the nuclear deal and keep Iran to its commitments, but this should not prevent us from engaging the Islamic Republic’s leaders on human rights and foreign policy.  In Syria, Yemen, Iraq and Lebanon, Iran plays a toxic role. Just because we are both against ISIS or Daesh, it does not mean we share objectives or interests otherwise. Of course the Iranian people are well aware that the billions worth of support for Hezbollah and Assad’s murder machine are not spent on healthcare, infrastructure or education in Iran itself.  When the nuclear deal was negotiated, we were constantly reminded that the talks did not cover human rights or Iran’s role in the region, so along the same vein we should not allow for the question marks that President Trump puts to the nuclear deal now to blur our sight. Precisely because human rights and Iran’s foreign policy are not part of the nuclear deal, we can confidently address these topics any time, and we are free to adopt more individual EU sanctions, and should not shy away from that. For the EU to be credible, we need to be heard clearly on all fronts, and not just in defence of the nuclear deal.  I urge the authorities to free all imprisoned demonstrators and to stop the torture and executions in the prisons, because I am convinced – and I hope we all are – that the march to freedom by the Iranian people is unstoppable.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! We mourn the demonstrators who have lost their lives just because they have publicly expressed their legitimate demands for better living conditions, for work, against the drastic price increases and for an environment in which it is possible to live. The deaths of these protesters must be investigated in order to do justice to their loved ones. We strongly share President Rouhani's view that demonstrators have a right to demonstrate. That is right, and we also think it is wrong, that Khamenei and the spiritual leaders threaten, for example, with the death penalty. But the consequence must be to release the arrested demonstrators immediately, and that is a central demand that we have. The power struggle for the future of Iran has long since begun. The situation there can only improve if the country opens up, and there is now a time window for this that must not be slammed from outside - not even by an insane US president. That is why it is right for the EU, for countries like France, Germany or Great Britain to adhere to the nuclear agreement with Iran. Because Iran is sticking to the deal, and because we should have a minimum of interest in seeing an end to nuclear armament in the Middle East. We also do not want to renegotiate the agreement. Iran no longer needs sanctions, but rather their dismantling, and that includes access to international banks. At the same time, a step forward - and a clear step forward - must be made in the human rights dialogue, particularly with regard to religious minorities, political rights and women's rights. It is about very important questions, such as employment, the future of Iranian youth, drug prevention, the withdrawal from Yemen and other countries. These are practical questions of theirs Solution depends on what the future of Iran looks like.It is therefore not about chaos, which should be fanned here, but about far-reaching reforms.As the EU, we are committed to responsible policies that keep the people of Iran in mind.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! The nuclear deal is an essential factor of stability in a region in which millions of people are already suffering from armed conflicts and crises. The deal is also a success for European foreign policy. This is evident in the face of ongoing and dangerous provocations from Washington. The EU and its member states are united and united in their support for the existing nuclear deal. The nuclear deal decided in 2015 has also raised hopes for domestic political reforms in Iran, which have so far hardly been fulfilled. This is also shown by the demonstrations last week. Initially, the protests focused on socio-economic issues, especially price increases and high unemployment. Political demands soon followed, including the overthrow of the government. The demonstrations resulted in mass arrests and at least 25 people were killed. These deaths need to be investigated and the prisoners of conscience released. President Rouhani has spoken conciliatory and self-critical tones towards the demonstrators. A rethinking process within the entire Iranian leadership is urgently required. However, following the re-election of Rouhani, the situation of human rights defenders has deteriorated further. The repression is terrifying: very long prison terms and official statements denigrating activists as foreign agents and traitors. Those at risk of repression stand up for freedom of expression, for women's rights, for independent trade unions and against the death penalty. As anti-capitalist activists, Ms. Narges Mohammadi is serving a sixteen-year sentence and Atena Daemi is serving a seven-year prison sentence. And the writer Golrokh Ebrahmi was sentenced to six years in prison just for texts denouncing the cruel practice of stoning. The EU must Increase support for human rights defenders more clearly in all the ways it has to talk about human rights and call for improvement.And it has to do that in all discussions and should not distinguish whether such debates are now only being conducted on the atomic deal or on the other topics as well.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President! Today we are talking about Iran, where dramatic developments are taking place. People take to the streets and demonstrate for a better and freer life. Anyone who finds the courage to do so deserves our full sympathy. It is everyone's right to seek happiness and complain about their government. President Rouhani's mullah regime is believed to be one of the most corrupt and incompetent regimes in the world. I warn, however, that the so-called West is interfering in Iran's internal affairs. All of these attempts have repeatedly failed, sometimes in a terrible way: Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, Somalia. There must be an end to such interventions! The West supports Al-Qaeda’s offshoot in Syria, just like the Wahabi system of Saudi Arabia - both wrong decisions of grandiose proportions, which prove that we should refrain from fiddling around in the Middle East for all time.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing a spontaneous, not heterodirect, revolt, as some sectors of Iranian politics have tried to believe, and I would even say genuine. A true popular revolt is a whole people, including the middle class, not just the young unemployed, who take to the streets to declare their desperate desire for freedom. And in the face of this real situation, motivated by economic and social reasons, of course, unemployment and poverty, but also by the rejection of a deeply corrupt Iranian ruling class, there is little talk in this House about the corruption of Iranian leaders. You have exalted us, Mrs Mogherini has exalted us several times her great friendship towards the Iranian Ayatollahs, the great successes of European diplomacy, but European diplomacy should also deal with the rights of peoples, not only the interests of the ruling classes, especially when they are so corrupt and so cruel to those who think differently, to those who demonstrate democratically in the streets for their rights. And what has been the response of this foreign policy, of this European Union? A few tweets, shy, belated, very shy, prudent, I dare say fearful! I have heard in this House rightly saying that the problem of nuclear policy must be distinguished from the defense of human rights, which should be valid erga omnes, not erga omnes after the Ayatollahs, erga omnes indeed! But there was not here, and even in this House there is no specific request, not only evidently to the Iranian authorities, to throw out these good guys who demonstrated democratically and peacefully, but also to ensure rights, to example, of the defense. Here the defense lawyers are incarcerated! All over the world Europe tears its clothes when these events happen but here they are protected. Then the explanation is only one: is that there are geopolitical interests, and perhaps also economic ones, maybe there are the interests of big business that you want to do with these gentlemen who are the Ayatollahs, who put in jail, persecute, kill, sentence thosewho allow themselves to go to the streets peacefully to demonstrate for freedom.Dear Europe, in this situation you demonstrate that you are cowardly, fearful, inefficient, inadequate, unworthy of your values of defense of the rights and freedom of peoples.The Europe of peoples, not the Europe of banks and interests!

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I have seldom seen such a dishonest debate as here. First you impose sanctions, pull through the ten years, bring Iran to an end economically and financially and then complain that the demonstrators take to the streets. Where did the demonstrators get the weapons they used when there were shootings? We know that from the Maidan, we know that from other countries in the Arab Spring, and now it's Iran's turn. You are always very quick with sanctions - against Russia, against Iran, against Syria. But where are the sanctions against other states that violate human rights and commit war crimes like the United States of America, like Saudi Arabia, like Israel? There are enough states. Yes, even NATO countries, especially Turkey, do not need to wash their hands here in innocence. So first return to your own door! Lift all sanctions, give Iran a new chance!

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, it was the PPE Group that asked for the inclusion on the agenda of this debate on the situation in Iran, because we believe that the European Union cannot remain silent about the demonstrations the most important that the country has known for almost a decade. At least 25 people lost their lives, some 4,000 people were arrested and, as you know, tens of thousands of Iranians protested in 80 cities across the country to defend their dignity, freedom and economic survival. . So, I say that it is an obligation for us to make the voice of Europe heard on these demonstrations and on these implications, because for the whole world, the almost complete silence of Europe during these demonstrations was difficult to understand. And the image given by the High Representative, present in Cuba at the beginning of the year to promote friendship with the Cubans and very hesitant about Iran, did not represent a good start to the year in terms of politics. foreign. I am very sorry to say this, but the European position really has been difficult to explain to our partners. We must insist that the right to peaceful protest be respected in Iran and that those unjustly arrested for attempting to assert this right be released. Above all, we must make our voice heard, because these demonstrations are an opportunity not to be missed to promote political and economic reforms in the country. It is in the interests of regional peace, stability and non-proliferation. If we keep quiet about human rights, that doesn't help with non-proliferation. We are well aware that these protests were very different from what happened in 2009, that there were also conservatives who started movements, but the right of the Iranians to express their discontent does not take into account of these political cleavages, of these ideological cleavages.Therefore, let us have the courage to demand economic reforms from our Iranian partners, because they are open to cooperation with Europe, but we must do so frankly on this issue.A “foreign affairs” mission will most likely visit this country and I think this will be an opportunity to mention this perspective: cooperation in a number of issues, but also respect for rights and the promotion of economic reforms inview of liberalization of this regime.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! Iran has been occupying this house a lot lately. One can see this fact positively or one can see it negatively. Negative because there are obvious problems. Positive because we talk about it constructively. This constructive dialogue is the order of the day and we must hold on to it. For too long the relationship between Iran-Europe / Europe-Iran, however you want to see it, was disturbed. We existed against each other and side by side - for almost 40 years. Only the nuclear agreement created a basis on the basis of which we can start building a zone of stability in the region. We urgently need this because the problems in the region have a direct impact on Europe. Stability - this is the lesson from our painful history - only exists if democratic conditions, the economy and economic prosperity exist and the states renounce violence in their relationships with one another. The nuclear deal is an important step that others must follow. Above all, we must end the arms race in the region. The protests in Iran have their roots in the unsatisfactory economic situation. Many people probably expected that the agreement would lead to an immediate economic upswing. None of this happened because the effects of the sanctions still exist. But the protests also made it abundantly clear that what matters to the people is democracy, the rule of law and human rights. It is positive that the reformist forces are fundamentally in favor of the right to freedom of expression, but this contradicts the use of force against demonstrators, the many imprisonments and the blocking of social networks. We expect those responsible to follow up the protests with deeds. The human rights dialogue must be continued and intensified. It's a positive one Signs that the new law against drug trafficking will for the first time result in a drastic reduction in the number of death sentences.Of course, our categorical call for the abolition of the death penalty remains, but it is an important first step if at least 4,000 people are not executed.Many such steps will be necessary, and the people of Iran expect it, and it is our obligation to note and promote this positive development.However, we must not lose patience.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, yes, there was too much economically-motivated enthusiasm, as well as diplomatic gestures of friendship towards the regime of the Ayatollahs, accompanying the conclusion of the JCPOA. But this topic is absent in the streets of Tehran. The people’s slogans are different and are against a very violent regime, also playing a very destructive role in the region and globally. We now have to send a very strong message condemning the actions of a regime that really has a very bad record of intimidating and murdering its own people. Ayatollah Khamenei quite recently spoke of executions. Yet, at the same time, we receive the Foreign Minister of Iran in Brussels pretending that the JCPOA is the most important topic. Our message is too weak. We have to deter further, eventually very destructive, actions by the regime.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, we have mentioned the nuclear deal. I must say that I understand the reasons, but there is no need really to talk about this because we stand firmly behind the deal, and of course our position is very different from what we see across the Atlantic. But that is not a reason to compromise on our principles and values. I must say we are fooling ourselves that purely economic issues were the driving force, and that there is a major difference between the radicals and the so-called moderates: as we have seen, in fact in the last few days, that is not the case. And seeing their excessive force, the killings, the arrests and, I am afraid, the executions that will follow, well this is something we cannot compromise on. I do condemn the excessive violence and the behaviour of the Iranian regime, and I show solidarity to the Iranian people. I also have expectations that we will send a strong message that we want respect for fundamental rights and that this excessive behaviour will be investigated and we will be firm on our values and principles. I am afraid that seeing what the Vice-President and her office have said and tweeted, so far, we have failed. I am sorry that Ms Mogherini is not here today so that I could say that to her face-to-face.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for human and civil rights is a non-negotiable constitutional principle of the European Union. It is clear that Iran still has a long way to go in this direction. There is no room for micropolitical expediency in this and that is why we unequivocally condemn the form of violence that we have witnessed in recent days in Iran. However, Parliament should in no way assist those who deliberately use these principles to strengthen the nuclear deal with Iran, at a time when the International Atomic Energy Agency has repeatedly certified compliance with all its commitments. I am glad that Mrs Mogherini clarified the position of the European Union when welcoming the Iranian Foreign Minister last week. Europe must pursue an autonomous foreign policy in order to balance the destructive policy of the United States, which seems to be moving rapidly from the motto "America first" to the motto "America alone".

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: - Madam President!The demonstrations in Iran were originally against social cuts.There is still a lot of unemployment there and, accordingly, poverty.What is that to us?Now that Iran has fulfilled all its obligations under the nuclear treaty, it is now up to us - the EU and the US - to lift the associated sanctions.As we know, the US is not keeping its commitments.But we Europeans do not fully comply with them either, because it is still not possible to transfer money to and from Iran via normal banks.But there are banks that are ready to do business with Iran despite threats from the US.It is now important that politicians send a positive signal that this is really happening.That will help the Iranian people.We are well on the way to this.I ask you, especially the Commission, for your further assistance.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the 5 Star Movement is and will always be in favor of peoples' demands for greater economic and social equity, their freedom of expression and their sacred right to demonstrate peacefully. And that is why my appeal to the Iranian authorities is to react with moderation, not to resort to violence and to listen to the demands of their citizens. Having said that, I want to point out some errors on the part of the international community, and in particular of Netanyahu and Trump, who voluntarily ignoring the nature of the unrest in progress, more of an economic than political nature, do nothing but add fuel to the fire hoping that protests are the beginning of the fall of the Iranian regime. But in Iran there is a protest against double-digit inflation, high unemployment, high prices, certainly not to ask for the military intervention of the United States, so readily offered by Washington, a Washington increasingly crushed on the myopia of sanctions. I believe that now more than ever the European Union must step away from these war-mongering, instrumental and dangerous positions, which could foreshadow the risk of a new Syria, and must continue on the one hand to support the nuclear deal and, on the other, to insist with Tehran that the benefits of post-agreement investments, including and especially those in Europe, can benefit the entire population.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Madam President! The days of unrest in Iran can be seen as a necessary signal to the Iranian government that reforms must be implemented. According to the magazine “Der Spiegel”, Iranian President Rouhani is calling for the release of imprisoned citizens and is now also reaffirming the right to demonstrate. This reaction by the president clearly shows that there are forces in Iran who have a will to reform, even without the tutelage of the West. I would like to see such forces in Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain etc. But right now, at this point in time, the American President Trump is taking notice and threatening to let the nuclear deal fall through, and makes a compromise, makes demands such as that Iran should give up the development of conventional weapons - a provocation, because which one sovereign state would accept that? Perhaps - ironically speaking - Mr Trump is dreaming that Iran will in future, like the Saudis, buy American weapons systems with open arms, and then the money freeze for Iran would certainly be lifted. Now Europe should absolutely stand by this nuclear agreement, acknowledge it, not only because one should keep its word, but also because the termination would be a fatal signal with regard to North Korea. Why should Pyongyang seek a diplomatic solution with the West when the whole world can see live how the beacon of democracy, how America - or rather, the Trump administration - deals with existing agreements, even though the International Atomic Energy Agency testifies that Iran actually complies with all the requirements stipulated in the agreement. Well, Trump doesn't even want to discuss and negotiate, and he is now trying to instrumentalize the Union. It is to be feared that Trump's policies will have a destabilizing effect on the entire Middle East. It only strengthens Russia and China's influence. Europe would have to be meet their own demands, and therefore the most recent activities and commitments by Ms. Mogherini to the nuclear deal are to be supported.What does Europe need?Europe needs an independent, energetic policy, on the one hand to secure Israel's right to exist, but on the other hand also to bring Iran and Saudi Arabia to the same table.If Europe does not succeed in that, Europe will be relegated to the spectator rank and will ultimately have to leave the field to Russia and China.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, in recent weeks, of course, Iran has been at the center of international interest. The government seems to be in control of the situation but it is still fragile because the causes of the recent unrest are no longer valid. Iran is the second largest economy in the Middle East. Second in the world in gas reserves and fourth in crude oil fields. But the hegemonic role he wants to play in the Middle East brings it into conflict with the interests of the United States, which has imposed sanctions on it. These sanctions have consequences for the country's economy, which, if it worsens, risks a recurrence of the unrest. The European Union is therefore given a first-class opportunity to support Iran politically, to help it carry out the planned and required democratic reforms, and to become a factor of stability in the region. Tehran's decision to sign control of its nuclear program is not only a sign of goodwill but also contributes to the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. That is why the European Union must persuade the United States to lift sanctions on Iran and at the same time help to bring peace to the region and promote the European Union's trade relations with Iran.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a month ago, at the December part-session, we had a debate here on the nuclear agreement with Iran, in the presence of the High Representative. The Commissioner has explained to us the events that have been taking place, among others the contact with the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Iran, and some aspects to which some of the honorable Members have referred, such as the certification for a period of 120 days , the latest certification from the president of the United States, which has put on the table an ultimatum to the European Union, if Iran does not meet certain conditions in relation to ballistic missiles, in terms of increased control of inspections and of course to try to restrict the influence it has in the region as a whole - Iraq, Syria, Lebanon or Yemen. All these aspects would, of course, give time to hold another debate, but I believe that the issue that unites us here today is precisely trying to maintain a critical dialogue, as the high representative said, and have a new appearance on the situation that it is taking place in the region. Obviously, the events that have occurred in Mashhad, and that have spread to the rest of the country, clearly reveal a concern that has its origin in economic problems, in the high prices, in the absence of prospects in the country and also in the situation of human rights. We have already expressed our concern in these debates about the situation of minorities, about the imposition of capital punishment and especially about the situation of the opposition. Commissioner, in your speech you referred to some first figures and we would like to ask that these figures were contrasted, because some information that reaches us tells us that, instead of that number of deaths, the figures are double. Has been many people tortured. Some bodies have been returned to relatives saying that they had committed suicide in prison. And we would really like to verify these disturbing and worrying figures and state that, indeed, the nuclear package and the nuclear agreement run through a channel, but respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms constitutes an essential element of the action of the European Union and we should not refrain from concern ourselves with these concerns. We are going to have a dialogue with some Iranian parliamentarians who are going to come to the Foreign Affairs Committee. The Foreign Affairs Committee of the European Parliament is going to visit Iran soon, in February, and I believe that all these data and all these elements must constitute a manifestation of the concern that the European Union has about the policy of human rights, in relations with the countries with which we have relations, be properly respected.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are two aspects concerning our relationship with Iran which I think it is useful to underline. The first certainly relates to the fact that the European Union cannot remain indifferent to the alarming signal of the Iranian population's discontent with government policies and to the growing ambiguity shown by Tehran in addressing reports of abuse and torture by security forces, just as we cannot close our eyes to the violation of human rights and, indeed, we must have a firm and uncompromising attitude. Then there is a second aspect, which concerns the political role of Iran in the region and the future of the nuclear deal. There is no doubt that for the European Union the presence of Iran in the Middle East region, like it or not, can represent an important element of balance and the same nuclear deal has also been useful to put Tehran back into a possible correct political game in the Middle East region. . And precisely for this reason I consider that the reaction of the US administration after the events is wrong and can produce negative drifts, unlike the just and balanced position shown by the High Representative Federica Mogherini. However, here is the point: recognizing the role of Iran and defending the nuclear deal does not mean for us to bend the question of human rights to "realpolitik", quite the contrary. Political role and respect for human rights must continue together and it is our duty to call Tehran back to its responsibilities and to forcefully request a new season of economic and social reforms that place the full protection of human rights at the center.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Shirin Ebadi, prominent Iranian human rights lawyer and Nobel Peace Prize winner, today sent a poignant message to European governments, to the EU as a whole, as well as to the European Parliament. In the pursuit of lucrative trade deals among themselves with the rulers of the Islamic Republic of Iran, Europeans must remember that they - and now I quote Ms. Ebadi - “shake hands with people who allow the stoning of women and persecute the political opposition in their country. and murder ”. End of quote. Following the recent wave of protests against the Iranian regime, Ms Ebadi calls on the Member States of the European Union to give concrete support to the Iranian people in their legitimate drive for economic well-being and political freedom, for example by offering Iranian citizens a free Internet through a satellite connection. However, I have very little illusions about the question whether the EU will actually respond to the passionate plea of ​​Shirin Ebadi and many other Iranians. Why? In that case, the EU would have to distance itself clearly and sharply from the Iranian reign of terror and its own geopolitical failures in the Middle East under the camouflage of the nuclear accord. Reality and honesty are now urgently required in European policy towards Tehran. In addition, the heartfelt cries of courageous Iranian demonstrators can serve as a guideline for Brussels. Invest in a life of dignity for your own citizens, rather than in the regionally destabilizing power aspirations of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. My urgent question to Ms Mogherini and her deputy, Commissioner Hahn, remains: which side in Iran is the EU actually standing on?

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Madam President, in the face of the demonstrations which have just shaken Iran as a whole, the mullahs' regime has reacted with unacceptable brutality. Thousands of protesters have been thrown in jail. At least 25 people, and possibly more, were killed. According to Amnesty International, five young people have died in prison. Suicides, the Rohani regime dares to claim. In the face of such events, an energetic reaction from the European Union was called for. I regret to say that this reaction has fallen short of what is to be expected of the European Union. It wasn't until January 3, four days after Mr. Trump, that Ms. Mogherini simply called on - and I quote - all parties, all parties, to refrain from violence. She made no difference between the regime's torturers and their victims. Of course, we are right to vigorously defend the nuclear deal with Iran. Of course, we are right to support the access of European companies to the Iranian market, but that is no reason to be so weak, even indigent, in the defense of human rights. The European External Action Service may be good at geostrategic and business matters, but it is dramatically weak at defending human rights. This situation cannot continue like this, the European Union must urgently correct the shortcomings of its external action.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Madam President, since the start of the protests in Iran last December, the repression has caused at least 22 deaths, and about a thousand people have been arrested; a repression that we strongly reject. Protests by the Iranian popular classes against the neoliberal policies of an authoritarian regime that has impoverished millions of people. An economic situation that must be remembered that it has been exacerbated precisely by the sanctions imposed by the United States and the European Union, the consequences of which are suffered, as always, by the civilian population. From here we want to make clear our defense of popular mobilizations, their demands, freedom of expression and their democratic aspirations. But it is also essential to remember that the European Union must respect the Iranian society that is mobilizing. We must not allow their instrumentalization, neither by Trump nor by anyone, because the only thing they seek is to impose their imperial agenda, which has nothing to do with the demands of the Iranian popular classes.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, quite unforeseen by many outside observers, in recent weeks we have seen many Iranians rising up for their rights and freedoms. These protests prove how explosive for many ordinary people in Iran the socioeconomic and political situation has become. This display of public discontent should give us hope for real change towards freedom, democracy and respect for human rights. It is time for the European Union to revise its policy on Iran. Instead of investing in the ruling political establishment as supposed moderates, who, as we have seen, many Iranians no longer trust, we should invest in the young people who deserve a better future but feel abandoned by their leaders and are tired of corruption, oppression and undelivered promises. Finally, the EU must make it clear to Iran that any torture or execution of those arrested in the protests is absolutely unacceptable and would have serious consequences.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Madam President, the right to freedom of assembly and to peaceful protest is a fundamental right not accorded often enough across the world. However, rights are always balanced with responsibilities, and all sides must refrain from violence and damage to public and private property. These protests have once again shown the power of social media as a catalyst for protest and initiating change. The desire for change by the Iranian people has been clearly expressed, and the government would be wise to take heed. However, experience has shown it would also be wise to be cautious in offering unconditional support for mass rallies, as who knows what will be waiting in the wings in Iran, as everywhere.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many of you welcome the recent protests that have taken place in Iran. However, let us be careful about the meaning to be given to these demonstrations. Let's try to take some height. I would like us to think about how to organize a real multipolar world. What could be the place of a great historic nation like Iran in a peaceful Middle East? The Middle East was set on fire and blood when, from 1991 and the fall of the Soviet Union, the West made it a theater of conquest and experimentation. The United States and the Europeans tested in this region the theory of state building, that is, to rebuild a state after having destroyed it. It was a bloody failure in Iraq. Even today, there are only three hours of electricity in Baghdad. We also tested the theory of regime change, with the help of an Arab Spring that we strongly encouraged, if not sparked. It was a disaster in Egypt; the Islamists supported by the West thus aggravated the underdevelopment of the country and maintain, in spite of the efforts of Marshal al-Sisi, a chronic insecurity. Finally, we tried the good old method of the coup d'état in Syria. Four years and 300,000 dead later, it is still a bitter failure and a humanitarian disaster, part of which we have paid for in the form of immigration and terrorism. Today we have the opportunity to ease the centuries-old tensions that we have helped to stir up. The pressure Donald Trump has exerted on Saudi Arabia seems to half open the hope of real reform that could be fatal to Islamist terrorism. Vladimir Putin's action, backed by China and Iran, has helped maintain Bashar al-Assad's pole of stability, despite everything. We must pool these efforts to allow the Middle East to be rebuilt, for minorities to be protected and a real development process to take place.The European Union must promote this dialogue, be an interlocutor, even if it has participated in too many destabilizations.The Sochi meeting and the Astana process show the return to the region of historical processes stifled by the Cold War and unilateralism.It is high time for the European Union to participate in the concert of this multilateral world of balance and peace.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, I cannot understand why the European Union, whose mouth is full of ‘diversity’, tries to make every state a copy itself. Iran was supporting Syria, saving it from the hands of Sunni extremists, and the European Union is not supporting Iran, it is supporting its enemies. Why? Only yesterday, Islamabad declared that only the possession of nuclear weapons saves Pakistan from heinous aggression. Why do you try to prevent Iran from possessing the same weapons that are in the possession of its direct neighbour? Why is Iran treated in a different way than, say, Spain and Catalonia. Why is Iran condemned for not recognising Israel, while Spain is not condemned for not recognising Kosovo or Abkhazia. Moreover, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, dictatorships will never last. They are bound to end sooner or later. But I think the latest surprise demonstrations, which included more than 140 cities in Iran, reminded us of this possibility. Because what is interesting is the scope and message of the demonstrators. Protests against the high cost of living developed within two days into political demands, into the slogans ‘down with dictatorship’ and ‘we want Iran back’. What is significant is that Iranians made no difference between so—called conservatives and moderates. They targeted the regime as such. I think the lesson for the EU is that counting on reformed dictators with a human face is betting on a dead horse. The nuclear deal should, of course, be kept intact despite all the problems. I am firmly for this. But, at the same time, the deal cannot be seen as the only centre for our relations with Iran. When a regime continues to use some breathing space from sanctions not to address the burning problems of their citizens – half of them need state support and 10 million out of a population of 80 million are jobless – but instead to speed up the export of terrorism, conflicts and ballistic missiles, then as my colleague, Mrs Schaake put it, they are playing a toxic role. I am also worried about the sharp contrast between the US and EU reaction. I think this is very important. Whereas the US administration and Congress, on a bipartisan level, sided immediately with the Iranian people, the EU message has been weak and vague. It has been said that in a spirit of respect we expect all concerned to refrain from violence. The regime has never refrained from violence during the last 39 years. So our attitude must be very firm and clear. It must be based on conditionality: release all prisoners, allow free demonstrations, and stop spreading ballistic missiles. Our understanding should be that the Iranian people are fed up with their government. They need a change of regime. We should also prepare for this option.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in recent weeks we have seen a wave of protests in Iran that has concerned us all and, especially, the response in the form of repression by the regime. It must be remembered that the root, the ultimate cause of these protests has been, in this case, especially socio-economic: frustration, lack of expectations in rural areas, peripheral areas, and distrust of the country's traditional elites, something that even Rohani himself has come to assume. In this turbulent scenario, and also taking into account the conflict that the region is experiencing, it is incomprehensible to see how the US administration has decided to add fuel to the fire, stress relations with Tehran and compromise, as we have seen in recent years. months, the nuclear deal. And I want to thank the role of High Representative Mogherini and the voice of the European Union in defense of a nuclear agreement that is being implemented and that is positive not only for the Iranians, but also for the international community as a whole. And I want to send three messages. First, to Iran, especially, but also to all the countries of the international community: the fundamental right to peaceful protest and freedom of expression must be sacred. Second, there is a clear and unwavering commitment on the part of the European Union with this agreement that we want to continue implementing, and we reject any unilateral way that wants to renegotiate or break an agreement that, as we have said, is positive for the Iranians and for the region. And thirdly, we want to continue talking about human rights, from the dialogue, with Iran, and see improvements and effective and constructive progress in a country that needs it. It is time for the European Union to occupy the geopolitical space and void left in the region by the United States, and Iran is a clear example.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Madam President, the courageous protests that have occurred across Iran over the past week should be welcomed as a manifestation of a people finally rejecting the suppression of this evil, autocratic mullah regime. The growing discontent amongst the young against costly foreign intervention, high unemployment and corruption has rightfully put pressure on the Supreme Leaders of Iran. But the EU’s silence on Iran is staggering. It was only after a full week of protests and after security forces jailed thousands, and killed at least 22, that High Representative Mogherini finally issued a shameful statement calling on all concerned to refrain from violence. It would appear that the EU is more interested in protecting its deeply flawed nuclear deal and the trade opportunities now that Iran is going for the WTO, than to tackle Iran’s extreme human rights abuses. As I wrote for The Times Red Box, Iran is not our friend. The price of the nuclear deal has been the unfreezing of at least USD 100 billion of assets that are now being put to malign use right across the Middle East. Iranian Soviet-style destabilisation is being conducted on a massive scale in Iraq with their Shia militias; in Kirkuk they have driven out the trusted Kurdish Peshmerga, just as they have forced out the Prime Minister of Lebanon; in Syria, Iran funds an army a quarter of a million strong; in Bahrain it is undermining the rulers there with violent unrest; in Gaza it is financing Hamas; and it is helping the Houthis firing missiles at Saudi Arabia; it is also working with North Korea on missile technology. The West has simply been suckered by Iran time and time again, but the lesson must be that if this malicious regime, this septic octopus with tentacles wrapped around the Middle East, has to beg for a lifeline from us in the West to stay alive, then we must resolutely refuse.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - I think we've heard it here many times this afternoon. This Parliament is absolutely behind the nuclear deal with Iran. I don't think anyone doubts that anymore. But that doesn't mean we should close our eyes to what's going on in Iran right now. We also discussed this with Mrs Mogherini at the end of last year. The disturbances that were there, disturbances that I can also understand: if there is high economic unemployment, if there is corruption, people then take to the streets and ask the regime to intervene. We from Europe must accept that with our European values ​​and standards. What we cannot accept, however, is that those riots have been violently crushed. There have been deaths, many people imprisoned and now there is also talk of mass executions! Death penalty! As a liberal, I am a very strong opponent of the death penalty. I therefore hope that we as Europe will respond in the direction of Iran. That nuclear deal should not make us turn a blind eye to the constant human rights violations that are now underway. Therefore, let us as Europe give the following signal: the nuclear agreement is in place, we respect this. But Iran also needs to work to reform the country. Allow peaceful protest, look at what can be reformed. Let's also take a look at the human rights activists imprisoned there. I will mention one name, our Professor Djalali. He is in prison and is under threat of death. I would like to draw your attention to this specifically.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Madam President, we have supported the just social demands of the workers of Iran in the face of the neoliberal measures that have led to poverty for a significant part of the population. The sharp rise in gasoline, the elimination of necessary subsidies or the unfair distribution of wealth are incontrovertible data that support the just struggle of the workers. At the same time, we denounce the attempted infiltration of sectors that, using violence, seek not the improvement of the population, but destabilization according to agendas of external interference. There are enough examples of what happened in Libya or Syria, which has brought chaos and war to the region. We also denounce the interference of the United States or Saudi Arabia, seeking to guide legitimate demonstrations towards a path of violent regime change according to their interests. We demand that the Government of Rohaní meet the popular demands and not oppose the repression of the protesters who peacefully demand social and economic rights for their people.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, after 10 days of silence since the eruption of protests in Iran, the High Representative came out with a statement calling on all concerned to refrain from violence. That statement implies that the activists and the regime are morally equal and accountable. This should be compared with the United Nations human rights expert who clearly condemned the Iranian regime for instructing the Revolutionary Guard to hit hard against the protesters. The brave men and women who have taken to the streets in more than 100 Iranian cities have done so to demand freedom, and to put an end to the endemic corruption of the elite. They are also opposing the brutal Iranian warfare in Arab countries and, indeed, the Iranian dictatorship as such. It is important to understand that the rise in living standards that the Iranian people were promised as a result of the international nuclear deal has not been realised. Instead, the ayatollahs and the guards are filling their own pockets and spending huge amounts on supporting terrorist organisations such as Hezbollah and Hamas. Only this year, the Iranian regime spends a staggering EUR 45 billion on the military and security apparatus, including the export of terrorism. Silence about Iranian misrule not only reflects very badly on the European Union, it is also a bad bet. While a free Iran could be a strong force for positive change and for stability, the current regime relies on a system of domination. European silence, European efforts to treat the mullahs as if they were snowflakes, will not change the nature of the morally corrupt Iranian machine. It is time to realise this. It is time to speak up against the grave human rights violations and, once and for all, stop pandering to the ayatollahs.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, the recent massive anti-government protests were motivated by the rage swiftly spreading among the poorest in Iran. Little was done to alleviate the long-standing unemployment problem, dramatically affecting young people in particular. The 2018 budget, cobbling together President Rouhani’s neoliberal agenda and Ayatollah Khamenei’s clerical fiat, exposed the regime’s disconnect over spending on religious institutions and military foreign adventures, such as in Syria, while imposing social cuts and increases in fuel prices, at a time when several provinces face drought and environmental degradation. The elite’s misappropriation and embezzlement rightly outraged Iranian citizens to the point that today the Iranian Parliament was forced to cancel allocations to so-called special entities. Reforms for accountability to attract investments and create jobs are needed. The EU should continue to work with Iran to make it comply with the criteria of the Financial Action Task Force. Fighting money laundering and corruption is in Iran’s and the EU’s interests. Iran’s law against drug trafficking was amended in a way which we hope will spare thousands of citizens from execution. It has to be a benchmark for the judicial reform that is much needed in Iran, which needs to be further pressed by the EU to abolish the death penalty and to stop and address glaring human rights violations. We call for the immediate release of political prisoners, including the recently jailed protesters and Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a dual British—Iranian citizen jailed in Evin since 2016. At the same time, the EU must call on the international community to reject all unilateral dangerous moves by President Trump, Israel, Saudi Arabia or any others to undermine the nuclear deal. The EU must be prepared with contingency measures to counter any attempts to block the JCPOA.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Flemish travel agencies today promote round trips in Iran. Programs full of culture, history and nature. Colorful photos that appeal to the imagination. Yes, the atmosphere has changed since Western civilization signed a nuclear deal with Tehran. A country like any other, a travel destination. But the agreement and the thawing in relations should really not prevent us from looking further. The Iranian people are sending different signals and international human rights organizations also paint a dark picture of the Islamic Republic. Executions remain commonplace. And also dark and gloomy sounds come from within the prison walls. We all know Ahmadreza Djalali, the Iranian professor who also taught in my country, in Brussels, and awaits his execution in Iran. A recent photo of him gives me goosebumps, gives me shivers. A sick, frightened man. The look in his eyes betrays fear and loneliness. Can he still count on us, Chief? I make another appeal to do everything possible to save the life of this professor, this doctor, this family man. Kashmar, Zahedan, Isfahan: these are just a few of the dozens of Iranian cities that have been demonstrating against the policy in recent months. Young people are campaigning against unemployment, inequality and for freedom. Their blood ran through the streets. The protesters want the right to speak their mind and can we prove them wrong? Of course not! The street is only feared in dictatorships. In healthy, open societies there is room for debate, discussion and dialogue. There is little we can do for the dozens who died during the protests. But for the many detainees, international action is needed, Commissioner. What fate awaits them? We can only fear the worst. Commissioner, demand fair treatment of prisoners, prevent them from becoming martyrs and hammer to investigate the conditions in which so many young Iranians live left.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, the extensive and unnecessary use of force against peaceful protesters in Iran by the security forces and riot police is unacceptable. The riots took place because Iranian people were expecting life to get better when sanctions were lifted after the deal in 2015 over Iran’s nuclear programme, and were expecting to get more political rights and freedoms. However, economic mismanagement and corruption has left Iranians feeling cheated of their hopes for a better life. Unemployment is high; the economy is not doing well. Years of political, economic and social grievances sent Iranians into the streets in the largest protests since 2009.  Instead of channelling this money from the lifting of sanctions into the economy and the social system, and improving the lives of the Iranian people, Iranian leaders have opted for spending the money elsewhere, mainly developing Iran’s political and military ambitions in nearby countries such as Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Yemen and others. People must be given a chance to have peaceful protests. Investigations must be made into the unlawful use of firearms against unarmed demonstrators, and also into prison deaths. Detainees must be protected from possible ill—treatment and torture. Society in Iran must be allowed more freedom.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, the Iranian people have been suppressed by a brutal theocracy for nearly 40 years. The so-called Islamic Republic of Iran that was imposed in 1979 has brought nothing but killings, torture, misery and poverty on the great people of Iran, as well as terrorism and the export of Islamic fundamentalism to neighbouring countries and the rest of the world. Now, after so many years, the people of Iran have again taken to the streets and are calling ‘down with the dictators’, and they continue to pay a very heavy price. (The speaker is showing an A4 picture) This is a picture of the 24-year-old Saru Ghahremani from the city of Sanandaj. He disappeared on 3 January while taking part into protests. After 11 days, the authorities informed his mother that the body of her son was at a morgue. She says that she has seen extensive bruises all over his body. Thousands of young protesters have been imprisoned. At least seven people are reported to have died in prison after being arrested in the recent protests. The EU needs to call for an independent international inquiry into the deaths in custody of arrested protesters. We should expect Ms Mogherini to tell Iran that we cannot tolerate any execution of demonstrators. Iran has a very well-organised and long-established democratic opposition coalition. The National Council of Resistance of Iran under the leadership of Ms Maryam Rajavi, was founded in 1981 with a secular platform. It advocates for full equality between men and women, the abolition of the death penalty, and fundamental freedoms. The regime has blamed the protests on this opposition movement. We cannot leave the Iranian people alone.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: - Madam President! The turn of the year began with widespread protests throughout Iran. A wave that also reached beyond the big cities into the countryside. The response from the regime came with brutality. It led to deadly violence and mass arrests, including violence in detention that has led to people dying. The EU should not only condemn the deadly violence and restrictions on freedom of expression, our task must nevertheless be to support the Iranian people in their demands for democratization, economic improvement and social freedom. We must demand the release of the mass arrests and the political prisoners who have been under house arrest or imprisonment for many years. It is still important that we stand up against the death penalty, dubious legal proceedings and the individual cases that we have expressed concern about. Finally, I would like to ask how the Commission now intends to act to support the people of Iran. In addition to the core agreement, we must now develop a new Iran policy based on a clear starting point in the people's demands for democratization and economic and social reforms.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, let’s be very clear and frank. We are dealing with a religious fundamentalist regime, or rather a dictatorship. We are dealing with part of an anti-Western coalition. We are dealing with a country which has very dangerous nuclear ambitions and with a country that is trying to become a regional power, which would shake the power balance in the region.  All that is contrary to our own European interests.  Now we can see that the people of Iran want a regime change and that in all 31 provinces in Iran people simply went out into the streets and called for that. The Revolutionary Guards subsequently killed dozens of people in the streets. They have arrested about 8 000, and some of those arrested have already been killed under torture. I have a picture of the very first person who was killed. So Iran is now in a very explosive situation and unfortunately the European Union is still following a failed policy of engagement. That must stop. The European Union has to speak up and we have to admit that the people of Iran, unfortunately, are hurt by the current policies of the European Union.  So, instead of having friendly relationships with Iranian officials, the EU should clearly take the side of the people of Iran who want change, including engagement with the best organised exile opposition organisation, the PMOI, rather than cutting ties with them. We should clearly say that we will not tolerate any executions of demonstrators under any excuse and, if the Iranian authorities continue, we must simply break off our relationships and again impose sanctions on Iran, for human rights violations.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, the riots in Iran in recent weeks are significantly different from those in 1999 and 2009 because they took place across the country in about a hundred cities. They were attended mainly by the poor and disenfranchised citizens of Iran and they expressed dissatisfaction with the regime as a whole, not distinguishing between so-called reformists and hardliners. During the riots, thousands of people were arrested and dozens killed, mostly young people. More detainees died in prisons as a result of torture. The European Union's response to these unrest in Iran has been belated, too lenient and unjust. The fate of arrested citizens in a country that has punished the political opposition with the death penalty since the beginning of the theocratic regime, especially since the mass executions of the opposition in 1988, the fate of these people today must be the focus of EU policy towards Iran. The European Union should unconditionally seek the release of all people who have been arrested simply for demanding respect for their basic human rights.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Massive protests erupted in Iran less than 3 weeks ago. It started from the second largest city with demonstrations against poverty and government corruption, but the uprising spread throughout the country. The slogans quickly became political and called for the fall of the Islamic Republic of Iran. The protests affected over 100 cities across Iran, with approximately 8,000 people arrested in 2 weeks. At least 7 people have died from torture in prison, but the total number of victims is undoubtedly higher. Amnesty International has called for an investigation, but of course this is not happening. The regime disconnected and censored the Internet and social media to prevent the spread of the uprising. Government intelligence agents identify protesters throughout the day, but arrest them only at night to avoid public outrage. As I have already said, there are deaths of those arrested who are actually murdered by the government regime. The difference between the Iranian uprising in 2009 and these recent protests is as follows. Previous protests were the result of a dispute at the governmental level, but this time the people are really against the whole regime and the government regime is aware of it. People are calling for this regime to change to democracy and freedom. Personally, I have had a long-standing relationship with the main Iranian opposition PMOI, which the Iranian regime has accused of protesting. I even met the leader of the opposition, Mrs Marjam Rajavi. She has many followers among the young generation within Iran, who these days published their portraits and their 10-point plan for Iran on bridges and in public places: the separation of religion from the state, women's rights, rights for minorities, freedom of opinion, end of punishment death and Iran without nuclear weapons. This is a plan that deserves our support. The people of Iran expect the EU to show solidarity with them. I therefore call on the EU to warn the Iranian regime very clearly that we will not tolerate the execution of any of the protesters. We must support these very protesters. The current response from the EU, in my opinion, is neither sufficient nor rapid.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Madam President! Jeopardizing the nuclear deal with Iran, as Donald Trump does again and again, is not only narrow-minded, but also grossly negligent. A few days ago, President Trump asked the Europeans to renegotiate the treaty. Only: The deal is not perfect, but it is currently the best international deal we have with Iran. That does not mean that we should not start thinking about how things can go after the expiry of the nuclear treaty. The previous contract was negotiated for 13 years. Of course, we are also concerned about the protests in Iran and above all the reactions to them. As the European Union, we must particularly press that the right to freedom of expression is preserved and that human rights are respected. Overall, the EU should speak with one voice with regard to Iran - also to Donald Trump. Only in this way can a responsible European foreign policy produce corresponding results.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Madam President, while here we were quietly celebrating the New Year, young Iranians, risking their lives, demonstrated on December 31 for the fourth consecutive night in Mashhad, Qom, Tehran and other big cities . An unprecedented wave of protest, no doubt, in the country since 2009, this time emanating mainly from the popular classes, the sons and daughters of workers, the unemployed, but also pensioners asking for bread, a roof and freedoms, and therefore, fundamentally, that require regime change. The mullahs' response was scathing, bloody: 25 dead, 8,000 arrests and cases of torture followed by death. The European Union’s response was long overdue. Five days. It’s a long time, especially since Mogherini has been cautious, even timid. So my question, Commissioner, is simple. On January 11, Mrs Mogherini met the Iranian Foreign Minister in Brussels to talk about the nuclear deal, much like you this afternoon, Commissioner, who opened our debate on this issue. It speaks, it seems to me, about your priorities, but there are deaths, there are thousands of people imprisoned there, so I come back to my question. Ms. Mogherini she obtained guarantees on their fate; if so why? I take this opportunity to conclude with the fate, which has already been mentioned, of the Belgian professor Mr. Djalali, who is sentenced to death, who is very ill, who is still in prison. I would like to know whether her fate was mentioned in the discussions and, if not, whether Ms Mogherini intends to do anything, and what.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: – Madam President, although my language as an Austrian Member of the Parliament is German, I want to speak in English, so that the enormous number of people in Iran who follow events via the internet and who want great change in their country may understand me better. Let me express my deep respect for the thousands who have been arrested, and the many dozens who have been murdered at the recent legitimate uprising of the Iranian population. This uprising is one of the most important developments in the Middle East and I think we should get the message that brave – and mostly young – Iranians wanted to express that the people of Iran have had enough of their Islamic regime. They wanted, right from the second day of the uprising, Khamenei and Rouhani to step down. We must understand what is going on there. By their slogans they clearly said that they are not interested in any of the ruling factions of this regime and they reject it.
