We can easily see a rather weak and fragile regime, despite its adventures in the region by meddling in Iraq, Syria and other countries in the region. This meddling in other countries is to cover its internal problems. I think the EU and our European External Action Services under Mrs Mogherini should really revise the current policies towards Iran. In reality there are no moderates in this regime. Under Rouhani’s government, around 3 500 people have been hanged, which makes Iran the number one state executioner in the world, per capita.  So it is absolutely a very bad policy for our long-term interests and not just morally problematic to be on the side of this religious dictatorship. We expect our High Representative to tell the regime that we will not accept any of executions, and especially those of people arrested in these protests. I was quite pleased by the position adopted in the United States, and especially by prominent leaders of the Democratic Party who expressed their support for the uprising, and by the agreement with that position, including from Nancy Pelosi, Jack Schumer and even Bernie Sanders. Without any doubt, the position of my Republican friends is consequently against the regime. Colleagues, you may know that the supreme leader of Iran, Ali Khamenei, was silent for 13 days, and when he finally spoke, he blamed this uprising on the opposition under the leadership of Ms Rajavi. Even the top leader of the regime has admitted this, so maybe the people should take this seriously and support this opposition, just as we support a free Iran.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, we are currently witnessing the most serious anti-government protests in Iran for a decade. At least two dozen protesters have reportedly lost their lives and nearly 4 000 have been imprisoned. The real numbers might be multiples of this. Many fear a repeat of 2009 when scores of demonstrators faced torture in unofficial detention centres. Meanwhile, vital communication channels and social media remain blocked. The alleged suicides of three jailed protesters underscore the importance of standing by the Iranian people in defending their fundamental right to peaceful protest and protecting them against disappearances and execution. With the nuclear deal hanging in the balance due to President Trump’s outrageous ultimatum, the EU now has the unprecedented leverage to use its role as guardian of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action to stand up for human rights in Iran. I urge European leaders to withstand the pressures to sweep one issue under the rug to the benefit of the other. We need to use our leadership in the nuclear file to support the Iranian people and those who are open to reform. The 2015 deal is a key EU foreign policy success that has to be defended. This is no less true for our reputation as a bulwark of fundamental rights.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam President, to this day, Iran continues to openly finance terrorist organizations. It is among the countries that apply the death penalty the most and deny the most basic rights to women and homosexuals. The regime of the mullahs has proven incapable of offering a prospect of prosperity to the Iranians, a young, vibrant people, not yet corrupted by the fanaticism of their tyrants, who expect the support they deserve from Western democracies. The European Union cannot deny it without compromising its values, without compromising its very nature. The repression in the recent protests has been brutal, with dozens of deaths and prisoners. I am very concerned about the fate of those arrested and accused, some of the limes have died in custody - at least five, according to Amnesty International. The European Union must monitor and demand that everyone be treated in accordance with international human rights conventions. Furthermore, Europe is nothing if it does not defend European values ​​throughout the world. If Rohani is really an opener, he should be showing it. From Europe we must act intelligently to combine stability and peace with the democratization of the region. Because democracies do not go to war: they resolve their conflicts in international forums or through dialogue. A democratic Iran, or at least more open, would be an opportunity for all. Mrs Mogherini, may prudence not be an excuse for immobility.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I am one of those colleagues who say that we should be brave and support the demonstrating people of Iran, clearly stand up for the students, the young people who, unfortunately, do not see the prospect of an interesting and happy life in this country today. I think it is clear that the reasons for the protests are not political, they are not against, say, the Islamic Republic of Iran, as some Islamic Republic officials claim, but they are mainly due to the poor living conditions that Iranians have. Whether it is an economic situation in a country that is not improving, rampant corruption or Iran's expansionary foreign policy, which exhausts a large part of Iranian taxes that could otherwise be used for the benefit of citizens, social systems, health care, etc. I am therefore convinced that we should not turn a blind eye to the situation in Iran just because we have a nuclear agreement with Iran. Iran is a country where democracy simply does not work, where human rights are being suppressed, where the death penalty is being abused. Iran is one of the 3 countries in the world where the death penalty is most used - and I say abused - and the EU has always been a leader, a critic of the death penalty. It needs to be constantly reminded. After all, even in connection with these demonstrations, more than 1,000 demonstrators were imprisoned, some figures say 1,000 to 2,000 demonstrators, and some members of the regime are already talking about severe punishments. There is even speculation about the possible death penalty, and here I think, Commissioner, that we must play a key role on the international stage and simply do everything we can to stand up for the demonstrators so that those imprisoned are released so that the Iranian people can demonstrate freely in general, to express our political views, but for those who have been imprisoned to be released, and above all we must prevent reprisals or, in the worst case, even executions against these prisoners. That, I think, would be a very bad business card for what Mrs Mogherini was talking about here a few weeks ago, how they are improving our relations with Iran, as trade is growing, as cooperation is improving on the basis of that nuclear agreement.I am skeptical of the agreement, I am afraid that the Iranian regime, if it suits it, will break it, but I respect Mrs Mogherini's being more optimistic about this.In any case, because of this agreement, we should not turn a blind eye to the situation in this country and side with the United States, Israel and clearly help the demonstrating citizens of the state.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the nuclear agreement with Iran, strongly supported by the High Representative Federica Mogherini, is working and is crucial for security and peace in the world. It is an international treaty that must be respected and extended, and not dismantled. The president of the United States threatens to suspend such agreements amid general amazement. Since January we have witnessed the growth of violence in Iran: the Iranian people show their anger by taking to the streets to demonstrate in different cities. The government repression of these demonstrations worries us and we condemn it unreservedly. We call on the Rohani government to respect democratic rights as well as the right enshrined in the Iranian Constitution to peaceful protests. The opening of the country to modernization entails respect for the democratic rights of citizens, with particular reference to the rights of women. Freeing those arrested and repealing the death penalty: these are imperatives.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, as many have already underlined, we are following with concern the ongoing demonstrations in Iran. It is crucial for the authorities to guarantee the fundamental rights of peaceful demonstration and freedom of expression and for all parties concerned to show restraint and to refrain from the use of violence. The socioeconomic situation in Iran has certainly contributed to the recent wave of protests and it is vital for the authorities to address effectively the needs and demands of the population with bold policies and a comprehensive package of reforms. The current situation, however, should not in any way be associated with the nuclear deal, which we continue to support with determination and which is delivering on its goal, that is, keeping the Iranian nuclear programme in check and under close surveillance. The International Atomic Energy Agency has confirmed in all its reports that Iran is fully complying with its commitments.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I would remind you that you have one minute to speak at each of the following spontaneous requests to speak.I won't repeat that every time.Spontaneous requests to speak

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, the Iranian nuclear agreement has unfortunately left aside the issue of human rights violations and the regime's neglect of its own people, while violence is escalating in Iran today. Dialogue with Iran is important, but it must be constructive and contribute to resolving burning issues. I see a big imbalance in inviting Iranian leaders to Brussels while in parallel the regime to which they belong on the ground is arresting thousands of people. And in addition to arrests, we are also witnessing the killings of protesters and prisoners. The Iranian regime must stop using violence against its own people, and the European Union should therefore not be neutral. The Iranian people are looking for answers to existential questions. The people need a government that cares about its citizens, not one that responds to their concerns with violence. We must unequivocally and urgently tell the government, which raises its hand against its citizens, that we will not tolerate that. We need to show the Iranian people that we care. Because silence is the sin of omission and it brings us closer to the culprit, and moves away from the victim.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Iranian nuclear deal had as its primary purpose the reconciliation of the West with a strategic nation in a region that has been hot for several decades now. The protests of the last few weeks and the danger of instability that the country can fall into risk putting into question all the results achieved so hard by European diplomacy. Our main concern can only be that of safeguarding the rights of all citizens involved in the unrest. There is, however, the danger that the protests will provide the regime's hawks with an alibi to abandon the agreement and resume the atomic program, inflicting a fatal blow to an ongoing detente. Europe must confirm its strong commitment to the nuclear deal and make every effort to ensure that the situation does not deteriorate further. Maintaining peace in the region must be our priority: the security of Europe itself is at stake.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, the situation in Iran is very symptomatic of the contradictions and volatility of the international situation. Protests emanate from the poorest sectors of society, those who will be most affected by the reforms provided for in the country's new budget, reacting to the deep inequalities of Iranian society. A society harassed by the consequences of neoliberal policies, but also by the sanctions imposed by North American imperialism. The reaction of the authorities is not unprecedented in a theocratic regime that keeps the Communist Party (Tudeh) of Iran outlawed. Evident are the maneuvers of the United States, promoted on the eve of the renewal of the nuclear agreement, to instrumentalize real problems, some resulting from its policies, with a view to promoting interference operations in that country. To those who have short memories, we remind you of the consequences of the so-called Arabian Springs or of the interference and aggression against Libya, Iraq, Syria or Afghanistan. To the Iranian people, who are fighting for their rights and living conditions, we express our solidarity, rejecting any interference.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, Iran is once again being used as a chessboard for global geopolitical and geostrategic tactics with clear intentions to influence the US-Russia and their allies. The pro-Western Shah ruled after the White Revolution with the help of the West until 1979, when the Shiite Ayatollah Khomeini, with the help of the Islamic Revolution, Russians and other relevant countries, seized power by establishing a state controlled by Islamist clerics. A common component of the above regimes is that both dominated through revolutions aided and abetted by foreign powers while any opposition effort was violently suppressed and political opponents ended up in prison or exile. It should not be a dilemma for the Union which camp to choose. But as European leaders fail to agree on a common ground with Iran because of their different national interests, what they need to take seriously is Erdogan's alarmingly active Turkish involvement in Syria, as happened with Syria. and with other Middle Eastern countries.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - We discussed Iran in December, now in January we are discussing again for another reason, the severe pogrom of the theocratic regime against those who would like more democracy and more freedom in Iran and, above all, the abolition of the death penalty.As early as December, we emphasized that our attitude towards Iran cannot be based solely on an assessment of whether Iran is complying with the provisions of the nuclear agreement or not.European citizens demand a comprehensive attitude towards Iran, which means that the European Union must not overlook the systematic violation of human rights and freedoms, that it must not overlook a ballistic agenda that threatens not only Israel but also the European Union and its members.diplomatic means to put effective pressure on the Iranian regime to finally become a factor of peace and stability in the region.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I truly regret and strongly deplore and condemn any disproportionate use of violence during the confrontations of recent days in Iran, as well as the 20 deaths in clashes with police. We should also consider also that the Iranian population is now complaining about the lack of socio-economic progress. Iranians need, most of all, economic and social reforms and democratic conditions. Considering all of this, I strongly support the call to end the violent conflict in respect of human rights and peaceful protests.  Last, but not least, we have to closely monitor the nuclear deal to ensure that Iran respects and fully implement this deal, which still plays a very important role for the region.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Madam President, developments in Iran cannot be dealt with apart from what is unfolding in the wider region by the intervention of powerful imperialist powers. Iran's alliance with Syria, Iraq, Russia and Turkey is also in fierce competition for Iran's nuclear program with forces such as the United States, the European Union, Israel and Saudi Arabia, which see the their own interests in the wider region. Both the European Union and its governments play a particularly dangerous role. The mobilizations that are an expression of the accumulated popular problems such as the accuracy, poverty, unemployment experienced by the Iranian people, are attempted to be exploited in the games of competing powerful monopoly interests and imperialist powers. They are in control of huge deposits and trade deals, taking advantage of Iran's geostrategic importance. The peoples should not pay the marble again and organize their struggle based on their own interests in a way independent of intra-bourgeois rivalries, confrontations and competitions between the imperialist centers.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, it is fair to say that the EU voice was missing when thousands of Iranians started protesting last year. While it is understandable that we had been building a relationship with Iran for a long time, we should not be at all shy to react when people are protesting for dignity, freedom and especially for their economic survival. We have long been advocating the liberalisation and democratisation in Iran, which I do not think is in contradiction with the nuclear deal that we stand behind. In the end we are profiting from the deal. Therefore it is really disturbing to see that ordinary Iranians might not feel its benefits. Despite the complexities of the situation, we should focus on measures that can assist the processes of democratisation in Iran. At the same time we should engage in discussions with the Iranian authorities and make it clear that hostilities against their own population could badly damage our political and economic relations.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, Iran occupies a strategic position in the Middle East, at a point in the world where the slightest spark can cause a huge explosion. Consequently, the European Union must be attentive to what is happening in Iran, in harmony with the values ​​it carries, both the values ​​of human rights and of peace. It is true that the nuclear agreement has not yet had the desired effects on the economic level, and persistent poverty, corruption, violations of the law and human dignity have provoked the protests that have been made. knows, as in all countries, moreover, which have experienced this type of situation. Ms. Mogherini had a first reaction that can be described as belated and balanced but, today, she must step up her action to try to bring the Iranian government to reason, forcefully ask it to put an end to the abuses against his people. In conclusion, we must strongly denounce the attitude of Donald Trump, President of the United States, who has acquired the unfortunate habit of adding fuel to the fire wherever possible to allow business to develop in the country. detriment of human rights.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, caution is needed in judging Iran's internal processes. Although the anti-government movements of the masses dissatisfied with the economic and social situation can also be interpreted as a desire for democratization, some say it is precisely a conservative stance against the current president that seeks to stir up tensions. The conservative trend in Iran has weakened in recent years, a trend that is certainly good news for democratic processes, which is why the current processes are dangerous, as they can easily have the opposite effect. Violence cannot be the answer, the protests of citizens must be heard by the government, but all the economic and political opening that has taken place in recent years, albeit cautiously and slowly, between the international community and Iran should be safeguarded. This is what can be built on, but hardly on complete isolation and conservative reorganization.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, it was not a blue card. I wanted catch-the-eye because I put my name down earlier. I am just trying to get your attention because many of the speakers here were male speakers and I think we need a gender balance.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Ms. Ward, unfortunately you did not make your request to speak in time.I can't make an exception now.You're right.It also bothered me that so many men and, above all, so few women got in touch.But that's because of the problem that women didn't get in touch.We must now continue the discussion.You are welcome to stay and ask to speak spontaneously at the next debate.Then we have you on the list.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this was a very fruitful, useful, interesting and partly shocking exchange and I thank honourable Members for their interventions. When it comes to the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, our first concern is always to be as effective as possible. Sometimes our action may be discreet, but rest assured that we never refrain from raising human rights issues at all levels, in all formats and at every opportunity. This is what we did after the recent events and protests and we will also do so in the future. When it comes to the individual concrete cases which some have raised and asked about, I cannot provide you personally with information as I have not been in the meetings of the High Representative. I believe that the debate we have just had also shows that the European Union is united on the need to uphold the JCPOA. Its continued implementation is in the security interests of the European Union. The nuclear deal with Iran has allowed us to have a frank dialogue on issues of concern which are outside the scope of the agreement. In fact, these issues of concern, in particular ballistic missiles and increasing tensions in the region, are constantly raised in the relevant fora, including in the high-level dialogue. As I said before, we will coordinate with the EU Member States to jointly assess the US statement and its implementation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the Commission's position.The people in Iran, from all walks of life, are dissatisfied with the corruption, with the nepotism, with the restrictions on their civil liberties and also with the fact that their taxpayers' money totaling billions of euros annually for highly problematic activities in Syria, Iraq, Yemen or Hezbollah in Lebanon.The Iranian government's violent repression against peaceful demonstrators is unacceptable and should be sanctioned if the behavior continues.I hope that those responsible for politics and religion in Tehran will give in.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – Iran is carrying out blatant abuses against thousands of people protesting about the poor economic performance of the country. This House is committed to defend and promote human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights inside and outside the EU, as enshrined in Articles 2 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union. We cannot pay lip service to these values deceiving our citizens and all the people of Iran hoping for a better future. Iranians already fought for their rights and for better conditions in 1979, but those protests resulted in a theocratic regime; in 2018 we cannot leave them alone. Even if official and semi-official sources announced that some people have been released, it is not clear how many Iranians are still detained, and we will not be satisfied until everyone is freed. As a Member of the European Parliament, I want to strongly condemn the intolerable violations of human rights and civil liberties of the so called ‘Islamic Republic’. I hope that this Chamber can take a unanimous position against these cruelties, and give voice to the people of Iran. Protesters are giving their own lives for a better future and we cannot ignore their voices.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Kenya (2018/2511 (RSP)).Here, too, Ms. Mogherini is unfortunately unable to attend and is represented by Ms. Malmström.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the High Representative is unfortunately ill, and at very short notice I am replacing her. Kenya is an essential player in East Africa, an economic powerhouse and an important pivot for regional stability. We all know how fragile the Horn of Africa is, with conflicts in Somalia, Burundi, Sudan and South Sudan. And we all know how important this region is for Europe as a connection between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean, between Europe, Africa and Asia. We Europeans are strongly committed to that region, with our development cooperation, with our investment, with our military and civilian missions, but also a growing diplomatic engagement. Let me recall the meeting, convened by High Representative Mogherini and ministers of the member countries of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development in late September in Brussels, and we intend to repeat that meeting this year. This makes Kenya a natural and vital interlocutor for us. Kenya’s positive role in regional dynamics is impossible to underestimate, and relative prosperity, democracy and stability are essential to the whole of East Africa. Kenyan troops are contributing to peace and security around Africa, starting with Somalia, and the country has given shelter to about half a million refugees fleeing from war in other African countries. Kenya’s strength matters for all of us, but also for its own citizens and for the rest of Africa and the European Union. Kenya’s strength and resilience very much depend on democracy and rule of law in that country, and that is why Kenya’s rising middle-class demands that its business environment is improved and that more investment is attracted. All Kenyans aspire to free and fair elections with credible and accountable institutions. We have always supported Kenya in its path towards stronger democracy, including by sending election observers to every Kenyan presidential election since 2002. This is also an example of Kenya’s commitment to transparency and its relationship with the European Union. Our observation missions are never meant to declare a winner, that’s not our job. They are there to observe, to report and to make recommendations on how to strengthen the electoral process. The electoral observation mission to Kenya last year has reported substantial progress compared to previous elections, and yet the 2017 electoral process was still marked by some irregularities, political polarisation and acts of violence. As you know, the mission’s final report was published last week. The chief observer, Marietje Schaake, and her team covered both the August general election and the unforeseen but historic decision by the Kenyan Supreme Court to order a re-run of the presidential election last October. The mission’s recommendation for the re-run election has already played a constructive role. In particular, they helped the Kenyan Electoral Commission to make systematic changes which largely eliminated irregularities in the transmission and tallying of results, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank Marietje Schaake and her team for the fantastic job that they did there. The mission’s conduct has been balanced, constructive and highly professional, in line with the terms of the agreement with the Kenyan authority. Throughout the electoral process, Ms Schaake and her colleagues have reported on both the irregularities and the progress they witnessed, in the best interests of Kenya’s democracy and of Kenyan citizens. Despite this overall positive environment, the mission has received criticism from supporters on both political sides. This wasn’t just unpleasant, it was totally unjustified. The mission’s final report provides a good basis to discuss how to further improve Kenya’s electoral system, and we are ready to support this work, and High Representative Mogherini has sent senior officials to Nairobi on Saturday to pass this message on to the Kenyan authorities, even if no government is yet fully formed. There is room to build on the progress already achieved, and there is a duty to do so for the people of Kenya. Kenya can move towards a more inclusive governance and more inclusive development. All communities and ethnic groups should feel that they have a role in the country’s present and future. Kenyans have already decided on the devolution of powers, using the existing constitutional tool to achieve this goal. Kenya has huge potential for economic and human development, it can be a force for stability and growth in the whole region. But the only way to unleash its potential is by making democracy stronger and more credible. The people of Kenya can count on the European Union to help them achieve their potential, and I know that the people of Kenya can count on the European Parliament. So again, thank you for the work that you have been doing. It is difficult, it can be exhausting, but it is truly contributing to peace, security in democracy in our common region.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! As the Commissioner mentioned, the transparency of procedures and the verification of results were raised during the repeated presidential elections in Kenya last October. And despite the flaws and some mistakes that the election commission noticed, the victory of Uhuru Kenyatta was declared legally valid by the Kenyan Supreme Court. At the same time, however, a serious cause for concern is the growing political conflict resulting from the consequences of late legal changes in the electoral law, as well as personal changes in the composition of the electoral commission. The reform of the electoral process should be carried out well before the elections and be based on a broad consensus among all stakeholders. I believe it is important that a dialogue is established between the supporters of the president's camp and the opposition in order to avoid further social polarization, which is starting to take the dimension of an ethnic conflict, with the risk of indiscriminate violence. It is important that, in accordance with the recommendations of the European Union's observation mission, the ruling party is open to cooperation with opposition groups to guarantee the impartiality of electoral bodies. Strengthening the position of the Kenyan Independent Electoral Commission is essential to prevent future election results from being undermined. The cases of the use of force and repression by the security services against the opposition, especially the use of firearms against demonstrators, which resulted in the death of over 60 people, are also worth condemning, both on our part and internationally. But also opposition leader Raila Odinga should refrain from actions that undermine the country's constitutional order, such as the planned unilateral announcement of the so-called president of the people. Therefore, it is essential that the Odinga group takes on the role of a constructive opposition building its political position through legal and peaceful means. All of them political forces in Kenya must work together to prevent an open conflict like the wave of violence in 2007–2008, which, as we know, killed over 1.5 thousand people.citizens of that country.The recommendations in the report of the European Union observer mission provide good guidance to improve the electoral process and establish a legal framework, effective practices and strong institutions that together form the basis of democracy.Despite the existing problems, the focus should be on the future of one of the most stable and democratic countries in Africa.Especially in this context, the European Union and Kenya should strive for better cooperation in the coming years.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, after a troubled electoral year the situation in Kenya is still very tense. I visited the country three times in the 12 months from December 2016 and also received members of Kenyan civil society in my office. I have developed relationships with a wide range of stakeholders, therefore, and I want to reiterate my support to the Kenyan people who were so keen to engage in democratic life. When I visited Kenya in my role as a European Parliament election observer last August, I was struck by the enthusiasm of the citizens who turned out in huge numbers, waiting patiently in line in the cold and in the dark, including many women with babies on their backs, waiting for hours for the polling stations to open so that they could cast their votes. We do not often see such enthusiasm in Europe, so the Kenyans have much to teach our citizens about the importance of freedom and democracy. As we know, the presidential election was subsequently cancelled by the Kenyan Supreme Court, a brave and unparalleled decision which gave hope to many who believed the election process to be seriously flawed. This should have paved the way for better democracy and increased trust. However, the continuing intransigence of political forces has dashed the hopes of many. I know that colleagues from different political groups share my concerns about Kenya’s future, especially in light of reports about the use of excessive force by the police and the serious situation of human rights defenders on the ground, including indigenous people such as the Sengwer recently violently evicted from their forest homes, with two reportedly shot this very morning by the Kenyan authorities. My Group and I encourage all political forces in Kenya to genuinely engage in constructive dialogue in order to find solutions to the deep crisis in which the country still finds itself. They owe it to the citizens and especially to those who contributed to the writing of the Kenyan Constitution adopted in 2010 following earlier election violence. The European Union must continue to support Kenyan institutions in order to increase transparency and credibility, and improve governance. The institutions, including the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC), must regain the trust of the Kenyan people. Political forces in the country, including the government, must also respect the institutions, especially the judiciary, and the election observation mission (EOM) report very clearly states that the judiciary institutions have shown their independence during these difficult times, but have also come under increasing pressure from political forces. This is unacceptable and must stop. As a frequent electoral observer, I can also say that my experience has taught me that we should improve the way we observe elections, in particular with regard to recent technological innovations made to processes worldwide. Electoral voting changes the way that votes are counted and transmitted, and fraud cannot be observed in the same way if votes are cast on paper or on a machine, and counted by hand or number crunched on a computer. The interference in democratic processes in the UK, the USA and in Kenya by big data companies such as Cambridge Analytica, as reported by Carole Cadwalladr, amounts to a hijacking of democracy, and we must be alert to these dangers. In accordance with our Socialist values my group and I support civil society organisations as an essential component of peaceful elections, and I was pleased to be invited to a recent event facilitated by the Quaker Movement on preventing deadlocked and violent elections in Kenya and elsewhere. It is very important to ensure that women and young people are included in political processes at all levels in order to prevent conflict around elections, and this can only be efficient if done through civil society organisations working at a grassroots level. The shrinking space of civil society is extremely concerning in this regard, and not only in Kenya. So as a member of the EOM I want to highlight and support the work of Marietje Schaake as chief observer. I stand by Ms Schaake’s final report and conclusions and support its recommendations. It is important that all parties involved understand we must remain critical friends.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, 2017 was indeed a very difficult year for Kenya. As democrats in this House, we all feel a profound sense of sadness when we observe elections that are flawed, and reading the reports from Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and our own EU Election Observation Mission, this seems to have been the case for both elections in Kenya last year. It was hoped that the historic ruling of the Supreme Court last September calling for fresh presidential elections would have made way for a new and fairer poll. However, evidence shows that, on the contrary, independent institutions were attacked by political leaders, the police again used disproportionate force and the independence of the judiciary and the Electoral Commission were still put into question. It is particularly worrying that the Supreme Court was unable to hear a case seeking postponement of polling the day before the fresh election was due to take place, due to the lack of a quorum of judges. Was pressure applied on the judges not to turn up on the day? It is also deeply regrettable that opposition candidate Raila Odinga felt he had no choice but to withdraw as a candidate. Where does Kenya go from here? The weight of responsibility now clearly lies on the shoulders of the Jubilee Party and President Kenyatta. The world will be watching closely. It is a testament to the courage and resilience of the Kenyan people that their country has not descended into civil war, frankly. Kenya must now come together again to uphold the rule of law and fundamental freedoms that are indispensable to a flourishing, democratic modern nation. The EU and the African Union must fully support Kenya in all these aspirations.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, when I was in Kenya leading the EU election observation mission (EOM), people would often ask whether we were holding Kenya or Africa to lower standards of democracy. The resounding answer is no. It is unacceptable to hold Kenya, or any country for that matter, to a lower standard. Instead, the EU assesses the extent to which elections meet Kenya’s own legal standards and commitments under human rights and international law. Unfortunately, during the 2017 elections, people’s rights were not always upheld and trust was eroded. Our final report, which is available for everyone to read, looks at the gap between law and practice and gives 29 recommendations. The elections laid bare existing tensions and created new ones that all Kenyans suffer from. No, the standoff has not resulted in as many casualties as in the past, but every death – and every death by a police bullet – is one too many. Some Kenyans complained that the world only has attention for the country when tensions escalate into violence. I believe the EU should be smarter and engage Kenya on core topics that benefit all Kenyans: strengthening the rule of law and good governance, supporting civil society and respect for human rights, fighting corruption and overcoming ethnic tensions. These are just a few areas that I do not think we hear enough about, while we hear lots about countering terrorism and trade and other such issues. Anyone who has followed the discussions on Kenya knows that over the past week strong words have been used against me. These statements have been revealing, but I hope mudslinging will not distract from the substantial discussion on our recommendations on electoral reform and on the joint way forward for Kenyans. I would like to thank the Commissioner, the External Action Service and colleagues for their words of support for the work of my team and the recommendations that we make. I am glad that the EU speaks with one voice. I call on Kenya’s political leaders from both sides to show constructive leadership and rebuild trust. Integrity should be baked into the electoral system, regardless of who is in charge and the independence of institutions such as the judiciary should clearly be respected by all. Over the past days, when people read the more critical remarks in our report, they said: ‘But Kenya is the most successful country in East Africa’. Yet, just because things could be worse, it does not mean that they are good or good enough. I remain convinced that we should never hold Kenya to a lower standard, including on the respect for human rights. I have met many Kenyans who are keen to enjoy the highest levels of democracy in their country. I wish them strength going forward and for the EU to be their principled partner.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president; Thank you Commissioner, I am sorry that Mrs Mogherini is not here today and I wish her a speedy recovery. Even so, we want to convey to you that the solution is for the European Union to abandon interference-type policies, to use exclusively peaceful means and that development funds are not used for military purposes. The European Commission must work to empower the popular classes, favoring their access to the means of production, natural resources, and guaranteeing food sovereignty. We also believe that in Kenya we must work tirelessly to put an end to land grabbing and promote a fair distribution - 98.4% of the peasantry only have 11.7% of the land - as well as favor access to seeds and water so that the peasant women and men of Kenya can feed their people. We believe that it is necessary to favor and support the population's access to water and public services, such as health or education. We also believe that the European Union must ensure security, food and decent living conditions for Somali refugees in Dadaab camp, who have been fleeing violence, poverty, drought and hunger since the military intervention of the United States, more than twenty years ago, destroyed Somalia, and work so that Kenya does not force its return.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! It takes time to build a functioning democracy and this is something that we who have had democracy for a very long time often forget. We take it for granted, and it is very dangerous because we then stop fighting to maintain it when it is actually threatened. We also have some young democracies among the EU Member States, and there we can see that what we mean by democratic rules is sometimes put out of play. We see the same or similar problems in many countries. The basis for a functioning democracy is, of course, that elections can be held in an orderly manner, that the organization of elections must be so secure that electoral fraud cannot occur, that parties can participate on equal terms and that winners and losers can handle any change of power peacefully. . Today, when we talk about Kenya, we know that those conditions have not been fully met during the recent elections and the result has, as we have heard, been violence between different groups and a large number of dead. The last choice is no exception. Before today's debate, I contacted my green colleagues in Kenya to get their picture of what Kenya needs today to move forward on its path to a better democracy. First on their list are far-reaching reforms of the electoral system in order to guarantee credible elections, at every election and during the conduct of elections. Respect for institutions and the rule of law as a cornerstone of democracy needs to be strengthened. There is therefore also a need for constitutional reforms that strengthen institutions and increase respect for laws and regulations. There is a need for an independent investigation into the violence after the last election and the perpetrators must be brought to justice. Citizens also need democracy education, where political mobilization is organized around specific issues and ideologies instead of around opposing ethnic alliances and personal interests over the common ones. But not only education is needed. Grassroots democracy and the active participation of citizens participation needs to be strengthened, not only during the elections themselves but in policy issues and decision-making both within and outside the government.Also on the list is to create equal conditions for women, minorities and the disabled to be able to participate in politics, for example to be elected by the people.Last but not least, my green friends draw attention to the importance of protecting whistleblowers.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the present reaction to the situation in Kenya is worrying. Kenya should be seen as a keystone of democracy in the continent. Africa and its partners across the world rely on Kenya to lead the way regarding elections and democracy. I have a strong belief that Kenya’s democratic institutions can and do work and must be supported and strengthened. The democracy of Kenya is crucial, not only for Kenya, but for the whole of Africa and for Africa’s relationships with the wider world. A strong and free Kenya brings security to the Horn of Africa and can be an important strategic ally for us all. The European Union must not destabilise Kenya by simply picking one side. This helps nobody except those who wish ill to democracy. One must ask why, alone amongst international observers, the European Union refuses to acknowledge that the election was comparatively free of issues. There needs to be international help for Kenya to enable trust, rather than trying to kick away the foundations. In this matter, the EU is running the risk of being perceived as acting in a high-handed and a neo-colonialist manner. It needs to be understood that Kenya is a pivotal country in Africa and is a key partner for us all in the fight against terrorism. So let us understand that to hold Kenya to a different standard than other nations is both unfair and runs the risk of alienating our true friends.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Commissioner, what would we say if Kenya judged our elections? Well, I am not sure that Kenyan observers would find very democratic the way in which the European Union goes about muzzling the opposition in different countries of Europe. However, an electoral process took place in Kenya and, due to irregularities, was held twice. Is the re-election of Mr. Kenyatta fraudulent? Today, I think that no one can say it, since even Mrs Schaake, who intervened earlier and who is at the head of the procession of Union observers, changed her mind between August and October 2017. What we must see, however, are the qualities of Kenya: first, a political life more peaceful than among many of its neighbors, an engine of regional growth and, finally, a pole of stability in East Africa. Given the dire situation in neighboring countries, particularly South Sudan and Somalia, it is one of the most effective bulwarks against Islamist terrorism. You are not without seeing, moreover, the resurgence of the Islamic militia Al-Shebab and the courageous fight which Kenya is waging to contain it. Kenya may not correspond to the democratic, human rights and virtuous vision of the European Union, but it is a sovereign state and, what is more, engaged in a common fight with us against the 'Islamism. It is therefore risky, I think, to destabilize it without having the elements to decide whether or not an election by direct universal suffrage is justified. Finally, the Union's observation missions are, as their name suggests, composed of observers, not judges. It therefore seems to me much more useful to encourage this country in our common struggles than to interfere in its electoral process.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, Kenya, after its independence from Great Britain, has been dragged, like other former African and Asian colonies, into the vortex of political, economic and social unrest. The colonialists may have formally resigned, but their influence remained, through the installation of puppets in government positions, economic strangulation, the exploitation of wealth and the creation of economic and political dependence on the former colonial metropolises. To the above we must add the problem of overpopulation, religious fanaticism, water scarcity, intra-racial strife and the outbreak of deadly epidemics. Logically speaking, I do not expect the European former colonial countries to be overwhelmed by a crisis of humanity and to completely liberate their former colonies. However, for the good of Europe, I propose that they finally pursue policies that will properly address the problems of illegal immigration, the risks of communicable diseases in Europe and the humanitarian crisis in third countries.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, the EU, including the European Parliament, has deployed election observation missions to all Kenyan general elections since 2002. The presence of an election observation mission has always been seen as an important instrument to support Kenya in navigating a potentially difficult election and consolidating the country’s democratic path under its new constitution. So naturally for the 2017 elections an election observation mission was also deployed. I was in Nairobi for the elections on 8 August, heading a seven-Member EP delegation which was integrated in the long-term EU mission headed by our chief observer, Marietje Schaake. It is important to stress that our EU election observation mission made a very balanced evaluation of the electoral results. All the Members who were there, including myself, observed the process in Nairobi, Kajiado and Naivasha and reach conclusions which were fully in line with the mission’s findings. I would also like to point out that right after the elections when the opposition issued a press statement that the election IT systems had been hacked and the election results fundamentally compromised, it was the international observers, and especially the EU election observation mission, who unanimously called on political leaders to act responsibly, to pursue any complaints through legal dispute mechanisms, and to ensure their supporters remained calm. This was a crucial moment in this difficult electoral process. We should support the EU election observation mission and our chief observer Marietje Schaake, the analysis and conclusions they made and the ensuing 29 recommendations which were presented last week in Brussels. As in the past in Kenya, the entire electoral process has been extremely difficult and created a lot of tension in the country. Now it is time for the government and the opposition to engage in a constructive dialogue in a spirit of reconciliation. It is time for the Kenyan politicians to bring the people together and work towards an inclusive and socially cohesive society for all Kenyans. Political parties have an important responsibility in this process, including by becoming more programme- and more policy-focused, and overcoming their reliance on ethnic divisions. Finally, the challenges and questions around the Kenyan elections have triggered a reflection, including consideration of the growing role of technology. We as the European Parliament, together with the European External Action Service, should reflect on how to better face the new electoral challenges in this respect. In addition, in mid-2018 the Democracy Support and Election Coordination Group will organise a high-level election observation conference with the participation of representatives of EU national parliaments and international organisations, where the case of Kenya will also be further discussed and looked into.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, last August Kenya experienced a democratic achievement. When the Supreme Court overturned the presidential elections for procedural reasons, the whole country moved towards democratization, as the judiciary showed itself free from conditioning. This courageous act gave hope to an entire continent hungrier for democracy. The candidate and outgoing president, Uhuru Kenyatta, complied with the judges' ruling, which is no small feat, given the dictates elsewhere. Except from that point on, the electoral process took a very bad turn with defections to the electoral commission, which was already suffering from the suspicious death of its director, on the eve of the elections. Unfortunately, the October election generated less enthusiasm. What we regret most is that the Kenyan elections again resulted in loss of life and that the country emerged divided from the polls. Already in the previous elections Kenya had experienced a real civil war, which had caused many casualties, so today Kenyans are likely to be wary and turn away from the ballot. We must demand from the authorities of this country to return the electoral processes to a peaceful political practice. This is how I firmly denounce the irregularities which have undermined the electoral process in Kenya and which will continue to hamper it: the lapse of the rule of law, often non-existent in certain villages in the country, the eternal renewal of the process. enrollment of voters on the eve of each election, in-extremis training of electoral agents. These evils also undermine Kenyan democracy and predispose it to form the breeding ground for controversies and open conflicts; a lasting remedy must therefore be found for these structural ailments. The European Union must find a way to support more strongly the democratic march of the Kenyan people.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! If I have heard some of the speeches made today, then, as one of the members of the Election Observation Commission that was in Kenya in August, I would like to warn that this is not a distortion of the Kenyan elections. As election observers, we did not see that the electoral process was seriously flawed - grossly distorted. Neither did we see that he was hijacked by any multinational or corporate group. What we saw was a free and fair ballot. Everywhere we went, Kenyans have been able - and they have insisted on being able - to vote freely, secretly, and unhindered. And the elections were extremely well organized at the local level, at least where we observed. The report that we adopted highlights that too. And he emphasizes that the Election Observation Commission of the European Union compared over 1,500 results that were counted and documented at the local level with the results published centrally, and that no significant discrepancy could have been found that would have been the result of the would have significantly favored one or the other candidate. If irregularities were mentioned here, then we are dealing with irregularities that were far smaller than what would have been necessary to actually change this election result. The fact that trust in the democratic process in Kenya has been significantly disrupted here is the responsibility of the defeated candidate, Mr Odinga, and it is very regrettable that this has been presented in this sharp form by NASA and Mr Odinga, as Kenya had a great opportunity to build trust in institutions and to strengthen democracy in your own country. Unfortunately this chance is largely been gambled away.The country is now divided.But the chance was there.And the EU should also speak out clearly who is to blame for this fatal development.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Madam President, member of the electoral observation mission last August, I came away with ambiguous and mixed feelings. Kenyans seemed to be both afraid of the recurrence of the violence of 2007 and to expect a lot from these elections, as the queues we have observed testified, indeed. We have only seen a tiny fraction of the actual voting and counting operations, and not the feedback of the results. Was I surprised by the decision, historic in Africa, of the Constitutional Court? Yes, like many others, but it resulted in the re-election of Uhuru Kenyatta, with over 93% of the vote and a low turnout of 39%, unlike in August when Raila Odinga called for a boycott. According to NGOs, this electoral sequence left at least 90 dead and many gang rapes were reported, the perpetrators of which were police officers and men in uniform. The Kenyans were determined to erase the past. They were led to believe that technology was going to restore confidence and the reverse happened. The months and years to come will be essential for respect for civil society and dialogue to prevent the worst, which is to be feared.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Kenya is not only a wonderful place to spend holidays between safaris and dream resorts, it is above all a country that has been fighting bravely for years, with all its strength, to heal the wounds of inter-ethnic war in the name of a democratic dream, a dream that seemed to come true when the Supreme Court decided to cancel the presidential elections due to the serious irregularities identified. But it wasn't enough. The election of Kenyatta, the boycott of the opposition, the unforgivable violence of the police, the indiscriminate use of force, even against simple passers-by, during the demonstrations and the hundreds of women brutally raped: the dream of Kenya today is returning to be there. nightmare of its people. It is not enough just not to submit the final report of the observation mission. Without incisive political, economic and commercial pressures on Nairobi, the soil cultivated with great effort by Kenyans will dry up and the seeds of democracy will be suffocated by the weight of impunity. Faced with the deafness of governments, we have a duty to defend the courage of citizens.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: - Madam President! It has already been stressed by the Commissioner and previous speakers: Kenya is one of the key countries in Africa in terms of stability, economic growth and cooperation with the European Union. That is why the elections in Kenya on August 8th last year were eagerly awaited. Not only the president was elected, but also the members of parliament, the members of the Senate and those responsible at the regional and local level. After previous elections had always led to violent clashes in which many dead were to be mourned, and the pre-election process was also accompanied by violent clashes, the question arose whether the elections on August 8 would be peaceful, especially since there was a new electronic voting process was tried and shortly before the elections the member of the central electoral commission responsible for the electoral process was found tortured and murdered. All the greater was my positive surprise as an election observer that election day was peaceful and that the Kenyans went to the ballot box with commitment and accepted the time-consuming election process with great discipline. The events after the elections are all the more lamentable. The apparent loser Odinga did not want to see his third defeat in a row. The Supreme Court canceled the presidential elections - but only those, not the other five ballots, which were conducted using the same method as the presidential elections - and challenger Odinga withdrew his candidacy shortly before the re-election date. One hears that he now wants to be sworn in as president by his followers. Conflicts between the different ethnic groups to which Kenyatta and Odinga belong are already the order of the day and have resulted in many deaths. The EU election observation mission has the impartial Analysis of the electoral process and recommendations on how the elections can be conducted more transparently, fairly and according to democratic principles.It is highly regrettable that the publication of the EU election observation report in Kenya was prevented by the authorities there.Kenya needs Europe as a sales market, but also as a partner in order to maintain stability in the region, but the EU also needs Kenya as a partner for the same reason.We should definitely maintain the dialogue with those responsible in Kenya, but also give the people in the country the feeling that the EU will not leave them alone in the difficult situation they find themselves in.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, when Kenyan people, including five million young people went to the ballot boxes last year, their hope was to help shape the future of their country. It is deeply disappointing that political leaders and security forces traded this for dispute and division, intimidating citizens, polling staff, civil society and the judiciary ahead of the October rerun. The result is a country bitterly divided along political and ethnic lines, at a time when the EU is looking at Kenya to be the engine of growth for East Africa and a partner in managing migration. We are one of the most generous providers of aid. Half a billion in the current financing period for projects under the Africa Trust Fund. Our priority should be to use this as leverage to support democracy and civil society in a meaningful way, not as a tick-box exercise. We really have to ensure that recommendations made by electoral observation missions are fully implemented and are in sync with the project we are supporting there.  Commissioner, numerous priorities need to be addressed, but I will highlight one in particular which other colleagues have already spoken about: the horrifying and wide- spread use of sexual violence against women and girls by police and security forces. In the 2007 and 2008 electoral violence, thousands of women were raped. This was met with impunity and indifference by the Kenyan Government. Ten years on, we are really seeing a repeat of the same atrocious crimes documented in a chilling report by Human Rights Watch. So, my question to you Commissioner is: will we make accountability for sexual violence and inclusiveness of women a priority for our relations with Kenya? Secondly, how do we move from this tick-box approach towards democracy-building and engaging civil society in Kenya in a meaningful way? Finally, how will we ensure a proper long-term follow-up of vital recommendations on these and other issues where there is significant room for improvement as far as our EOMs are concerned?

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Madam President, the European Union and Kenya are preferred partners. However, it appears that we have dropped some of the provisions of the Cotonou Agreement. While promoting those that represent strictly commercial interests, we seem to have forgotten other fundamentals. For example, promoting the fight against money laundering and tax evasion; promote the rule of law and the judicial system; give financial support to food sovereignty programs; in the field of human rights, lobby for the development of programs for human rights defenders and strengthen civil society. And it is worth remembering that Kenya has more than 600,000 refugees in a state of absolute abandonment. To conclude, and as a priority, we must exert pressure on the Government to undertake a broad and inclusive process of national reconciliation, aimed at overcoming ethnic divisions, which have bankrupted and bankrupt towns and neighborhoods. Without social justice, democracy will not be able to break through.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I join the description of the situation as my predecessors and colleagues have done it. The re-elected Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta has taken office, taken an oath and has another 5-year term. Although the opposition claims that he was not elected legally, he convenes demonstrations, but the local organization that supervised the elections and their outcome claims that the result was OK. However, the police are dispersing tear gas with protesters, and this is undoubtedly no longer in order, and in this context it is necessary to fundamentally disagree with the fact that more than 70 victims have died in major protests in the past. Thus, although the opposition calls these elections rigged, it is necessary to accept the establishment of the president and his term of office. After all, the United Kingdom and the head of EU diplomacy, Mrs Mogherini, and other diplomats congratulated him on his victory. What should the EU do in this situation? I think it is important to strongly support the efforts of the group of prominent African figures led by Kofi Annan and to provide any necessary EU assistance to this group. The Council also mentioned the need for the international community to give its united support to the dialogue under Kofi Annan. It is also important, in my opinion, to support the UN's activities in response to the events in Kenya, which it is carrying out not only at the political level but also with concrete support for the civilian population affected. It is therefore, in my view, very important for the EU not only to engage in political dialogue, but also to be present in the country with concrete action to help the situation of the affected civilian population. Until a legitimate political solution is agreed, the EU and its Member States cannot, in my view, maintain normal relations with Kenya. It will be important to continue to monitor the situation in Kenya closely. All efforts to end the violence should be supported, which is, of course, a priority, but also ensuring democracy, stability and respect for human rights. I think that would testify to the EU's position.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, what happened last year in Kenya, from an electoral point of view, reflects well the potential, the difficulties and the contradictions that affect much of the African continent. Today, there is new hope in Africa, a hope for growth and economic development, a hope for building and consolidating true democracies, based on respect for human rights. And in several African countries, fortunately, we are witnessing changes with great significance. In Kenya, we were able to witness precisely these contradictory data. On the one hand, a people with an enormous desire to participate in a democratic electoral act. Five million young people with a strong desire to participate in this democratic election. Then, an unprecedented decision in Africa of a Supreme Court, which considered that those elections had to be repeated for violation of legal norms, which is something that cannot be stressed here, because this points, in fact, to the enshrining a fundamental principle of any serious democracy, which is the principle of the separation of powers. And then, the negative part, which was the inability of political leaders to deal with this situation properly. Now, the role of the European Union can be none other than, outside any neo-colonialist horizon that, truly, is not being placed in our minds today. The European Union's role can only be this, which is to help consolidate development and help consolidate democratic institutions in Africa and, in this case, Kenya in particular.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I will follow up on what my colleagues have already said, in short and well, Kenya is a key country in East Africa. It is our key business partner. We are more or less evaluating the election year in Kenya here today, 2017. Of course, there are many issues that have been discussed here today, protests, people who unfortunately died in protests, on the other hand, it must be said that fortunately the situation in Kenya is not as in some other African states where civil wars are taking place, where various Islamic terrorist organizations are fighting. Nevertheless, there is room for improvement, and I am glad that today the debate is leading the EU and the EP voice to be fundamentally united in the spirit of calling on the various political forces in Kenya to work together, calling on the defeated candidate in the presidential election or who, in principle, did not even run during the October elections to respect the winners of the elections, because what other solution is it for Kenya today? It is necessary to create peace for political national reconciliation, space for reform, space for the functioning of the state and permanent questioning of election results in the presidential election simply will go nowhere, especially when those election results were recognized by the international community, as my colleague Dr. Polčák said. , The United Kingdom acknowledged these results, etc. The position of the United Kingdom, of course, in relation to Kenya is absolutely crucial. Nevertheless, I welcome interesting and important positive moments in this process, such as the fact that the Supreme Judge was not afraid to cancel the first presidential elections, which took place in August. The moment he found that the elections did not take place in full compliance with local regulations, he simply acted, he reacted. I thus perceive that the Supreme Court of Kenya operates essentially independently. This is certainly a positive moment, but in the future, precisely because of the inaccuracies needed throughout the electoral process, it would be good for the international community and the EU to call on Kenyan politicians to eliminate these problems in the future by amending the law and electoral reform. So what my colleagues said is true. Let us ask the Kenyan President to do his utmost to reconcile the political elites in Kenya, to act in a spirit of so-called constructive dialogue and for the country to develop further.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Mr President, after a difficult political year for Kenya, unfortunately the situation in the country remains extremely tense and volatile. We are concerned about the prolonged period of instability and the latest developments. The enthusiasm and commitment of the Kenyan people to the democratic process and to shaping the country’s future has been marred by tensions amongst political forces escalating into outright violence. Many shortcomings in the electoral process were identified by the EU Election Observation Mission led by our colleague, Ms Schaake. Since the elections, the situation has failed to stabilise and the use of force by the police and the persistent attacks against human rights defenders on the ground are a cause for grave concern. It is high time for all forces in Kenya to show political maturity and to come together to lay the preconditions for an environment conducive to constructive dialogue in order to address the many challenges the country faces today.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, elections invalidated in August, the new elections immediately after, appeals and annulments, police violence, the pride and tenacity of the people who demand democracy, transparency, rights: after the MEPs' mission in Kenya , all the more reason we must relaunch our commitment and our vigilance on what is happening in that country, promote cooperation, a healthy electoral system, the strengthening of the judiciary to guarantee citizens and respect for human rights. The Kenyan people, the government itself and the institutions have the right and the duty to consolidate democracy. The European Commission must guarantee the greatest access to resources and we must all, for example, work even harder so that farmers, especially young people, have greater access to land and its cultivation and that everyone, but everyone guaranteed the right to water. May the European Union strengthen its commitment to Africa, in this case to Kenya, for its people. A great bet is being played on the African continent and we must be guarantors of all this.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We want Kenya to be a stable and economically prosperous state. I hope this is not just wishful thinking. I think we have every reason to do our part within the framework of our cooperation to improve political and economic stability in Kenya. To do this, we also sent election observation and we have not introduced any special rules for Kenya, but apply the rules that we apply everywhere. That is why I expect the Commission and the European External Action Service to fully support the head of our observation mission, who has done an excellent job, and not to allow her to be criticized in a filthy manner by various political sides in Kenya. It almost reminds me of the way the incumbent Vice-President disparages a colleague here in Poland. That is also an unworthy way, and I hope it will be the last chair of the session under this Vice-President.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, following the worrying situation in Kenya, especially regarding the disappointment of last year’s presidential elections, I would like to express my support to the Kenyan people involved in democratic life. Unfortunately the last elections brought frustrations after the repeated confrontation of the opposition against the Electoral Commission, during which more than 90 people died, shot by police. In the light of these violent and tragic episodes, Kenya’s democratic functioning and the situation of human rights defenders was weakened. Therefore, I would like to support the call to immediately end the violent conflict and to encourage the political forces in Kenya to find solutions. The European Commission has to play a very important role in this situation using its full tools of soft power. Last, but not least, I would like to thank publicly Vice President Czarnecki for his activity as Vice—President of this Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Kenya has emerged as a so-called successful country in many ways. But this is a country where land grabbing is on the agenda. The people of Kenya need access to health and education. Exploitation by multinationals continues while public debt is constantly increasing. Within this economic context, the political process is carried out which is characterized by the logic of the client state, by the non-compliance and observance of the principles of the rule of law and the protection and respect of civil liberties. Now the situation in Kenya has escaped with clashes between the supporters of the President and the supporters of the opposition leader, with police violence, with the dead, and even with the rape of women. Unfortunately, in the last year Kenya has missed the opportunity for a peaceful transition to democracy. The European Union must help facilitate the normalization of political life in Kenya, but Kenyans must realize that if they do not face their country's economic challenges together, no foreigner will be able to provide them.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, Kenya, due to its geographical location but also the stability of its state, is a country of strategic value for security and peace in the Horn of Africa, because it affects all its neighbors. In addition, it ensures and guarantees the smooth conduct of trade and the transfer of humanitarian aid from the European Union to the countries of the Horn of Africa via the Red Sea. In addition, it contributes to the fight against international terrorism, religious fanaticism, the smuggling of migrants and the illicit trafficking of weapons and drugs. If, due to destabilization, Kenya is unable to carry out these activities, the consequences for the European Union will be very large and significant. That is why the European Union must support the stability of the country, get in touch with both the government and the opposition, try to contribute to its democratization and serve the interests of the European Union as a whole and not just some countries.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange, and as someone said: ‘the voice of the European Parliament is basically united’, and that is important. We have sent a strong message to Kenya and the Kenyan people. I would like to thank you for your speeches and also express thanks on behalf of the High-Representative / Vice-President. Thank you again, Ms Schaake and your team for the fantastic job that you have been doing and also the people on the ground in Kenya who made it possible for everybody involved in the election observation mission. The report and the recommendations that the mission produced are very useful and helpful. The European Union will continue to engage with Kenya to support it in its path to strengthen democracy and the rule of law. As has been said, Kenya is an important friend, and we will stand by the Kenyan people. I also want to use this opportunity extend my gratitude on behalf of the High-Representative to all the European electoral missions and the teams in the European Parliament who make such essential contributions to peace and democracy all across the world.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Firstly, I would like to welcome and further encourage the strengthened bilateral relations between the EU and Kenya. Despite the difficulties and instability in the area, this state has proven to have a great humanitarian sense and considerable capacity for solidarity, hosting already almost half a million refugees. However, Kenya’s stability and further development are closely linked to the rule of law. During the last electoral process, citizens showed their determination to live in a functional democratic system. Given Kenya’s key role of providing stability in the East Africa area, I find it crucial to have persistence on EU missions in the area, in order to strengthen democracy, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. Finally, I would like to emphasise the special warmth shown by Kenyan citizens during my visit to the region. It is an attitude from which we all should learn. Therefore, I would like to end by expressing my respect, support and sympathy for the Kenyan people.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, the last elections were marred by serious human rights violations by Kenyan security forces, who used excessive force to break up protests and carry out house—to—house operations, during which more than 90 people died, shot by police. The Kenyan authorities have failed to adequately investigate a range of abuses across the country, undermining basic rights to free expression and association. Human rights activists and journalists face numerous obstacles and harassment. The Kenyan authorities should condemn the recent violence, rein in any police abuses, and investigate scores of killings, most of them by police, during the prolonged electoral period. We have to encourage all political forces in Kenya to genuinely engage in constructive dialogue in order to find a solution to the deep crisis in which the country still finds itself. We really have to ensure that recommendations made by the EOM to Kenya are fully implemented.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Klaus Buchner on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union regime for the control of exports, transfer, brokering, technical assistance and transit for dual-use items (recast) (COM (2016) 0616 - C8-0393/2016 - 2016/0295 (COD)) (A8-0390 / 2017)

name: Klaus BUCHNER
