text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! In 2011, human rights activist Abdul Ghani Al Khanjar was sentenced to 15 years in prison in Bahrain; before that he was tortured for days. The reason for his arrest: peaceful participation in anti-government protests during the Arab Spring. The police showed him printouts of all of his phone numbers as evidence. This data could only be hacked by surveillance technology imported from Europe. There are thousands of examples like this. And with the current demonstrations in Iran and Tunisia, precisely this targeted spying is also happening in our day. The European Union is not allowed to assist in human rights violations. That is what this is about, and it is not negotiable. We fight for a trade policy that promotes security and stability in the world and prevents the spread of weapons of mass destruction and espionage. Man is above profit. I am very proud that we and my colleagues from all political groups here in the House were able to agree on important value-based principles for the dual-use regulation. I can see that there are no amendments and I hope that tomorrow you will all vote with me in favor of this report so that Parliament can enter the trialogue negotiations united and strong. I would also like to thank the Commission in particular for its excellent draft, which already contains many elements that are very close to my heart. I would like to express my sincere thanks to Commissioner Cecilia Malmström and the editor Stéphane Chardon for their work. With our design we are modernizing the export control of dual-use goods and closing dangerous loopholes. It's about time. Through revelations and investigative journalists, we see that dictatorial regimes use European spy software to spy on, imprison, torture and kill their people. Happens today, and we fight against it. As with the Ordinance on Torture Goods and the Ordinance on Conflict Minerals, we are continuing value-based trading. We are calling for clear definitions, uniform penalties for violations across Europe, uniform conditions of competition so that the economy continues to know exactly where it needs permits. The catch-all clause for highly dangerous surveillance technology is restricted enough not to interfere with legitimate exports and open enough to close known loopholes. If an export violates human rights, it cannot be granted a permit. The technical development of surveillance technology is extremely fast, which is why the limited catch-all clause and the associated European list are to be constantly expanded. The normal legislative process is too slow for that. It must therefore be sufficient for one state to recognize the problems and for this to become law if the overwhelming majority of the other states agree. We also call for more transparency, the publication of all relevant data on licenses and the participation of non-governmental organizations in the legislative bodies, because industry is involved anyway. We demand that encryption technology be taken out of export controls as an important defense against spying. And particularly positive for the economy: we are encouraging the Commission to convert most export licenses into a general clause that will cut red tape. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to the debate.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this possibility to have this very timely debate. The subject we are discussing today is a true example of value—based trade.  I welcome this report for many reasons. First of all, because it is timely. One year after the proposal from the Commission the adoption of this report by an overwhelming majority sends a very strong political signal. No amendments – that is a signal that the rapporteur has managed to gather almost a whole plenary behind his report. It is illustrating that the process is moving forward thanks to Members’ determination. I understand that the Council is also actively proceeding with its examination, and I hope that the mandate for trilogues will be ready by the end of the Bulgarian Presidency.  I would also like to welcome this interim report because it shows the strong convergence of views between the European Parliament and the Commission. In particular, the introduction of a human security dimension that explicitly incorporate human rights into export controls reflects our commitment to a true value-based trade policy. The human security dimension subjects the trade in cyber—surveillance technologies to effective control. Cyber—threats increasingly threaten countries, businesses and citizens in the EU and across the world, and we must take action – and when and where necessary autonomous EU action – to ensure that this trade does not fuel conflict and human right violations.  We have heard your message on encryption and we share the concerns that trade in advanced IT products that contain encryption should not be unduly restricted at a time when we are racing towards the Internet of things. The proposed general export authorisation is an important step in that direction, but I agree that we should identify efforts to find the right balance between security and trade in encryption products. A few issues that require further attention. Firstly, the parameters of human security controls must be carefully calibrated so that they do not hinder the development of the EU cybersecurity industry, nor the trade in cyber—surveillance technologies that are essential to protect us against criminals and terrorists. Here the report by the Committee on International Trade (INTA) proposes interesting avenues for ensuring that this control will not stand in the way of IT—security research. However, we have to be aware of the unintended consequences of suggestions to identify countries that would be systematically subject to control. Indeed, a defining feature of export control is it is based on case-by-case assessments, and that is why we believe that controls must be targeted and take into account the precise circumstances of a particular export. The INTA report cautions against so—called extra—territorial controls and in this respect we must not forget that the overarching objective of the proposal is to adjust EU policy to rapidly changing technology, economic and security conditions. Technology is global, economy and trade are global, security is global, and proliferators do not care about borders or our regulations, so we must take into account that reality while maintaining control firmly within EU jurisdiction where we can act to strengthen them.  I would also like to point out that there are obvious links between different facets of the threat environment. It is no coincidence that the Wannacry cyber—attacks of 2007 were attributed to North Korea – the same malicious actor that puts international peace and stability and security at risk by developing nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles in contradiction of United Nations Security resolutions, and commits terrorist attacks in foreign countries using chemical nerve agents. This illustrates the convergence of security threats from the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction to cyber—proliferation and terrorism. So we must respond to the risk of sensitive items falling into the hands of non-state actors, and in particular terrorists, and ensure that controls contribute to preventing terrorism.  Last but not least, it is our joint responsibility to wield trade tools to effectively protect security and human rights, and the starting point for this is to make the correct analysis of the threat landscape. The broadening of the threat landscape today does not only concern cybersecurity. Autonomous weapon systems, artificial intelligence and additive manufacturing will shape our world in years to come not only in the civilian area, but also in the military sphere. That is why we consider that EU control should not be limited in principle to cyber—surveillance technology, but should be ready to address other emerging technologies of concern. Failure to do that would make our controls obsolete by the time the proposal enters into force.  So that is why we need to have a proposal that is capable of continuously adjusting to a constantly changing security, technological and economic environment, and we need – as you so rightly say in your report – to make the system future proof.  Again, thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Buchner, and to the shadow rapporteurs for the very constructive report. We are looking forward to working with you to make sure that we have a joint decision not very far away from now.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, the billion-euro commercial market in ready-made surveillance systems remains largely unregulated, and that is astonishing in light of the capabilities that companies in surveillance, hacking and exfiltration technologies are further and further developing. While many politicians claim to be concerned with cyber security, anyone who can afford it can buy systems that collect massive amounts of data, can break into people’s devices without the consent of the user, and information can be removed unnoticed. This is unacceptable and regulation lags behind. The digital surveillance market should worry us in Europe, but the consequences of exports to dictatorships where the rule of law is absent is even more grave and unacceptable. The Arab uprisings seven years ago were often associated with the use of technology to advance human rights, but it has become crystal clear how repressive regimes have mastered technologies for their own goals and control, and this is not limited to the Middle East. Human rights defenders, journalists, critical citizens, dissidents and representatives of civil society are targets worldwide. It has taken a long time for there to be EU action but I’m very glad that we found broad consensus to update the dual-use regulation that will tackle this toxic trade with targeted measures on the basis of human security. Surveillance systems will require a licence before export, human rights will become a clear criterion to assess before a licence is granted, and definitions will be clear, so the private sector will not suffer or be hindered unnecessarily, and we in turn count on their cooperation. Similarly, we seek a predictable level playing field in Europe. We need to end the notion of so-called ‘licence shopping’ where a company maybe rejected a licence in, for example, the Netherlands, but can be granted one in, for example, Italy. At the same time – and I am glad the Commissioner mentioned it – security researchers should be able to do their job, which sometimes requires coordinated attacks on systems precisely to make them more resilient and robust. An encryption which actually helps people to protect data doesn’t belong on a controls list. We call for the lifting of export controls on that. I look forward to a swift trilogue that can start under the Bulgarian Presidency without delay. It is good to see such a coming-together of minds between our three institutions which can have a real impact in the real world.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President! Tomorrow, we will therefore be voting on control of exports, transfers, intermediation and transit, as well as technical assistance for dual-use items. Just the name is very complicated and these rules are very complicated. My goal in my work as responsible in my party group and - I dare say - my most important contribution in this work has been to make them a little less complicated than what many of my colleagues seemed to want. This is important, because these rules are important and if the rules are to work, they can not be complicated away to unusability. Because it is with these rules that we ensure that we do not export things that can contribute to weapons of mass destruction and to chemical weapons - something that the attacks in Syria have shown us with all the desired clarity is a reality in our immediate area as well. Now, with the update we are making, we can also help these tools, this legislation, prevent dictatorships from using European products to spy on their own citizens. New technology provides fantastic opportunities for people who live in dictatorships and suffer from oppression to break free and become free, but it also provides incredible opportunities for dictatorships and those who oppress to spy on, monitor and crack down on democracy fighters. This is also important for our economy. We talk about this too seldom, but treat this issue quite stepmotherly. For the products that are exported, and which are then also regulated under this legislation, in Europe - our export of them - corresponds to over SEK 4,000 billion every year. It is about millions of jobs in Europe in high-tech companies that sell these products, it is about qualified jobs, mainly in the IT sector. This is the new thing here: that it is the IT sector that will also be affected. International trade in IT products really creates benefits. We have noticed this, not least because we have abolished it all tariffs on IT products for 20 years and there seen how IT has revolutionized the world.In a few years, over 7 billion people, over 50 billion devices, will be connected to the internet.And we in Europe are, and must remain, world leaders in spreading this technology.It is important for jobs and growth here, but it is above all important for the freedom it can create and the prosperity it can create in the rest of the world.Therefore, this legislation must be useful and not nearly as bureaucratic as its name has become.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! If we as journalists were working outside the European Union and suddenly found that there is a Trojan on our PC, our communication system is monitored and we learn that third parties know exactly what we have been talking about, how would we feel then ? I think not very comfortably, and if we then found out that the technology was coming from Europe, then I think it would be clear that we would have to have a different regime of export control for such technologies. Technologies that can be used for monitoring and suppression, but also for billing telephone calls. It is therefore important to develop a clear line here so that such technologies cannot be used to violate human rights. That is why we have tightened the legislation on five points. On the one hand transparency: nowadays hardly anyone knows which applications are made, which exports are approved and which are banned. Sometimes you can find out with parliamentary questions - sometimes there are leaks. We want this information to be made available to the public every quarter. That already has an impact on practice. Second: We also want to have responsibility for companies so that they not only stubbornly look what is on the list, but also see for themselves whether our products, for example, restrict freedom of expression. And as the Commissioner just said, this should also be clarified with a manual - guidelines - so that companies' due diligence is going in the right direction. In addition to the list-based approach, according to which long-term products that are subject to special observation are recorded on lists, we also want a catch-all, because especially in the area of information and communication technologies the development is much faster than what we can do with the lists - so here too an improvement.We also want to ensure greater harmonization of practice within the European Union so that it does not matter where you apply.Fifth: It cannot be that letterbox companies, in Dubai for example, circumvent export controls.That is why the legislation also applies to branches and letterbox companies outside the European Union.And indeed, I am also glad that we negotiated for a long time with the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and sometimes postponed the vote in order to develop a common clear signal from this plenary, which I think is good.Because it is absolutely clear: human rights have priority over economic interests.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - There are goods and products that you can use in ordinary civilian industry, but at the same time you can also use them for military purposes. For example, products that can just as well be used for weapons of mass destruction. We see that the European Union is a major producer and also a major exporter of such dual-use goods. It is important that we monitor them strictly. That we put strict permits on the table to tackle abuse. That is important for our international security, for peace, for the protection of human rights. At the same time, there is also our focus on free trade. What is on the table today is an important step forward. What we'll do here is a good thing. It is a modernization of legislation, which will enable us to better tackle new threats and at the same time be able to deal more quickly with new technological developments. I would like to expressly thank the rapporteur, Mr Buchner, for this, who has done an excellent job on this file, so that we will be able to control exporters properly, to monitor them strictly, but not unnecessarily. So a good thing. It is at the same time a compromise. In a compromise there are always points that you don't like. I especially have some questions about a number of points and their practical feasibility. 1. In this proposal for a European regulation, we also provide for an application outside the European Union, the so-called extraterritorial effect. There are doubts as to whether this is practically fully feasible. Also because the European member states do not really have the tools to punish those entities, which means that there seems to be some leeway and rules may be circumvented. The question can be asked whether the previous logic did not also have arguments, logic whereby you give the license to the exporter who lives in the European Union remains.2. As far as practical feasibility is concerned: there will be a new avoidance clause, but on this point too there are questions about sanctions, whereby sanctions will partly remain a national matter.That being said, this is a giant step forward.Again, special congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Buchner, who has worked hard to gain broad support for this report. I am pleased that we are now discussing this report. It is really badly needed. The developments in the field of internet technology are going so fast that we are increasingly lagging behind the facts. There are several European companies that sell technology to countries with a bad reputation for human rights. For example, we know that people were tortured in Bahrain on the basis of text messages they exchanged and overheard with the technology of those European companies. We must prevent that. It is therefore important that there are clear and unambiguous rules that provide guidance for application in practice. It is of the utmost importance that human rights are assessed. Otherwise, this revision doesn't really make sense. I would therefore like to call on my colleagues to support this report so that we have broad support in the trialogue. I also want to call on the Member States to work hard for an ambitious implementation. We're not there yet. And it is very important that we are committed to human rights.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, my green colleague Klaus Buchner, for a very good report, and several others have also said so. It is gratifying that we Greens are also leading the work on this issue to reduce the wrong equipment falling into the hands of the wrong people and regimes. It is, just like with arms exports, that we must adapt to a changed reality. The Arab Spring and everything that has happened since then has shown it very clearly. It is seven years since the Arab Spring started in Tunisia, and although it has gone relatively well in some cases, it does not look the same in all countries where the uprising spread. The problem is that several Member States were involuntarily indirectly involved in the uprising of insurgents. When the activists were chased by the dictators' security services, it was with surveillance equipment from Europe, and that in addition to several countries also holding the dictatorships under their arms both politically and with the sale of weapons. Sweden was no exception. One year before the protests began, we gave permission for the export of sensitive mobile equipment from Ericsson to Iran and Syria. And the same year, the Swedish Minister of Trade was in Libya to sell surveillance equipment to Gaddafi. For the proponents of the Arab Spring, these tightenings come too late, but for future freedom defenders, they can be the difference between life and death. It is extremely positive that we can reach such a broad majority in this House to really ensure that the products we manufacture, and which are good, go to the right people, but certainly not to the wrong ones.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we produce and sell in the world software and hardware capable of spying on anyone and anywhere, capable of controlling phones, reading e-mails, even checking our movements via smartphones. But what is scandalous is that we sell them to dictatorial regimes who use them to track down their opponents, arrest them and kill them. Sometimes these are real illegal exports, but more often some unscrupulous companies take advantage of the gaps in this system, gaps that must be closed. Gaps that leave room for terrorism and the proliferation of criminal groups that have no interest in understanding the ultimate purpose of these tools but only in enriching themselves to the detriment of human rights in those countries that, for some time, have suffered from the insistence of dictatorial governments . Gaps that are represented by viable alternative routes: I am referring to the various Italian companies, reported by Al Jazeera for example, which use countries such as Turkey to divert controls and export to illegally occupied territories. Europe must not only defend the many honest companies that today obviously ask for more flexibility, but must demonstrate that innovation can be exported but, at the same time, also peace and justice. This regulation bears the responsibility.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: - Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and everyone else involved for their good and constructive work on this important and sensitive dossier. It was long overdue for the Commission to make a new proposal after 2006, because of course the techniques have changed and developed a lot during this time. That is why I would like to expressly support the compromise that has been found here - perhaps I should say: the sum of many compromises. I hope that this will give our negotiators in Parliament a strong negotiating mandate. My group supports the reform of the regulation on export controls and stresses the need for modernized export controls that take account of changing political and economic challenges and advancing technical developments. In addition, we support the principle of anchoring the protection of human rights more firmly than before in dual-use export controls. At the same time, however, we have always paid particular attention to the practicality of the regulation. It must contain practical and precise definitions of human rights and control criteria. We not only need vague principles that anyone can interpret, but which can then also create unnecessary bureaucratic hurdles. An essential principle should be that only really critical exports are in focus and thus the export of less risky objects is made easier. There is no question that we are committed to more uniform export controls adapted to the new digital methods, but at the same time not to restrict the progress and export of modern technologies that are used for legitimate and legal purposes. The aim must be to close any remaining control gaps at EU level in a timely manner, particularly in the area of ​​digital surveillance technology. Out For this reason, this report focuses primarily on the export of cyber surveillance technology.In conclusion, I would like to point out that we naturally need modern European rules, but we should also press ahead with our multilateral work.In order to keep up with the rapid advances in technology, it will most likely be necessary to continuously update this guideline at regular intervals.This is an appeal to the Commission.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about two concrete examples of how trade, through good regulation, can promote our values ​​and set standards globally, sustainable development, which we will talk about later, and regulation of trade in goods that could be used by dictatorial regimes to limit the freedom of citizens. As progressives, we have fought since the beginning of the legislature for the European Union to equip itself with this fundamental tool, leaving no dangerous regulatory gaps. In fact, we have always reiterated that our partners, in order to trade with Europe, which is still the largest and richest market on a global level, must accept its conditions. The approval of this new regulation will make us more consistent. We can no longer allow dictators and repressive regimes to use our technology in defiance of human rights and universal values. Once again the European Union will lead the battle for respect for human rights. This reform, in fact, is a cutting-edge tool, the most advanced on a global level. We are proud to have made it so thanks, among others, to the introduction of an all-encompassing clause that will allow the coverage of technologies not yet available, to the greater transparency that the reform will require from Member States, to the establishment of a European list - the largest globally - of risky products and clear provisions on circumvention. In this way, Europe reaffirms that its business model is an open model but anchored to firm inescapable principles. Our work does not stop today. On the contrary, it will intensify: we will have to monitor its implementation to ensure its maximum effectiveness and make sure that no one tries to evade it. We cannot in fact state our values ​​in a passive way, instead we must make sure that our action is concrete and strong.The message we are sending out today is more positive than ever and as Europeans we can only be proud of it.Today's is a victory for everyone.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Mister President!A few days ago the film “Poland before the ordeal” came on television.During the film, our valued colleague Róża Thun was accompanied by a journalist in her constituency.The film portrays problems that the filmmakers are currently facing in opposition in Poland.After the film, critical protesters are arrested, although demonstrations have been registered, and juveniles who invite opposition members are punished.Mr President, if it is reported correctly, you have compared the journalist to a Nazi director, and our colleague Róża Thun was insulted in what I believe was irresponsible.(The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr.Article 162, point 2. Should I read it to you?You are not speaking on the subject, please do not hesitate to speak about the report by Klaus Buchner.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Yes, I'll come to that in a moment, but we also have the right to speak freely, and in the European Parliament we should be able to point out things. Dear Mr President, we all have a bad day and make mistakes. Therefore, my request is simply to apologize to the colleague and the journalist or to draw the conclusions and resign as Vice-President of this House! And now to the subject, in order to comply with your request: We have the situation - and many colleagues have responded to it - that goods and products from the European Union are also used to oppress people. It is good that we are in a situation where the European Commission has proposed an amendment to the existing regulation. We urgently need to face the new technological and unfortunately also political challenges in other countries around the world. And we have to make sure better than before that European products cannot be misused. In this sense, it is good that with this draft law - Mr Buchner has done very good compromise work here - we are not only mentioning our human rights on Sundays, but are also enforcing them in production and sales. Secondly, however, we have improved a number of things where the European Commission may have overshot the mark in the first attempt. We have improved legal certainty for companies. With this in mind, I would like to thank you very much for your proposal, thank you very much for the work in Parliament and I think that we will, in a responsible manner, encourage our companies not to undermine the rule of law in other countries of the world without their knowledge and unwillingly.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you, Mr.The regulations apply to everyone, including you.I recall Art.162 point 2. Please remember this for the future.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, the EU rightly and regularly condemns state intimidation and violence against journalists, dissidents and human rights defenders. Yet, as we have heard in this debate, our Member States and companies continue to provide the very tools that facilitate such harassment to the very governments that undertake such repression. The gap in our dual—use legislation has allowed this to happen. If the Council accepts the excellent text we will adopt tomorrow, exports of dual—use items such as surveillance technologies will no longer be possible where they could be used for human rights violations. In this report, Parliament is sending a strong signal to the Council that the human rights dimension is a priority for us – I hope that it is a message that they will get – as is ensuring uniform implementation of the regulation throughout all of our Member States. It is clear at the moment that all 28 are not committed to the same level of implementation of the existing regulation. I hope that will change with the new regulation.  We also need countries, like France and Italy in particular, to make licensing data publicly available. It is unacceptable to hide behind the shield of privacy in this area. As the departure date, sadly, for the United Kingdom from the EU is approaching, I also hope that the United Kingdom will equip itself with similar rules and keep up its cooperation with the European Union on these matters after it leaves the European Union. Finally, I would like to thank the Commissioner and the Commission for such a good proposal and my colleagues, particularly Mr Buchner, who I think did an excellent job steering this legislation through Parliament.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: - Mr President, my congratulations to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work and to the Commissioner for having taken the initiative to launch this important proposal to modernize the Regulation, which we have improved with the Resolution and with this Parliament's report. I believe that we all agree that the development of ICT and surveillance software, without adequate control, can put our security at risk and, of course, also facilitate repressive regimes to persecute, harass and practice torture against opponents and defenders of human rights. And, of course, European technology cannot allow it to help export and contribute to it. I think it is essential to point out that, with European technology - because there is no adequate regulation to control exports - it may be facilitating the implementation of policies that are endangering our security and, what is more serious or just as serious , which are endangering the lives of human rights defenders, journalists and political opponents who act and work against repressive regimes. That is why it is so important to modernize, improve and tighten this regulation. But we believe that it is important that, throughout the process and at the end of the Regulation, the demands that the Socialists have been making and the text as approved by the International Trade Commission are maintained. It is essential to extend export control to ICT and cyber surveillance, incorporate the human rights dimension, include this general control mechanism to foresee that in the future unforeseen products may be subject to control and ensure uniform implementation in all the states. And, finally, once we get this Regulation, Commissioner, I ask you to try the same thing that you are doing with the Regulation that prevents the trade in instruments that infringe torture or punishment of death, which is its internationalization.They have made a great effort, they have taken a great step forward and, once we have the European Union Regulation, we have to ensure that they also adhere to the same principles in order to truly end this type of practice.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Mr Chairman! Brand new threats keep appearing, which are often difficult to predict. This forces us to constantly change the European security policy, and within this policy we must constantly change the rules governing the control of trade in dual-use goods. The same products and technologies can support the fight against crime, and this is happening fortunately, but also the same products and technologies can be used by criminals and even governments to violate human rights. Therefore, among the proposed changes, I pays particular attention to the new definition of dual-use items. This definition covers new types of products better, in particular, I am thinking of information technology surveillance technologies here. This undoubtedly increases our chances, on the one hand, of fighting criminals, but on the other hand, it should make life very complicated for those governments that want to break human rights and the opposition.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Reform of the dual-use legislation is urgently needed. This involves revising the export regulations for dual-use goods that can be used both civilly and militarily. Above all, Internet and communication technologies must be given greater consideration in export controls. During the Arab Spring it became clear that precisely these technologies were deliberately used by dictatorial regimes against human rights activists and journalists, leading to human rights violations and persecution. The S&D has therefore vehemently advocated a system that is practicable, transparent, future-proof and protects the competitiveness of European industry. European trade must be based on clear values, the core of which is human rights.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, this week we will be voting to strengthen controls on the export of goods, notably cyber surveillance technology, that can be – and has been – used to abuse human rights around the world. This legislation shows how serious Parliament is about trade policy. We take our responsibility to scrutinise policy proposals carefully, but it also shows that we are serious that our rhetoric about values—based trade becomes our practice. Under Tory plans, MPs in Westminster would never have such an opportunity post—Brexit. Parliament’s scrutiny powers under the draft trade bill amount to zilch, with trade rules drawn up entirely behind closed doors. Brexit shouldn’t be used as an excuse to wind back parliamentary scrutiny. MPs should have at least equal rights to those held today by our MEPs.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mister President! New technologies open up the possibility of abusing certain digital services to monitor individuals and groups. Updating European regulation on dual-use goods accordingly would be a political success; it corresponds to a demand from our last election manifesto. It is therefore all the more important that this regulation is completed before the end of the mandate. The European Union must be enabled to act quickly and flexibly in the event of abuse. It cannot be that Made-in-Europe products are used in the event of human rights abuses. After the EU already introduced a ban on the import and export of torture instruments, the export of products that can be misused for espionage is now also being regulated. The next step must be that arms exports are finally legally regulated in a legally binding manner at EU level. This demand is all the more explosive in view of the planned European funding in the arms industry. In the case of arms projects funded by Europe, the European Parliament should be given a say in exports.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have been experiencing an increasing fragility of the international order. The values ​​shared by the Member States of the European Union - democracy, freedom and the rule of law - are at risk in many countries with which we are interconnected, economically and politically, and technological changes affect not only citizens' way of life but also threats to which our society is exposed. In this context, the European Union, as the most powerful trading bloc in the world, cannot shy away from playing a leading role globally in defense of our values. This Parliament has more than once called for measures to be taken to ban the export of surveillance technology to countries with authoritarian regimes and which violate human rights. The proposal under discussion on dual-use items has the merit of providing the European Union not only with an additional instrument to protect human rights globally but also with an effective export control mechanism to defend free and fair trade .

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, control of the dual-use trade is a very important development for the European Union. So I think this debate highlights all the issues that really come to the fore because we have goods that are being used for both political and military use. At the same time, advances in technology have now shown that there are a number of products being used for surveillance, and these products are being exploited by dictatorial regimes to restrict human rights, punish and often arrest activists, journalists and anyone who really opposes these regimes. In addition, it is important that exports of torture materials be banned. I also consider it important that imports of minerals from war-torn areas in Africa are banned, because there is essentially a purge of the population in order for some to grab the minerals. These minerals are then imported into the European Union. I think all these bans are very important.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the great advancement of technology unfortunately allows trade in materials and instruments that can be used for a dual purpose: one legal and one illegal. Such materials are surveillance materials, encryption materials, electronic interception and deception systems, materials and products that enhance the possibility of cyber attacks, as well as materials for the manufacture of weapons of mass destruction, but also means that can be used to carry out torture. The European Union is based on principles and values, and this reality obliges it not to place economic gain above morality and human rights. It must carry out effective controls so that these products do not fall into the hands of terrorists, nor are they channeled to countries that violate the human rights of their citizens. Finally, it must enact strict legislation that will punish violators of these provisions. For all these reasons, I think we need to support the report by my colleague, Mr Buchner.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, everybody here in this room agrees that it is high time that we update the current legislation when it comes to export control of products that could have dual uses. This is what our citizens expect from us, namely that we take human rights very seriously in this kind of trade. Companies are also expecting guidelines from us that are user-friendly, up—to—date and modern. This is what we are trying to do here. We are trying to things easier – and I think Mr Fjellner brought this up – for the vast majority of companies who want to work with us and to do a good job here in reducing costs and enhance competitiveness, while, at the same time, responding to legislation and citizens’ concerns. We are introducing a new EU general export authorisation, simplifying controls on intra-EU transfer on sensitive products and technologies, we are developing an electronic licensing system in Member States and we are facilitating technology transfers. All this will reduce the burden of controls for the companies and also make procedures more user-friendly. It is indeed high time that we adapt to changing technologies and emerging security threats, and this is what we are trying to do with this. I am happy to see that there is such a great consensus in this House – maybe the Christmas spirit is still looming – but I think it is mostly thanks to the rapporteur and his work that we have such strong support for this report. It will definitely facilitate discussions with the next institution, and hopefully we will have flexible legislation that is able to adjust to technologies and security. It will have a robust human security dimension, more harmonised transparency arrangements and also a system that builds on this important partnership with industry and civil society. I think we obviously still have some issues to solve in the future legislative work here, but this is definitely a very important step forward. Thank you again to the Committee on International Trade for the work you have done. I am looking forward to working with you in the coming months.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! The speeches showed that the European Parliament and the Commission are ready to practice a value-based trade policy for dual-use goods. I would just like to comment very briefly on the comment made by Mr Loones, who is unfortunately no longer here, but I believe that the problem that he raised concerns more colleagues in this House. The point is how to prevent such a dangerous product from being transferred within a company to a branch that is outside the EU and can therefore no longer be controlled. No general theoretical answer can be given here, but recent practice has shown that we can pursue such originals. We can follow the path how it finally comes to the regime where we want to prevent its use. We have seen this in the examples in Bahrain, Iran and many other countries - so it is possible if you investigate it, and the advantage of this article in our regulation is that we can then really punish the company in question, what was just not possible before. I appeal to the Council and, above all, to the Bulgarian and then to the Austrian Council Presidency as well as to all Member States to formulate their opinions as quickly as possible so that we can start the trialogue negotiations as soon as possible. We are ready, now it is the Council's turn. Finally, I would like to once again thank the Commission and all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation. It's not just being said, we all come from very different areas. That there was a willingness to compromise, that in the end almost all of us agreed to this paper, I would like to thank you very much again and hope that this agreement will continue tomorrow in the vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 January 2018.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on an oral question to the Commission by Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on trade and sustainable development chapters in EU trade agreements (O-000098/2017 - B8-0617 / 2017) (2017/2988 (RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner! Trade brings advantages - I think that is more or less undisputed. However, that does not mean that the benefits of trading will reach everyone. Sometimes they don't go down well with those who produce the values ​​for retailers. And that is why it is eminently important that fundamental workers' rights such as freedom of association and the formation of trade unions are secured so that those who produce the values ​​can also use the advantages and not only multilateral companies benefit. And there is also an aspect of competition. It cannot be that trade allows unfair competitive advantages through environmental and social dumping. Both considerations lead to the fact that we incorporate rules for the protection of fundamental labor rights and environmental standards into our trade agreements. The key question is, of course, how do we build them so that they are really effective? We have already made approaches in the past. I only want to remind you of the agreement with Korea, where we have indeed integrated a sustainability chapter, with, for example, domestic advisory groups - made up of three thirds of companies, employees and NGOs - accompanying the process. However, it has been found that the possibilities for action are very limited. There are no proper rules of procedure, naming it is not as easy as we imagined, and there is no provision for domestic advisory groups to take legal action. That led us to say: We need improvements. And in the course of the discussions about the agreement with Canada, the CETA agreement, we called for precisely these improvements and now also have a revision clause in the CETA agreement on the modernization and enforceability of workers' rights and environmental standards. So it is important right here to start how we can make improvements. Some time ago the Commission launched what is known as a non-paper, which actually contains two options. One option is: we will basically continue as before. And the other option is: We look at the US model, sanctions in the area of ​​trade agreements, if there are violations of workers' rights or environmental standards in connection with trade flows. I think this model cannot be ours. That is not manageable and actually does not address the needs. The question is: Isn't there a third or a fourth between these two models, where it is clear that enforceability is shaped by other mechanisms and that compensation for victims of violations of labor rights and environmental standards can also be built in? I myself tried, together with the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, to propose a third model that brings a clear three-stage regulation in motion, domestic advisory groups with reasonable rights, a panel of experts who can and can make binding judgments for both partners then an enforcement mechanism if this judgment of the panel of experts is not accepted. So the question is whether there are other models to discuss besides the two proposed models and how the process can be approached. This question is hidden behind the question for an oral answer, but also the question of how we should proceed with CETA. We said that after the provisional application, we want to start the negotiations in order to reform and further develop the processes, i.e. to take the revision seriously. And the question also arises: If we do not have a further developed model, shouldn't such revision clauses also be found in other trade agreements? Otherwise it will be difficult to convey why we act like this with one and differently with the other.And of course the question arises of how the public - business and trade unions - are actually involved in the process.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as the previous debate illustrated – and it’s basically the same audience and contributors here – I think we are all very committed to having a strong value-based trade policy, and that is why we are committed, in the Commission, to having and promoting labour policies, labour rights and environmental standards in all our policies, including trade policy. We have trade and sustainable development chapters in all our trade and investment agreements, and they are a key tool in promoting that – not the only tool, but a very important one that allows us to work with our partners and ensure a level playing field for our workers and enterprises. That is why, as Mr Lange said, we submitted it to the European Parliament, the Council and others. We wanted to talk about this and how we could increase the effective implementation of these chapters to make sure that they are even stronger. We proposed this paper outlining progress up until today, as well as putting forward two real-life examples of existing approaches and asking questions. This is not a proposal setting out only these two options; these are the two of which we are aware, but there could be others as well. That is why we wanted to have this debate, and we don’t want to limit the discussion in any way, so we welcome feedback and proposals. The fundamental question that needs to be posed is: what is working, what is not working, and what tools do we need to better implement the chapters? Trade policy is only one important factor, but it is not the only tool to improve the situation in other countries. There are synergies with development policies, for instance, and that has been acknowledged in the recently updated EU Aid for Trade strategy. We are still receiving inputs on this. Countries, organisations, Member States and parliaments have told us that they are still working on their proposals, but thus far there is broad support for a more affected and more assertive implementation of the trade and sustainable development chapters, and there are specific areas for improvement which have been proposed. There is a need for increased transparency; increased communication on developments in trade and sustainable development-related proceedings; in dispute settlement; the strengthening of civil society organisations when it comes to monitoring; the effective implementation of the existing provisions; and more assertive enforcement and stepping up of pre-implementation efforts in order to increase awareness in our partner countries and tackle non-compliance issues. These are a few suggestions that are important and that have been given to us. There has been no suggestion that the broad scope of the TSD chapters will be abandoned. The discussion has not been concluded yet, but there is nothing that indicates a consensus emerging on a policy shift towards introducing trade sanctions. The key issue here is that sanctions are supposed to counterbalance specific trade costs, demonstrating that the trade costs of a country not respecting certain basic social and environmental standards has concrete effects on trade. With regard to civil society, it is indeed a very important ally in ensuring that labour and environmental standards are promoted. Civil society is also an important partner that is able to alert us when there are things are not going well in a country. Therefore, we are considering increasing the organisational capacity of civil society structures, improving their interaction with government bodies under the trade agreements, and stepping up the pre-implementation efforts to increase awareness in our partner countries and tackle non-compliance. This includes the handling of comments and information from civil society. All stakeholders have the possibility to submit views and to advise the parties through the civil society mechanism, but this process could be clearer. As regards the potential impact assessment or public consultation, the final results will have to determine that. It is a little early to say whether such a process would be warranted. In any event there will be several opportunities, in addition to the current one, for the regular assessment of the effectiveness of the approach chosen through the annual implementation reports and exports to impact assessment. So, discussions are still ongoing. We welcome the input that has arrived so far and those who have indicated that they would be coming. We are looking forward to continue discussing these issues with Members of the European Parliament.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the European Union is a champion in promoting global free trade and the multilateral rules—based trading system. At the same time, it needs to remain a key advocate for fairer trade. The benefits of globalisation do indeed have to reach all citizens and all communities. The EU needs to strive for an effective application of sustainable trade clauses included in our free trade agreements (FTAs), and our citizens expect us to turn theory into practice in line with the EU Agenda for Jobs and Growth.  The provisions of existing trade and sustainable development (TSD) chapters already include a comprehensive set of binding provisions. These are based on multilateral norms, respecting the relevant ILO conventions and multilateral and environmental agreements. I strongly believe that the EU can make a difference in the essential fields of labour rights and environmental protection, amongst others, and also through its TSD chapters in our FTAs. The Committee on International Trade (INTA) has a strong preoccupation with the potential avenues to improve the current affairs in TSD chapters’ implementation, and so do the EPP members in INTA. In—depth analysis and thorough debate have already been dedicated to the possible ways forward.  In conclusion to all that work, I can share the EPP Group’s view that we see sanctions as a last—resort mechanism and would appreciate turning towards more effective ways to deal with the problem at hand. Trade agreements can serve as a good tool for economic diplomacy. However, a sanction—based mechanism, by its punitive character, could possibly destabilise the relationship with our trade partners and backfire in various counter—demands. The experience gathered so far at the global level shows that trade—related sanctions fall short of delivering the desired results. On the contrary, these have often worked to the detriment of those that have introduced them, and concomitantly to the disadvantage of the less privileged partner. We do not see conclusive evidence that sanctions could lead to an improvement of the effectiveness and the implementation of the TSD chapters. The EPP relies on the efficiency of dialogue with our partners, and with all the stakeholders, and cooperation with international organisations, as currently stated in the existing TSD provisions. The way forward is to consolidate these chapters and to strive for the more effective and sustainable implementation of this important pillar in our value—based trade policy. Some of the concrete proposals have just been stated and highlighted by Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, and the EPP strongly supports these suggestions.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the growing protectionism we are experiencing at a global level paradoxically creates a great opportunity for the European Union. Our third way to trade can finally establish itself as the global "golden standard". All the major players in international trade look to us, from Japan to the Mercosur countries, via Australia and New Zealand: all our partners are asking us to establish even stronger relationships. From this point of view, we welcomed the Commission's initiative to launch a process of reviewing the most suitable instruments to achieve this result. We have already succeeded, in some cases in an innovative way, in including binding compliance with more ambitious environmental and social standards in our internal regulations. It is important, at this point, to continue on this path and identify a model that can be applied in all our present and future negotiations. We therefore ask the Commission to take steps forward in considering approaches that introduce more binding mechanisms in an innovative way, also through a gradual sanctioning system, not necessarily a Copernican revolution, or through specific incentives that are combined with greater efficiency in the resources dedicated to monitoring. I am pleased that in your words, Commissioner, you mentioned monitoring because the subject of monitoring actually still represents a problem, because it is often difficult to identify the most suitable subjects to conduct the process in those countries where there is no civil society. with sufficient tools to operate in this sense. In the same way, specific revision paths of existing agreements will have to be envisaged on the basis of an ever greater capacity to carry out broad and detailed impact assessments. We do not ask to renounce cooperation and dialogue with our partners, on the contrary we ask not to waste the chance that Europe has to promote human, social and environmental rights with ever greater force and on an ever wider scale.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Lange that although we usually agree in the Committee on International Trade on many things, this will not be one of them: EU trade agreements should not be extended that far beyond the scope of what we can call ‘trade policy instruments’. I have the feeling that what we can see here is a clear tendency to call for sanctions in trade agreements we are negotiating with third countries, and we in the ECR Group oppose that approach. We worry that applying sanctions would have a counterproductive effect on how much our partners would be willing to commit in the scope of the TSD chapters. Again, there are definitely limits to which we can use trade policy for some achievements in the field of human rights or environmental protection.  There is no doubt that TSD chapters must be better implemented, but there are other instruments, other options, that need to be further explored. First of all, an introduction of measurable targets defining clear procedures on how to deal with complaints and how to launch government consultations. Thirdly, to recognise that each trade partnership is a different one and that civil society takes different forms in different trade partners. Last, but not least, we should also make better use of our own resources – our delegations, chambers of commerce contacts, Member States’ embassies and all diplomatic channels. We have to use our EU soft power through the instrument of TSD chapters, and the only way I see that this can be achieved through trade policy is on the basis of cooperation and continuous dialogue. We have to treat our trading parties as partners and not threaten them with sanctions.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Lange for introducing the debate and the Commissioner for framing a really real issue. Indeed, this evening's debate brings us back to fundamental questions relating to international trade and human development. Trade is a means, while human development is an end. Logically, everything should be done to achieve the ultimate goal of sustainable development. It is about health, education, access to drinking water in developing countries, in particular. However, we see that the rules governing international trade are well codified; they are generally respected because in the event of non-compliance, they allow the aggrieved party to refer the dispute to the WTO dispute settlement body, which is empowered to apply the sanctions in the defaulting country. This is not the case when it comes to achieving the goals for sustainable development. Admittedly, the United Nations has indeed adopted a resolution to this effect, but in the event of non-achievement of the SDGs, no sanction is foreseen. The process to be put in place to remedy this major gap in global governance is long overdue and will have to be remedied. It is not because the task is difficult, because it seems impossible to do it, that we must fold our arms and wait for Godot, because Godot will not come, as Václav Havel said, because Godot does not does not exist. But the Union does exist. Yes, the European Union should step up initiatives to ensure that the objectives for sustainable development come with a real obligation of result. The European Union must act on two levels. First, at the level of global governance, by trying to convince its G7 and G20 partners, as well as its partners at the WTO, that environmental and social standards are not only essential, but above all in the interest of all countries and of all citizens of those countries.A second avenue to explore is to include in these bilateral agreements, with all third countries, accompanying measures in the neighborhood policy, in its development policy, in its trade agreements, with a view to achieving these objectives.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, it is no longer a secret: the fever of signing trade and investment treaties at all costs will have — and already has — dire consequences for many people and for the Earth. In the first place, I am glad that no one doubts that each of these treaties has to be accompanied by a chapter on sustainable development. However, the agreements that the Commission continues to propose to us and for which part of the Members continue to vote in favor only include very vague commitments: they are dead paper. And some of you will say no, that the labor and environmental clauses of the new treaties are binding. I remind you that yes, they can be called binding, but they do not have any sanction mechanism or anything to ensure compliance. And this is called wet paper. Do we believe in the "Trade for All" discourse? Well, enough that the sustainable development chapter of the treaties is a mere decorative appendix! We need these chapters to be really executable; that they can be reported and that, if they are violated, there are consequences; that are aimed at punishing violations of rights themselves, and not their impact on trade. This means that we need to review the mandates. In closing, let us be aware of the enormous power that the European Union has to shape global trade. We are going to compete, but on the upside, not on the downside. And let's put, at once, human rights at the center.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, trade and sustainable development chapters in our trade agreements are relatively new, but we already have some experience from agreements with Korea, Colombia and Peru. This is indeed a good moment to take stock of those experiences and it is commendable that you, Madam Commissioner, have opened a discussion on this topic and that you are open to input on various options.  Obviously trade agreements are not done in a vacuum, but they should be in line with other – may I even dare to say – more important policies, but please don’t take me wrong. The UN’s Agenda 2030 which Mr Goerens mentioned is the overall framework that needs to guide our trade policy, as well as other EU policies. Primacy of human rights, social rights, as well as climate agreements, environmental questions, should be the norm in EU trade agreements, and the sustainable development chapters are definitely a great addition, but I believe that without legal enforcement, they lack teeth and here I disagree with EPP and ECR speakers who seem to be talking about a more kind of soft way.  We do have mechanisms in trade policy. We have the GSP+. It does have the possibility to waive the benefits that we have given to our trade partners if things go the other way and against EU values, so I think it is only normal that when we talk about legal enforcement there will be some consequences. It could also be incentives when things go well in terms of social protection and environmental norms.  I believe that we can no longer afford to continue putting environmental and social considerations into a second class category. Environmental and social obligations need to be on an equal footing with commercial interests. There needs to be a balance of interests.  Finally, when we include binding and enforceable obligations in our trade agreements, these obligations obviously go both ways. The EU must also be accountable for its actions, and this is the core idea of the Agenda 2030, the sustainable development goals, which are universal. We must be ready to demand the same from ourselves as we demand from our trade partners.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the chapter on sustainable development in trade agreements remains the only tool we have for raising and addressing some concerns. The Commission has begun a process of reform which will certainly serve to ensure greater compliance with employment standards, but I believe there is a lack of a similar commitment on environmental issues. The current proposals on the table seem rather vague, for example there is no clear "dispute settlement" system based on real sanctions. Without a mandatory and independent system, where stakeholders, trade unions, civil society, consumers and human rights defenders are able to lodge their complaints, any attempt to link sustainable development to trade will remain a futile effort. In the past, the United States has already used, albeit with problems, a sanction system in trade agreements. I believe that it is necessary to start from an idea like that, creating a new and satisfactory instrument which, however, provides for sanctions, such as the application of economic duties where such shortcomings occur. What we need today is not a relationship full of good intentions, which is typical of modern election campaigns, but more courage and more vision.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would of course like to thank Mr Bernd Lange here for submitting these questions to the European Commission. However, I am quite upset, surprised by their wording and by the lack of correspondence between the wishful thinking expressed and the reality of European Union trade policy. The European Union is said to be committed to respecting human rights, workers' rights and environmental standards in its trade policy. But it does not hesitate to engage in trade relations with countries that do not respect labor laws, nor the standards set by the World Labor Organization. The Union does not hesitate to engage with countries which exploit children, men and women crammed into rabbit cages, with the sole aim of producing more with maximum profit. Have we not seen here the repeated and desperate attempts by the European Commission to grant market economy status to China? Brussels tells us again that trade policy must promote sustainable development in trade agreements; It is a very nice initiative that is by no means respected. The free trade agreements with Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the Mercosur countries, which she so ardently defends, are not compatible with the notion of sustainable development. Hormone-boosted beef, bleached chicken, cloning meat or GMOs that will fill our plates tomorrow will have first toured the world, with the resulting carbon footprint. In France, a committee of experts appointed by Mr. Macron ruled on the risks of CETA, pointed out its shortcomings and deemed it incompatible with the Paris agreements, and the fact that the President of the French Republic or finally sitting on it does not detract from the seriousness of this study. God laughs at men who deplore effects whose causes they cherish, but that does not make our fellow citizens laugh, who demand consistency and clarity, my dear colleagues.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, safeguarding human rights and workers’ rights, but also environmental standards, is one of the biggest commitments here in the European Union. Even though it is sometimes challenging for European companies to respect such provisions, we continue to improve them and we are proud to set an example in the global world. At the same time, we also expect that our international partners follow the same standards. That includes trade. I therefore welcome the Commission’s initiative to improve and ensure more coherent, ambitious and effective trade and the sustainable development chapter in the future free trade agreements. However, the question is how to stay competitive whilst promoting such a high level of environmental and social standards.  Trade policy is closely linked to sustainability: trade is a means to promote not only economic growth, but also norms and values that will help to address today’s complex global value chains, achieving a level playing field whilst promoting social inclusion and environmental protection. European companies for many years now have been committed to delivering such sustainable solutions, both in the EU and abroad. Nonetheless, free trade agreements are not – and should not be – a way to promote the EU’s social environmental standards. Trade agreements must first and foremost focus on enhancing trade and maintaining the international competitiveness of European companies. We should therefore not make the beginning of negotiations or entry into force of the EU free trade agreements conditional on the ratification of international conventions and treaties. I think we should promote such issues during the negotiations, but we should definitely not limit ourselves at the beginning of such talks.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Bernd Lange for raising this very important issue and also to thank the Commissioner for the answer. Saying that trade is part of our policy and the values that we have in Europe on sustainability, human rights, labour rights and the environment are fundamental to us. I will have to disagree with my colleagues from the PPE who spoke earlier. This is a very important debate and what we have neglected in the past is that the trade-related rules we have introduced haven’t respected the fundamental rights of workers or the environment. We have put a lot of effort into ensuring the rights of investors. We have discussed investor- state disputes and mechanisms for dispute settlement, but what about the right of workers to organise themselves for collective bargaining? These rights are even denied by European companies in countries where we trade, so we need to have not only a value-based trade order, but also a value- and rule—based trade order; and with rules that can be enforced by sanctions if they are neglected by our partners. Therefore, it is important to link trade with sustainability and, I would say, with behaviour on how the rules work in globalisation. The Commission produced a very good paper on harnessing globalisation last year and one of its aims was to empower the EU to harness globalisation to benefit people. What we are unfortunately seeing today are rising inequalities and, if we want to fight that, we need a rule—based trade order in which rules on workers, the environment and human rights are at the core. These rules must be implemented. If not, then we should punish our partners.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, ladies and gentlemen! Do you know Thomas Mann? In his novel “Die Buddenbrooks” he lets the protagonist say: “My son, enjoy doing business during the day, but only do things so that we can sleep peacefully at night.” That is exactly what I want Europe and the Commission to do Writing the trade agreement script. The EU has concluded over 70 free trade agreements in the last few decades and, of course, it was always about business during the day. But the reaction of the citizens shows us: Many can no longer sleep at night. Time for a new culture of fair trade, time to give human rights, environmental standards and social standards the importance that fair trade deserves. Let's stop preaching water and stop drinking wine. Fair trade doesn't need Sunday sermons; fair trade needs action. And who else but one of the two largest economic powers in the world should strive for that? Who else but us? My question is therefore also: Are you, are we ready for honest fair trade? Are we ready, as Europeans, to put ourselves at the forefront of a world trade reform, sustainable world trade, the central message of which is: people at the center?

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: - Many beautiful words are spoken here, but the elephant in the room is that all beautiful rules are on the one hand not deductible and on the other hand are undermined by the arbitration paragraph.Ms Malmström, you have an obligation to ensure that companies not only have rights, but also obligations, and that they honor them.The UN Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights commits states to include human rights in their trade policies.And while the OECD guidelines for multinationals are not binding, you can include them explicitly in free trade and investment agreements.Companies can then only rely on investment protection if they comply with the OECD guidelines.The European Commission listens very carefully to the wishes of companies and we know that investment protection is given every opportunity.How will you ensure that they move within the boundaries of the UN and the OECD?

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I do not know whether we will ever be able to really anchor the necessary standards in the sustainability chapters of our free trade agreements in such a way that they will also take effect as long as the rest of our free trade agreements follow a different philosophy. Sustainability chapters are not a patch that can be stuck on if sustainability is not the general yardstick of an entire trade agreement. Second: Mr Tusk once said in connection with the CETA debate: EU trade agreements should be designed in such a way that the interests of consumers, companies and employees are equally taken into account. We all know many examples in which this has not been the case. But if we want to do justice to Mr Tusk's standard, which I think is good, then we cannot say that in one case where the rights of companies are at stake we want to create special instruments to safeguard their claims, but When it comes to the rights of employees, the brackets put in front of them are that there must be no sanctions. If I do not include an enforcement mechanism, then in my opinion the promise of equal consideration cannot be realized, and it is not about always practicing these sanctions. There is the beautiful sentence of the former chess grandmaster Nimzowitsch, who once said: The threat is stronger than the execution. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Bütikofer.I know my hammer, too, is a threat that is better than execution.But in this case we just have to pay a little attention to speaking time.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – Mr President, I salute the Commissioner’s initiative on promoting a sustainable trade approach. As we already know from previous successful experience, a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is the perfect entry door for many other policies, programmes and areas of EU interest, such as human and workers’ rights or environmental issues. The Gulf area is a top priority for the EU as well. Related to this area, the EU has many more topics on its agenda than just trade: defence and security cooperation, the fight against terrorism and regional cooperation for the support and stabilisation of surrounding regions, especially the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa. All of these are high priorities on the EU’s agenda. Unfortunately, the EU-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) negotiations for an FTA have been suspended since 2008. In line with the current debate on ways to improve EU trade agreements, I would like the Commission to consider the possibility of a country-by-country approach in the Gulf area. The EU has already signed successful FTAs with many third countries. I do not see why we cannot have a similar approach in relations with GCC members. The Commission must know already that several GCC countries are open to a bilateral FTA with the EU. We all know Oman as a successful, stable country – a role model for the whole region. We also notice the remarkable progress made by Qatar in its legislation on the protection of workers’ right and labour conditions – changes that have already been noticed by both the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the United Nations. These two countries can represent a good start for a new approach in FTA negotiations to be considered by the Commission for this region. Such proceedings have the potential to unlock the process for the whole GCC. We can even use the experience from a different area of policy, namely the visa regime. A liberalisation in EU relations with the United Arab Emirates (UAE) was followed by a clear increase in trade between the parties and improvements, at the same time, of the human rights situation in the UAE. Therefore, visa liberalisation can also go hand-in-hand with negotiations for Free Trade Agreements with these countries and others in the region.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, trade in general – and FTAs in particular – cannot solve all the ills of the world; I fully accept that. But I strongly believe it is incumbent on those of us who are in favour of removing barriers to trade to ensure that this does not undermine human rights, labour, environmental or animal welfare standards. We have tried the light—touch approach to trade with sustainable development, but it is clear that our existing TSD model is not fit for purpose.  Commissioner, I welcome the fact that you are open to a review of the TSD chapter, and a clear example that our TSD model needs to be reformed is the Korean FTA. Great in terms of economic benefit, but has completely failed in terms of reforming or even protecting existing labour standards in Korea. After a labour leader was jailed in Korea, we were unable to take any action, and any pressure we attempted to put on Korea was completely futile. We also have panels of experts in relation to some of our key TSD chapters. How often have their reports been acted upon? As far as I can work out, on zero occasions.  A more strongly and easily enforceable TSD would make it not only fairer in terms of the FTAs we adopt and implement with the rest of the world, but would actually help gain political support and wider support among the general public for our free trade agenda.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, during globalization, the major multinationals of the European Union and the United States have shifted their investments to countries mainly in Asia. It is the well-known "outsourcing". They invested there because they believed, and indeed it did, that they would make super profits.
