They made huge profits because in these countries labor law is not complied with in the first place, trade unionism is not allowed and there are starvation wages. At the same time, these countries do not meet other obligations such as health and safety conditions. We have seen countless accidents at work in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. So this is the reality that the West has been led to in order for its companies to make super profits. At the same time, there is a social dumping against this process. Also the environmental agreements are not observed. There are other countries where even prisoners work, such as China. So this is the trade process that is taking place today because European companies are importing all these cheap products into the European Union itself. In addition, the European Union cooperates with countries that do not respect human rights. We have the agreement between the European Union and the countries of Southern Africa, where rights are not respected. Nevertheless, they are allowed to export to Europe commercial products, agricultural products and even feta - we will soon have "south-african feta" - thus dissolving the agricultural production of the European Union itself. It is not possible for these procedures to proceed. Very specific measures are needed and of course there can be no sustainable development with TTIP, with CETA, with all these trade agreements that are dissolving the rural economy of the European South.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sustainable development in trade policies means, above all, protection of the environment and defense of human and social rights. In the lexicon of international trade, however, these are referred to as "non-tariff barriers", an expression that too often contains a clear political indication, which translates into the primacy of the right to profit over civil, social and human rights. Women's rights are human rights and the gender perspective should be transversal to any political issue, the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals also remind us of this, but we know that it is feminist politics that first appointed the instance of subjects that male history has carefully silenced for a very long time. With Malin Björk and as a member of the INTE commission and the FEMM commission, I am rapporteur for a joint report on gender equality in EU trade agreements. I remember that we should talk about trade treaties starting from the fight against gender discrimination, from the defense of labor and environmental rights and not despite them.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: - Mister President!Our trade agreements with developing countries have a number of dire consequences.They are forcing countries in Africa to let our highly subsidized food into the country without restrictions.In doing so, they destroy their own food production.Many farmers have no choice but to either sell their land or give up their previous production and grow coffee, cocoa, tropical fruits and the like for Europe and the USA.The companies that buy up these products form a cartel and push prices down in such a way that the farmers can no longer live on it with dignity.The free trade agreements also enable land grabbing.The same applies to industry: protective tariffs are necessary in order to build up your own industry with little capital.In short: trade agreements are not meant here, but free trade agreements only make sense between similarly developed partners.Our trade policy creates causes of flight.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, if I may mention at the outset, as this is a debate about trade and globalisation, that last week Peter Sutherland, a former Commissioner – and indeed a man who has been dubbed the father of globalisation – passed away and was buried in his home country of Ireland. He was European and Irish, but very much a man who believed in the power of trade to free people from poverty and destitution. I think it is important to name him in this House, because I think we believe that too. He also, in his latter years, did a huge amount of work to help refugees, because he believed in humanity and the dignity of every human person. Maybe in that context we should frame this debate about trade and sustainable development. We should also be quite anxious that Europe is perhaps needing to lead on this, because the WTO is not functioning as you and I would like it to. Maybe the Commissioner could allude to that and why this debate is so important. The issues of human rights, workers’ rights and environmental standards are something we hold dear here in Europe, and we fight for better standards all the time. We want to think that, when it comes to trade, those who we make arrangements and agreements with also strive to reach those standards. The question is how we translate aspirations into reality: how we monitor, how we control and how we use that term ‘sanction’ not in the way it is framed in this question, but how we actually get countries to react and respond to our concerns. One of our colleagues here mentioned the protection of producers. In that context, I want to talk about the producers I represent on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. There is a real dilemma here for us in the European Parliament, because agriculture is always an issue when it comes to trade agreements and our concerns for producers and the food supply system that we have here in Europe. To some extent, we have concerns not just on the environment, human rights and workers’ rights, but around animal welfare standards and food safety standards. So this issue is quite broad and it needs careful reflection. The trouble, I fear, is that people will turn away from globalisation, and that the values and the merits it brought that Peter Sutherland believed in with great passion will be lost to future generations if we do not get this right.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, while the reflection document presented by the Commission for the chapter on “sustainable development” was supposed to be a neutral document, the option that you have clearly chosen is to continue in an inefficient model, which you want to improve, but still ineffective. However, a combination of the two approaches, that is to say the reinforcement of the dialogue accompanied by sanctions, is a perfectly reconcilable proposal and above all, desirable. In addition, the debates that we had within the framework of CETA, in which you undertook to re-examine the “sustainable development” chapter, clearly show that this chapter, as provided for in current trade agreements, does not meet expectations. that we have in terms of respect for social and environmental rights. The European Parliament has, moreover, on several occasions called on the Commission to move in this direction, that is to say to provide for sanction mechanisms. As part of the opinion it delivered on Singapore, the European Court of Justice also indicated that the “sustainable development” chapter aims to govern trade between the Union and its partners by making liberalization conditional on of these on the condition that the parties respect their international obligations in terms of social protection, workers and the environment. She further added that a party is authorized to end the liberalization of such trade or to suspend it in the event of a violation by one of the parties of the provisions on social protection, workers and the environment. The credibility of the European Commission is therefore at stake, which is seriously committed to this policy in favor of sustainable development. If we want to convince of our responsibility in this matter ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! When building the European Union, we developed the obligation that the creation of common markets also requires regulation of environmental protection, health and working conditions here in the internal market, and we know what the reality is like. The new trade agreements go very far in questions of the regulation of trade and investments and provide for specific sanctions in the event of violations. In environmental and social protection, they remain toothless. The instruments are missing to enforce legally binding compliance with the obligations - examples: Colombia, Ukraine, Moldova, the EPAs. The development of global production and value chains and investments require new regulatory frameworks that can implement the goals of sustainable development clearly defined in the 2030 Agenda. And one proposal for this would be, for example, that a catalog of central environmental, consumer and worker protection norms be anchored in a binding manner for all trade agreements, which must also be subject to the general dispute settlement mechanism.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s Trade for All strategy calls for a trade agenda consistent with European values of high social and environmental standards and respect for human rights. How can these standards be guaranteed when there are no enforceable mechanisms to support them? As businesses seek to underpin corporate privilege through a multilateral investment court, civil society organisations must have a real input into both binding but truly enforceable chapters within trade agreements. This is also the ambition of the UN-backed Binding Treaty on business and human rights.  I urge the Commission to strengthen the sustainability criteria and civil society participation in existing and future trade agreements and to support the Binding Treaty initiative. This will put the EU on the right side of history in terms of human rights, social standards and environmental protection in our trade agreements. Citizens are waking up to the real human and environmental implications of trade, and we need the EU to uphold the highest standards in global supply chains and value chains.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Not least at the insistence of the S&D group, the EU has anchored sustainability chapters in several trade agreements. That’s a good thing. In the end, however, the decisive factor is whether the agreements are also brought to life, and we have some shortcomings there. In this context I would just like to suggest three things: I think it is crucial to improve the monitoring processes. Above all, it is important to involve civil society in its entirety - this is crucial - and to involve it as early as possible. It is also important to ensure that civil society has sufficient resources. Incidentally, this is not only a task for the countries in which the civil societies are located, but it must be ensured that these resources are available, for example to be able to prepare or commission scientific expertise. A second thing is, if one has identified violations, to be able to react appropriately and to react in stages. In this context I would like to encourage you to think about the extent to which sanctions against our own European companies can be useful. Because with all the violations of labor law in Bangladesh, nobody can tell me that the European retail chains did not know this before thousands of people were burned there. So there are also ways to think about sanctions. And finally the third suggestion: we don't always have to just talk about sanctions, but also about help and support when sustainability chapters are adhered to. That is also very useful with some of our trading partners. And often it is better to act through incentives than sanctions.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: - Mr President! The issue of fair and environmentally friendly trade is a matter of destiny. But the EU's trade agreement shifts power from democratically elected governments to big business. It is good that the Commission is now talking more about human rights and sustainability in trade policy, but so far it has mostly involved dialogue meetings and no binding rules. The parts of the agreements that are to protect large companies, on the other hand, are binding, for example the possibility for companies to sue countries that introduce rules to protect the environment and consumers. Now you want to further cement that system through a multilateral investment court. Is it really good for the environment? What the world needs now is no more power for big business, but rules to protect the environment and workers that really work. It is time for us to introduce binding rules in trade agreements for the environment and for the protection of workers, and for us to vigorously support the work of the United Nations for an agreement that makes large companies respect human rights.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, there has been a marked change in the Commission’s language around trade policy, with increased recognition that globalisation may have negative, as well as positive, impacts on European industry workers in some regions. Trade deals set the rules of engagement, and therefore good standard—setting and civil society participation is crucial to ensure a balanced and fair environment for workers, consumers and companies. Our sustainable development chapters are therefore absolutely central and of vital importance. I recognise that we learn by doing, but what we are learning from our current sustainable development chapters is that they are inadequate to address labour violations and environmental degradation in our relations with our trading partners.  The EU’s approach of coaxing our trading partners to improve standards is inadequate, and we are regularly told that the only alternative is the US system of trade sanctions, which has its own flaws. But there are other alternatives. Since 2014, when I was elected to this House, there have been three comprehensive reports from this House outlining an alternative – dare I say a third way? The European Parliament report on the mandates for Australia and New Zealand show that there is cross—party consensus on the need for a stronger, more assertive and effective model chapter. EU negotiators should heed the message that we have been sending and come forward with clear, strong recommendations for coaxing and sanctions.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - Trade agreements are the most important form of development aid.By being honest and true to our principles, we cannot allow goods and services that are produced without a responsible approach to the environment to enter the European market.Palm oil grown in place of tropical forests or electricity produced by nuclear power plants that do not meet international standards are just some of the many examples that we Europeans cannot import.The European Union must demand that trade agreements with third countries commit the latter both to human rights and to the implementation of production standards, and to contributing to global goals such as climate change mitigation.We must not only demand but also exercise real control over the implementation of such commitments, and we often lack this.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I appreciate very positively that the Commission has launched this debate, that we are having this debate here in Parliament today. I think it is essential that we get a sustainable development chapter that has the appropriate content and that guarantees its implementation. And for it to have the appropriate content, I believe that something that most of us agree on is essential, which is the incorporation of more representatives of civil society from the beginning: in the negotiation, in the follow-up and, of course, it is also fundamental, in the evaluation of the commitments and in the litigation that may arise in the event of non-compliance. But I wonder how it is possible to better guide behaviors so that development is truly sustainable if we do not establish mechanisms based on sanctions. How could we educate our children if we did not have both positive and negative stimuli not to apply them, but to avoid these unnecessary and negative behaviors? And, unfortunately, there are many cases where these breaches occur and we have to ensure that there are mechanisms that will prevent it. That is why I believe that it is essential to open the debate on a mechanism based on sanctions, fair, proportional and applied to each case. And, finally, I would like to ask you what review mechanisms you foresee for the agreements already signed, so that they can incorporate these advances in an agile and rapid way in the sustainable development chapter.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Mister President! If we want to promote and strengthen human rights through trade agreements, we finally need enforceable sustainability chapters with sanction mechanisms. This is the only way we can show the citizens that we really mean business for everyone. Critics often use the USA / Guatemala as an example to explain that such a sanction mechanism does not work. But I am firmly convinced that the European Union could design an effective mechanism that provides sanctions as the last resort to settle disputes. In most cases, it won't matter at all. But the mere possibility of being able to impose sanctions has already led to improvements on the ground in the past, for example in the case of GSP + for El Salvador. In future, employees and the environment must be given the same priority as tariff reductions, market access or the protection of investors. We will not get any further with voluntariness and pure dialogue. Sanction mechanisms are needed in trade agreements.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I say to those Members – although they have left – who said there are no human rights in EU trade policy and that all that matters is the multinationals, I think that is totally wrong. The debate just before this one, on the report by Mr Buchner, was indeed about how we can increase export controls to make sure that dual-use surveillance equipment and other items are not used to abuse human rights. Very recently, before Christmas, you voted with a very strong majority in favour of the regulation for equipment that can be used for torture and the death penalty. Before that, there was a vote on conflict minerals, so I think it is totally unfair to say that there is no human rights dimension in EU trade policy. Today we are talking about how to enforce the chapter on sustainable development in our free trade agreements. We do not have free trade agreements with China or Pakistan or Equatorial Guinea or other countries that were mentioned here. We are talking about free trade agreements that we have negotiated in partnership with other countries. So we need to find a way where they can also agree to have it included in the agreement and that is a challenge. But more and more countries actually do sign up to the same notion as we do, that trade policy should be value-based, should be progressive, should include elements that are not only about facilitating trade, but that are also sustainable and fair. When we meet in different conferences and so on, we have a group of progressive-minded countries – and that group is getting bigger – who do want to trade in this way. There are other countries where this is less obvious, and that is what we are talking about. Sustainable development chapters in trade can be a very important tool here. We have seen that some countries have been persuaded by these chapters to involve civil society in trade evaluation; this has been very useful. I think we all agree that we need to enforce this in a much better way and we need to make them stronger. The question is, how can we do this in a way that that actually works? I do not have the final answer today. I know that some of you are calling for sanctions. This sounds attractive, but we need to find a way, as some of you have said, that is fair. We need to prove in a trade agreement that violation of human rights in sustainable development is actually trade-distorting, and that is not easy. I am still waiting for concrete suggestions on how to do that. We need to focus on how we can improve this. As I said, we have already received many useful suggestions and others have signalled to us that they are working on reports. They will send them in in the coming weeks and that is extremely helpful. We have been engaging broadly in conferences, my team has been travelling to many countries of the European Union, you in this House have been active and many NGOs and many national parliaments have been active in this debate, and that is very welcome because it shows that we need to find a way to improve this. There are many academic studies as well. Many of them prove that engagement is more effective than sanctions, but we are looking at this and talking to different researchers and different academic environments to get more input on this. The debate will still continue. It does not have a formal deadline, even if, we should wrap up soon, but I want to give the chance to those who have signalled to us that they are working on proposals and suggestions to get back to us. When we have a clearer picture of this – and the debate seems to be fading out – I will be happy to come back to this plenary and further discuss it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.I thank all colleagues who have done their own speeches the honor of hearing the Commissioner's reply.The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: written. - In my opinion, the pie is still unevenly divided when it comes to the benefits of international trade. Shareholders and employers benefit more from trade than, say, employees or the environment. That must change. Not only for employees or for the environment, but also to combat unfair competition between companies. I admit that the history of the trade agreements concluded by the European Union shows a positive learning curve. For example, a sustainability section has been included in the trade agreement with South Korea. However, it is not enforceable. At CETA, we have demanded that enforceability of decent labor and environmental standards. The European Union must ensure that the chapters related to labor and environmental standards can be enforced in practice. This means, for example, that people must be able to associate themselves in trade unions and have the right to collective action. These standards must be enforceable by people at the local level, with reference to the trade agreement. Only in this way can the European Union combat social or environmental dumping in third countries.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - The European Union's trade policy is to be based on values. It is supposed to go beyond regulating and deepening our trade relations with a consequent positive impact on our partner countries. One way to do this is to include sustainable development chapters in EU trade agreements with third countries. They can be tools for promoting relevant international labor and environmental standards as well as for the overall projection of human rights and good governance principles. Note, however, that the provisions on sustainability chapters are already binding and subject to a mutually recognized dispute settlement mechanism. The European Commission should therefore exhaust all existing means, including the dispute settlement mechanisms already agreed. The criminal sanctions mechanism proposed by some could destabilize relations with our trading partners with whom we want to conclude sustainable trade agreements, and thus be counterproductive. Moreover, such an approach would lead to a lower level of protection due to the more limited scope of FTAs. So we must first begin to use the resources at our disposal effectively before deciding to punish our partners.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: written. - The European Union is committed to respecting human rights, workers' rights and environmental standards in its trade policy. The inclusion of chapters on sustainable development in its trade agreements is therefore a very good evolution. However, the enforceability of these chapters leaves a lot to be desired. These cannot be substantiated at present, as there is no system of sanctioning for non-compliance. The great danger is therefore that the words remain fine and good intentions with regard to working conditions, respect for environmental standards and human rights remain a dead letter. There is no strong incentive for the EU's trading partners to comply with these provisions. I call on the European Commission to opt for binding provisions on human rights, workers' rights and environmental standards. Binding provisions, with sanctions if our trading partner breaches the provisions. This also requires close monitoring of effective compliance. In this way, trade will no longer be tolerated with countries where workers' rights and environmental requirements are questioned. This chapter will then no longer exist purely formally, but will also efficiently strengthen more sustainable trade.
